characters.name: etymology:
data: <\b{}capensis\b0{} = from the "Cape of Good Hope".>
<\b{}crinus (L.)\b0{} = hair, presumably referring to the hair-like leaf-sheath apices.>

<\b{}Ecklon, C.F.\b0{} = collected extensively in southern Africa from 1823 until 1832, much in collaboration with Drege. Separately and together they collected many new species of Restionaceae, which were described by Masters, Nees, and others.>
<\b{}gramen (L.) \b0{}= grass, + \b{}folius (L.)\b0{} = leaf, referring to the grass-like leaves of young plants>
<\b{}insignis (L.)\b0{} = remarkable for, outstanding, noted. Probably referring to the tall size of the plants.>
<\b{}laxe (L.)\b0{} = loosely + \b{}flos (L.)\b0{} = flowers, referring to the flowers not tightly aggregated into spikelets.>
<\b{}singularis (L.)\b0{} = unique, indicating that the species does not appear to have any close relatives, is not similar to any other species.>
<\b{}albus (L.)\b0{} = white, + \b{}aristatum (L.)\b0{} = awns, referring to the strikingly pale awns or bract apices found in some specimens.>
<\b{}altus\b0{} \b{}(L.)\b0{} = high, elevated, + \b{}cola (L.)\b0{} = dweller, suggesting that this species is found at high altitudes.>

<\b{}Andreae, H.K.C.\b0{}, came to South Africa from Germany as an assistant to Dr Marloth, and collected Restionaceae mainly in the more arid inland mountains. Two restioid species were named after him by Neville Pillans.>
<\b{}capitulum (L.)\b0{} = head, referring to the capitate female inflorescence characteristic of this species>
<\b{}chartaceus (L.) \b0{}= papery, referring to the floral bracts>
<\b{}delicatus (L.)\b0{} = addicted to pleasure, dainty, fastidious, referring to the dainty appearance of the plants, and their fastidious restriction to a very beautiful, if isolated, mountain.>

<\b{}Esterhuysen, E.E.\b0{} = the foremost collector from the Cape mountains, who made Restionaceae her speciality. She collected actively from 1930 to 1990, and contributed more to our knowledge of the Cape flora than any other collector. Her meticulous collections, assembled to reflect the distribution range and morphological variability of each species, are currently housed at the Bolus Herbarium.>
<\b{}insignis (L.)\b0{} = remarkable for, outstanding, noted. Probably referring to the tall size of the plants.>
<\b{}longus (L.)\b0{} = long, + \b{}flos (L.)\b0{} = flower, referring to the long flowers in this species.>
<\b{}nitens (L.)\b0{} = shiny, polished. This might refer to the perianth of the flowers, which in the whole genus is rather shiny.>
<\b{}panicula (L.)\b0{} = panicle, probably referred to the paniculate inflorescence, which is common in Restionaceae.>
<\b{}ruga\b0{} \b{}(L.)\b0{} = wrinkle or fold, but it is not clear what structure this is referring to.>
<\b{}anfractus (L.)\b0{} = turn, referring to the locality of the species, "Keerom", meaning "turn around" in Afrikaans.>
<\b{}arenos (G.)\b0{} = sand, + \b{}cola (L.)\b0{} = dweller in, referring to the sandveld habitat of the species.>
<\b{}aristate (L.) \b0{}= hair. Might refer to the long acuminate bracts.>
<\b{}congestus (L.)\b0{} = collecting, heaping together. The name might refer to the overlapping female spikelets.>
<\b{}grandis (L.)\b0{} = large, tall, full grown. Refers to the large growthform.>
<\b{}nitidus (L.) \b0{} = shiny, sleek, fat, in good condition. Not clear what this name refers to, possibly the shiny, rounded nuts.>
<\b{}parvus (L.)\b0{} = small, + \b{}flos (L.)\b0{} = flower. Possibly referring the small male flowers.>
<\b{}Primos, R.,\b0{} a relatively poorly known collector, who first collected this species.>
<\b{}Saunders, Rod and Rachel, \b0{}seed collectors and very knowledgeable botanists from Cape Town, who contributed much to this study of the Restionaceae.>

<\b{}Schlechter, R.\b0{}, superb orchidologist, collected extensively in South Africa at the end of the 19th Century. Although his major contribution was a new classification of orchids, he collected several new species of Restionaceae while in South Africa.>
<\b{}scirpus\b0{} \b{}(L.)\b0{} = rush, + \b{}oides\b0{} = like. Suggesting that the plant is rush-like.>
<\b{}dolicho (G.)\b0{} = long, + \b{}caryon (G.)\b0{} = nut. Refers to the remarkably long, slender nut characteristic of this species.>
<\b{}virgate (L.)\b0{} = branching, after the branching habit of the plants>
<\b{}argenteum (L.)\b0{} = silver. In reference to the appearance of the male inflorescence with its silvery bracts.>
<\b{}caespitosus (L.)\b0{} = turf, botanically meaning tufted. In reference to the tufted growthform of this species, contrasting to the spreading stolons of its relatives.>
<\b{}decipiens (L.)\b0{} = to deceive or beguile. I am not sure what this refers to.>
<\b{}fimbriatum (L.)\b0{} = fringed. This probably refers to the ciliate sheath margins.>
<\b{}fistula (L.)\b0{} = tube, or water pipe. Referring to the hollow culms typical of this species.>
<\b{}persistens (L.) \b0{} = to persist, remain constant. Referring to the resprouting habit of the plants, allowing them to survive the frequent devastating fires.>
<\b{}pulcher (L.)\b0{} = beautiful, fair, lovely. Referring to the stunning appearance of these plants when in full flower.>
<\b{}xeros (G.) \b0{}= dry, + \b{}philo (G.)\b0{} = loving, fond of. Referring to this species' preference for dry habitats.>

<\b{}Acocks, J.P.H.\b0{}, formerly spelt his surname "Acock", produced a detailed study of the vegetation types of South Africa (published 1953), in the process of which he collected numerous excellent herbarium specimens and many new species. His survey of the Bottelary Hills for a Masters resulted in the first documentation of several now very rare species found on seasonally waterlogged sands.>
<\b{}aggregatum (L.) \b0{} = clustered. Refers to the tightly aggregated female spikelets, making an almost capitate inflorescence.>
<\b{}alte (L.)\b0{} = high up, + \b{}genero (L.)\b0{} = to beget. Suggesting that this species was produced at a high altitude.>
<\b{}amoenus (L.)\b0{} = pleasant, delightful to look at. It is indeed one of the more beautiful species of Restionaceae.>
<\b{}asperus (L.)\b0{} = roughness, +\b{} flos (L.)\b0{} = flowers. Rough flowers, referring to the acuminate bracts giving the inflorescences a bristly appearance.>
<\b{}atratus (L.)\b0{} = clothed in black, + \b{}flos (L.)\b0{} = flower. Referring to the black or dark coloured flowers.>
<\b{}caespitosus (L.)\b0{} = tufted. Referring to the tufted growthform.>
<\b{}capensis\b0{} = of or from the Cape.>
<\b{}coleurus (L.)\b0{} = a leather sack, liquid measure. Not at all clear what this means.>
<\b{}cuspidatus (L.)\b0{} = point, spear. Referring to the acuminate floral bracts, unusual in this genus.>
<\b{}decipiens (L.)\b0{} = to deceive or beguile. I am not sure what this refers to.>
<\b{}deustum (L.)\b0{} = to burn down or out. Not at all clear why the poor species has this name.>
<\b{}glomero (L.)\b0{} = to form in a sphere. Referring to the globose female inflorescences.>
<\b{}ebracteatum (L.) \b0{} = without bracts. Might refer to the greatly reduced size of the floral bracts, typical of most species of \i{}Chondropetalum\b{}.\b0\i0{}>
<\b{}elephas (L.)\b0{} = elephant. This species is known as "Olifantsriet" on the West Coast.>
<\b{}equisetum\b0{} = horsetails. Referring to the similarity in the vegetative growth-form between this species and the genus \i{}Equisetum\i0{}.>

<\b{}Esterhuysen, E.E.\b0{} = the foremost collector from the Cape mountains, who made Restionaceae her speciality. She collected actively from 1930 to 1990, and contributed more to our knowledge of the Cape flora than any other collector. Her meticulous collections, assembled to reflect the distribution range and morphological variability of each species, are currently housed at the Bolus Herbarium.>
<\b{}extendo (L.)\b0{} = to stretch out, expand. Referring to the curious spreading rhizomes typical of this species.>
<\b{}fastigiatus (L.)\b0{} = pointed, sloping down. Maybe this refers to the floral bracts.>
<\b{}fenestratus (L.)\b0{} = window, loopholes, a breach. The reason for this is not known.>
<\b{}filum (L.)\b0{} = a thread. Maybe referring to the slender culms.>
<\b{}fistula (L.)\b0{} = a pipe. Referring to the hollow culms.>
<\b{}fuco (L.)\b0{} = to colour, paint. Probably referring to the beautifully coloured sheaths.>

<\b{}Galpin, E.E.\b0{}, a banker and naturalist, collected widely in South Africa from 1881 to 1940, mostly in the summer-rainfall parts of the country. His collections formed the nucleus of what eventually became the National Herbarium in Pretoria.>
<\b{}grandis (L.)\b0{} = large. Referring to the relatively tall plants, but even taller inflorescences.>
<\b{}grandis (L.)\b0{} = large, + \b{}spicatus\b0{} = spikelets. Referring to the large inflorescences of this species.>

<\b{}Hooker\b0{} = British botanist, associated with the Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew. W.J. Hooker was the director of Kew, died in 1865. His son, J.D., was the director at Kew after 1865, and presumably this species was called after him. The two Hookers were amongst the most influential systematic botanists of the 19th Century.>

<\b{}Hutchinson, J.\b0{}, a remarkably productive botanist from the Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew, who collected in South Africa in 1928/1929, and again in 1930. He befriended Gen. Smuts, and wrote a very useful book on Systematic Botany in South Africa.>
<\b{}intermedius (L.)\b0{} = in the middle. Not sure what this is called after.>
<\b{}junceus (L.)\b0{} = rushlike, made of rushes. Suggesting that this species looks like a rush (Juncaceae).>
<\b{}macros (G.)\b0{} = large, + \b{}carpos (G.)\b0{} = fruit. Referring to the large fruit typical of this species.>

<\b{}Marloth, H.W.R.\b0{}, a chemist, who was one of South Africa's foremost natural historians. He settled in Cape Town in 1883, and was one of the first to explore the higher mountains, in the course of which he discovered many new species. His greatest impact was by thinking about plants and vegetation in a remarkably modern way, and much of his work has only recently been taken further forward.>
<\b{}micro (G.)\b0{} = small, + \b{}carpos (G.)\b0{} = fruit. Referring to the small fruit of this species.>
<\b{}mucro (L.)\b0{} = sharp point or edge. Not clear which plant part this refers to.>

<\b{}Muir, J.\b0{}, a physician at Riversdale, who made a comprehensive survey of the vegetation of the Riversdale area in 1929, in addition to other researches in natural history. He collected many new species in this area.>
<\b{}namaquense (L.) =\b0{} Namaqualand, the region where the species was originally found.>
<\b{}nudus (L.)\b0{} = naked, unclothed. Maybe referring the flowers not covered by bracts.>
<\b{}persisto (L.)\b0{} = remain constant, persist. It is not clear what aspect of the species Masters was referring to.>
<\b{}promineo (L.)\b0{} = to stand out, jut out, project. Maybe Pillans was referring to the prominent stylopodium in the species.>
<\b{}racemose\b0{} = referring to the unbranched inflorescence?>
<\b{}rectum\b0{} \b{}(L.)\b0{} = to guide, direct. Not clear what this means.>
<\b{}rigidus (L.)\b0{} = stiff, unbending, rigid, hard.>
<\b{}spathe (L.)\b0{} = broad flat wooden blade, in our species probably referring to the inflorescence spathes, which are very prominent.>
<\b{}squama\b0{} = scale.>
<\b{}stipula (L.)\b0{} = stalk, haulm, stubble. Not sure what this applies to.>

<\b{}Stokoe, T.P.\b0{}, climbed extensively in the Cape Mountains, from 1913 to 1959. He collected very extensively, if somewhat chaotically. He was the first collector of many species, and contributed much to our knowledge of the mountain flora, expecially that of the Hottentots Holland and Kogelberg.>
<\b{}tectorum (L.) \b0{}= used for covering. This plants was probably used for thatching the roofs in Cape Town several centuries ago.>
<\b{}thyrse\b0{} = a type of inflorescence; -fer = in Latin composition meaning carrying. Thus "thyrsifer" is the restio carrying a thyrse.>
<\b{}thyrse\b0{} = a type of inflorescence. But it is not clear what Masters might have referred to.>
<\b{}vagina (L.)\b0{} = sheath, scabbard. Maybe referring to the leaf sheaths?>

<\b{}Verreaux, P.J.\b0{}, collector of natural history objects, who was active in the southern Cape several times between 1826 and 1840. Although he and his brothers mostly concentrated on animals, they also collected some plants.>
<\b{}Rattray, G.\b0{}, from 1904 he was the principal of Selbourne College in East London, and collected extensively in the Eastern Cape over the next 30 years.>
<\b{}albus (L.)\b0{} = white, + \b{}aristatum (L.)\b0{} = awns, referring to the strikingly pale awns or bract apices found in some specimens.>
<\b{}alternus (L.)\b0{} = by turns, one after the other. I am not sure what Ms Esterhuysen was referring to.>
<\b{}argenteum (L.)\b0{} = of silver, or the colour of silver. Probably referring to the male spikelets, which are quite silvery at anthesis.>
<\b{}aristatus (L.)\b0{} = hair. Referring to the acuminate bracts on the female spikelets.>
<\b{}laevigatus (L.)\b0{} = smooth and polished. Maybe referring to the culms.>
<\b{}montanus (L.)\b0{} = found on mountains. The species is known only from the summit of Misty Point, one of the highest peaks in the Langeberg>

<\b{}Nees ab Esenbeck, C.G.D.\b0{}, German nature-philosopher, physician and Botanist, he described many of the earlier Ecklon and Zeyher collections of restios and grasses from the Cape, and his work had a profound influence on the knowledge of Cape grasses and restios. His work was remarkably detailed and generally excellent.>
<\b{}procurro (L.) \b0{} = to run forward. This species has long spreading rhizomes, and it might refer to these spreading the plant.>
<\b{}rigidus (L.)\b0{} = stiff, rigid, unbending. Not clear what this refers to.>
<\b{}rugosus (L.)\b0{} = full of wrinkles. Maybe this refers to the caps on the nuts.>
<\b{}squamae\b0{} = scapes. Meaning unclear.>
<\b{}stria (L.)\b0{} = furrow or groove. Refers to the striate or vertically lined culms.>
<\b{}sulcus (L.)\b0{} = furrow or wrinkle. Refers to the striate culms.>
<\b{}syn (G.)\b0{} = with, together, +\b{} lepis (G.)\b0{} = scale. Thus "with scales", maybe referring to the leaf sheaths.>
<\b{}Willdenow, C.L.\b0{} = botanist and director of the Berlin Botanical Garden in 1801. He published extensively, but apparently very little or nothing on the Cape Flora.>
<\b{}digitus (L.)\b0{} = finger, thumb. Possibly referring to the male spikelets, which could conceivably look like a thumb.>
<\b{}purpurea (L.)\b0{} = purple colour. In reference to the colour of the base of the plants.>
<\b{}spathula \b0{} = spoon. The reference is not clear.>
<\b{}obtusissima\b0{} = most blunt. Probably in reference to the rounded male spikelets.>
<\b{}singularis (L.)\b0{} = single. The reference is obscure, since the species is rather similar to \i{}N. obtusissisima\i0{}.>

<\b{}Vlok, Jan. \b0{}Botanist and environmental consultant in the southern Cape, first based at Saasveld, then in De Rust and Oudtshoorn. He has a superb knowledge of the flora and vegetation of the region, and discovered very many new species, including this new Nevillea>
<\b{}acutus (L.)\b0{} = sharp point. It is not clear what organ this refers to.>
<\b{}anceps (L.)\b0{} = two-headed. Maybe the type specimen had two spikelets?>
<\b{}calli (G.)\b0{} = beautiful, + \b{}stachyus (G.)\b0{} = spike. Kunth found the inflorescences of this species to be beautiful.>
<\b{}cascadensis\b0{} = the Cascades at Betty's Bay, where the type of this species was collected.>
<\b{}compressus (L.)\b0{} = squeezed together. In reference to the flattened culms typical of this species.>
<\b{}pauper (L.)\b0{} = poor, a poor man. I am not sure that this is the meaning of "depauperatus".>

<\b{}Galpin, E.E.\b0{}, a banker and naturalist, collected widely in South Africa from 1881 to 1940, mostly in the summer-rainfall parts of the country. His collections formed the nucleus of what eventually became the National Herbarium in Pretoria.>
<\b{}major (L.)\b0{} = great, large. This species has the largest spikelets in the genus, and the name refers to this.>
<\b{}Mt Mlanje\b0{} = the type locality, a huge granitic mountain in southern Malawi.>

<\b{}quartzite\b0{} = bedrock type on which the species grows, + \b{}cola\b0{} = to inhabit. Referring to the habitat of this species, restricted to the quartzitic rocks of the Chimanimani mountains in Zimbabwe.>
<\b{}subcompressus (L.)\b0{} = compressed. Referring to the flattened culms typical of this genus.>

<\b{}Acocks, J.P.H.\b0{}, formerly spelt his surname "Acock", produced a detailed study of the vegetation types of South Africa (published 1953), in the process of which he collected numerous excellent herbarium specimens and many new species. His survey of the Bottelary Hills for a Masters resulted in the first documentation of several now very rare species found on seasonally waterlogged sands.>
<\b{}adpressus (L.)\b0{} = lying flat against. This refers to the leaf sheaths, which are closely wrapped around the culm, while in the closely related \i{}C. fruticosa\i0{} they are spreading.>
<\b{}adfinis (L.)\b0{} = neighbouring. The reason for this name is not known.>
<\b{}albus (L.) \b0{}= two, + \b{}turbeculatum (L)\b0{} = tubercle; referring to the whitish tubercels which are characteristic of this species.>
<\b{}altus (L.)\b0{} = high, + \b{}cola (L.)\b0{} = dweller. The high-altitude dweller, referring to the habitat of this species at the summits of the Cape mountains.>

<\b{}Andreae, H.K.C.\b0{}, came to South Africa from Germany as an assistant to Dr Marloth, and collected Restionaceae mainly in the more arid inland mountains. Two restioid species were named after him by Neville Pillans.>
<\b{}a \b0{}= not, + \b{}normalis\b0{} \b{}(G)\b0{} = normal. Abnormal, referring to the absence of male plants.>
<\b{}arcuatus (L.)\b0{} = bowshaped. Probably referring to the curly terminal branches.>
<\b{}aridus (L.)\b0{} = dry, arid. Named after the habitat, on the arid fringes of the Cape mountains.>
<\b{}asper (L.)\b0{} = rough, uneven, referring to the culms.>
<\b{}aureolus (L.)\b0{} = glittering, splendid.>
<\b{}barbatus = \i{} \b0\i0{}reference to the long, straight hair from the sheath axils, thus a sparsely bearded species>
<\b{}bifarius (L.)\b0{} = in two parts.>
<\b{}bifidus (L.) \b0{}= split into two parts.>
<\b{}bifurcus (L.)\b0{} = having two prongs.>
<\b{}Blinkberg\i{} \b0\i0{}= pass leading from the Cederberg to the Ceres Cold Bokkeveld.>

<\b{}Bolus, H.\b0{}, established the Bolus Herbarium, collected actively from 1870 onwards, and published on the taxonomy of orchids and ericas. He was the first really prolific plant taxonomist resident in South Africa, and his collections and library were central to the initiation of develop of indigenous plant taxonomy in the Cape.>
<\b{}brachiatus (L.)\b0{} = belong to the arm?>
<\b{}brunneus (L.)\b0{} = deep brown. In reference to the colour of the spikelets.>

<\b{}Burchell, W.J., \b0{}a remarkable traveller, who travelled extensively in southern Africa from 1811 to 1814, covering many areas not previously explored. His account of his travels contains many insights into life at the Cape, and more remarkably, often lists of species and vegetation descriptions of various areas. His specimens were meticulously labelled, but unfortunately only became available for study more than 40 years after they were collected.>
<\b{}caespitusus (L.)\b0{} = tufted. Named after the growth-form, with the plants forming small rounded cushions.>
<\b{}saxum calcareum (L.) \b0{}= limestone, + \b{}cola (L.)\b0{} = dweller; referring to the preference of the species to limestones.>
<\b{}capensis\b0{}. Named after the Cape of Good Hope.>
<\b{}capillaris (L.)\b0{} = hair-like. Referring to the very slender culms.>
<\b{}Cedarberg (L.)\b0{} = referring to the distribution range, from the southern Cedarberg into the northern Bokkeveld mts.>
<\b{}cincinnus (L.)\b0{} = curled hair. Referring to the characteristically curly ends of the culms.>
<\b{}clandestinus (L.)\b0{} = secret, concealed, hidden. Referring to the obscured or hidden female flowers.>
<\b{}coactio (L.)\b0{} = a collecting. Rather obscure, what this could refer to.>
<\b{}collis (L.) \b0{} = hill, + \b{}sperma (G.)\b0{} = seed. Referring to the colliculate seed coat.>
<\b{}communis (L.)\b0{} = public, shared. Maybe referring to the plants occurring in dense stands.>
<\b{}confusus (L.)\b0{} = confused, join together. Not clear what the species got this name.>
<\b{}constipata (L.)\b0{} = crowded together, referring to the male and female spikelets, clustered together in the capitate inflorescences.>
<\b{}corneolus (L.)\b0{} = horny. Possibly referring to the texture of the bracts.>
<\b{}curvo (L.) \b0{}= to bend, arch, curve, + \b{}bractea\b0{} = specialised leaf, here probably the floral bract. Here referring to the recurved, acuminate spikelet bracts.>
<\b{}curvo (L.) \b0{}= to bend, arch, curve, + \b{}ramus (L.)\b0{} = branch, twig. Thus "curved twigs" probably referring to the curved terminal culms.>
<\b{}debilis (L.)\b0{} = feeble, weak. Possibly referring to the slender, weak culms of this species.>
<\b{}decipiens (L.)\b0{} = to deceive.>
<\b{}degenero (L.)\b0{} = to become unlike one's race.>
<\b{}dispar (L.)\b0{} = dissimilar, unequal.>
<\b{}distans (L.)\b0{} = distance, diversity.>
<\b{}distichus (L.)\b0{} = arranged in two opposite rows.>
<\b{}duo (L.) \b0{}= two, + \b{}stylus (L.) \b0{}= styles; referring to the two styles of the species.>
<\b{}distraho (L.)\b0{} = to pull apart or to pull to pieces. The context for this species remains obscure.>

<\b{}Wolley-Dod, A.H.\b0{}, collected in the Cape ca. 1896-1898, and seems to have been the first to have properly collected the southern Peninsula, especially the area that is now the Cape Point park. He compiled the first Checklist of species from the Cape Peninsula with Harry Bolus.>

<\b{}Wolley-Dod, A.H.\b0{}, collected in the Cape ca. 1896-1898, and seems to have been the first to have properly collected the southern Peninsula, especially the area that is now the Cape Point park. He compiled the first Checklist of species from the Cape Peninsula with Harry Bolus.>
<\b{}durus (L.)\b0{} = hard. Reason unknown.>

<\b{}Augusta Vera Duthie, \b0{}born in Knysna, lecturer in Botany in Wellington and then the University of Stellenbosch, where she was department head, started the Stellenbosch University Herbarium and specialized in the plants of the Cape Flats and from her family farm at Knysna.\b{} \b0{}>
<\b{}echinatus (L.)\b0{} = hedgehog, thus armed with numerous prickles. Probably in reference to the recurved, acuminate floral bracts, resulting in a hedge-hog like female spikelet.>
<\b{}egregius (L.)\b0{} = outstanding, different from the common herd. Probably in reference to the stature, but possibly also because it is reather different from anything else in the genus.>
<\b{}ejuncidus (L.)\b0{} = ?>
<\b{}helios (G.)\b0{} = sun, + \b{}charis (G.)\b0{} = grace. Maybe sun-graced? Possibly a reference to the plants habitat, next the beach, in sunny South Africa?>

<\b{}Esterhuysen, E.E.\b0{} = the foremost collector from the Cape mountains, who made Restionaceae her speciality. She collected actively from 1930 to 1990, and contributed more to our knowledge of the Cape flora than any other collector. Her meticulous collections, assembled to reflect the distribution range and morphological variability of each species, are currently housed at the Bolus Herbarium.>

<\b{}Esterhuysen, E.E.\b0{} = the foremost collector from the Cape mountains, who made Restionaceae her speciality. She collected actively from 1930 to 1990, and contributed more to our knowledge of the Cape flora than any other collector. Her meticulous collections, assembled to reflect the distribution range and morphological variability of each species, are currently housed at the Bolus Herbarium.>
<\b{}femineus (L.)\b0{} = relating to a woman. In reference to the absence / scarcity of males in this species.>
<\b{}Festuca\b0{} = a grass genus, + \b{}formis\b0{} = like. The inflorescence is like that of a grass.>
<\b{}filum (L.)\b0{} = a thread, + \b{}formis\b0{} = like. Probably referring to the slender culms.>
<\b{}fragilis (L.)\b0{} = weak, feeble. A weak scrambling plant.>
<\b{}fraternus (L.)\b0{} = brotherly. The context remains obscure.>
<\b{}fuscus (L.)\b0{} = dark-coloured, dark. I am not sure why it got this name.>
<\b{}fusiformis (L.)\b0{} = swollen in the middle, and tapering to each end.>

<\b{}Gaudichaud-Beaupre, C.\b0{}, French naturalist (1789-1854). It remains obscure why this species was named after him, since he seems not to have worked on Cape plants. Maybe we should be grateful that it was called only after the first part of his name.>
<\b{}gossypinus (L.)\b0{} = cottony. Referring to the tufts of hair / wool emerging from the leaf sheaths.>

<\b{}Harvey, W.H.\b0{}, although based in the Cape only from 1835 to 1842 (during which period he was absent in England for almost a year) had a huge impact on South African botany. Harvey produced the first "modern" account of the genera of Cape plants, and eventually, with Sonder, started the Flora Capensis. These works formed the foundation on which the work of Bolus, Marloth, and many others was based.>
<\b{}Helena\b0{} = I have not been able to establish who this was.>
<\b{}hyalina (L.) \b0{} = glas. Referring to the transparent lobes on the sheaths.>
<\b{}hystrix\b0{} = the source or meaning of this name is unknown to me.>
<\b{}implicatio (L.)\b0{} = intertwining, interweaving. Referring to the growth-form of the species.>
<\b{}impolitus (L.)\b0{} = rough, unpolished. Referring to the tuberculate culms.>
<\b{}in\b0{} = not, + \b{}conspicuus\b0{} = visible, remarkable, striking. Referring to the inconspicuous appearance of the plants.>
<\b{}ingens (L.)\b0{} = huge, exceeding the size usual for the group.>
<\b{}insignis (L.)\b0{} = remarkable for, outstanding, noted. Probably referring to the tall size of the spikelets, which are among the most remarkable in the African Restionaceae.>
<\b{}inveteratus (L.)\b0{} = of long standing, established, firmly rooted. Possibly referring to the plants being firmly rooted.>
<\b{}Karoo\b0{} = arid desert-like interior of the country, also can refer to arid places in South Africa. In reference to the aridity of the habitat of this species.>
<\b{}laniger (L.)\b0{} = wool-bearing. In reference to the tufts of hair or wool from the leaf axils.>
<\b{}leptos (G.)\b0{} = fine, slender, + \b{}stachys (G.)\b0{} = spike. Thus "slender-spike">

<\b{}Levyns, M.R.B.\b0{}, lecturer in Botany at the University of Cape Town from 1916 to 1945. She revised several taxonomically difficult genera, and wrote several influential papers on the biogeography of the Cape Flora. She collected mostly along the arid fringes of the Cape Flora.>
<\b{}longus (L.)\b0{} = long, + \b{}arista (L.)\b0{} = hair. This refers to the long, slender aristae on the sheaths and bracts.>
<\b{}leptos (G.)\b0{} = thin, slender, + \b{}clados (G.)\b0{} = branch. Referring to the slender culms of this species.>
<\b{}Luxurians (L.) = \b0{}luxuriant. The reason for the name is not known.>
<\b{}macer (L.)\b0{} = thin, poor. Maybe referring to a typical, slender, restio plant?>

<\b{}Marloth, H.W.R.\b0{}, a chemist, who was one of South Africa's foremost natural historians. He settled in Cape Town in 1883, and was one of the first to explore the higher mountains, in the course of which he discovered many new species. His greatest impact was by thinking about plants and vegetation in a remarkably modern way, and much of his work has only recently been taken further forward.>
<\b{}micans (L.)\b0{} = to shine, glitter, from things moving. Maybe referring to the bracts?>
<\b{}miser (L.)\b0{} = miserable, wretched, unhappy, pitiable. Possibly referring to the very slender culms of the species.>
<\b{}Mkambati\b0{} = National Park in Pondoland, the area in which this species is found>
<\b{}monos (G.)\b0{} = solitary, + \b{}anthos (G.)\b0{} = flower. Referring to the single-flowered spikelets found in some specimens.>
<\b{}mono (G.) \b0{} = one, single + \b{}stylus (L.)\b0{} = style. Referring to the single style of this species/>
<\b{}montanus (L.)\b0{} = of mountains, or found in mountains.>
<\b{}nubigena (L.)\b0{} = born from a cloud. In reference to the habitat of the species, mostly near mountain summits frequently encased in cloud.>

<\b{}Muir, J.\b0{}, a physician at Riversdale, who made a comprehensive survey of the vegetation of the Riversdale area in 1929, in addition to other researches in natural history. He collected many new species in this area.>
<\b{}multus (L.)\b0{} = many, + \b{}flos (L.)\b0{} = flower. Many-flowered, possibly referring to the spikelets.>
<\b{}nanus (L.)\b0{} = dwarf. Referring to the small size of the plants.>
<\b{}nodosus (L.)\b0{} = full of knots. Maybe referring to the round spikelets.>
<\b{}nudus (L.) \b0{} = naked, unclothed, bare, + \b{}flos (L.)\b0{} = flower. Referring to the flowers visible above the bracts.>

<\b{}Nuweberg\b0{} = one of the names for the mountains between Elgin and Jonkershoek, largely based on the name of the forest station on the inland slopes of the mountains. It is the type locality of the species.>
<\b{}obscurus (L.)\b0{} = to cover, darken, obscure.>
<\b{}occultus (L.)\b0{} = to hide, conceal.>
<\b{}ocreatus (L.)\b0{} = wearing greaves. Probably in reference to the striking, almost free-standing sheaths on the culms.>
<\b{}pachys (G.) \b0{}= thick, stout, + \b{}stachys (G.)\b0{} = spike. Referring to the almost round spikelets.>
<\b{}paludosus (L.)\b0{} = marshy, boggy. Referring to the habitat of this species, usually in marshy places.>
<\b{}paluster (L.)\b0{} = marshy, + \b{}cola (L.)\b0{} = dweller in. Referring to the habitat of the species in boggy places.>
<\b{}panicle \b0{}= branching inflorescence, referring the the characteristically large branching inflorescence topping the plants.>
<\b{}papilla (L.)\b0{} = nipple or teat. Referring to the tuberculate culms, covered in small nipple-like bumps.>
<\b{}papyraceus\b0{} = papery. In reference to the bracts.>
<\b{}pateo (L.)\b0{} = to be open, stand open, or lie open.>
<\b{}parthenocarpus (Gk.) \b0{}= Producing seed or fruit without fertilization>
<\b{}membrana (L.)\b0{} = thin skin, film or membrane. Refers to the membranous lobes on the bracts and sheaths.>
<\b{}peculiaris (L.)\b0{} = provided with a special property. Probably referring to the appearance of the plants with their stubby culms and long, membranous sheath lobes.>
<\b{}pedicellaris \b0{} = provided with a pedicel. But where on the plant?>
<\b{}perplexus (L.)\b0{} = confused, entangled. This probably refers to the tangled growth-form typical of this species.>
<\b{}persevero (L.)\b0{} = to persist, persevere, continue.>

<\b{}Pillans, N.S.\b0{}, Mr Neville Pillans was the specialist on African Restionaceae for a good 50 years, from 1920 till his death in 1964. He described numerous new species, and published the last comprehensive revision of the African Restionaceae, in 1928. The quality of his work was outstanding.>
<\b{}praeacutus (L.)\b0{} = sharpen to a point, pointed. Possibly referring to the apices of the female spikelets.>
<\b{}pratensis (L.)\b0{} = of a meadow. The species is found in short vegetation in seasonally waterlogged lowlands, possibly the closest Cape approximation of a meadow.>
<\b{}pulcher (L.)\b0{} = beautiful, fair, lovely. Referring to the appearance of the plant.>
<\b{}pulvinus (L.)\b0{} = cushion. Referring to the growth-form, with the plants forming dense cushions.>
<\b{}purpuratus (L.)\b0{} = clad in purple. Possibly referring to the colour of the sheaths.>
<\b{}pumilus (L.)\b0{} = a dwarf. R.referring to the small size of the plants.>
<\b{}pygmaei (L.)\b0{} = races of dwarfs inhabiting Africa. Referring to the small stature of the plants.>
<\b{}quadratus (L.)\b0{} = square. Referring to the culms.>
<\b{}quinque (L.)\b0{} = five, + \b{}farius (L.)\b0{} = ranked. Thus five-ranked, referring most likely to the bracts in the female spikelet.>
<\b{}ramosissimus (L.)\b0{} = much branched. This refers the culms, and indeed the whole plant, which forms a small, tangled tuft.>
<\b{}rarus (L.)\b0{} = rare, infrequent: presumably referring to its rarity. Although, strictly speaking, it is solitary, not infrequent.>
<\b{}rigidus (L.)\b0{} = still, unbending, rigid, hard.The name might refer to the stiff and rigid floral bracts.>
<\b{}rigorata (L.) \b0{}= stiff, rigid. Possibly referring to the habit of the plant.>
<\b{}rivulus (L.)\b0{} = a small brook. The species is generally found near streams or seepages.>
<\b{}Rottboell, C.F., \b0{}Danish botanist, student of Linnaeus, and director of the Copenhagen botanical garden, 1770-1797.>

<\b{}Marloth, H.W.R.\b0{}, a chemist, who was one of South Africa's foremost natural historians. He settled in Cape Town in 1883, and was one of the first to explore the higher mountains, in the course of which he discovered many new species. His greatest impact was by thinking about plants and vegetation in a remarkably modern way, and much of his work has only recently been taken further forward.>
<\b{}rupes\b0{} (L) = rock or cliff, + \b{}cola\b0{} (L) = dweller: thus the rockdweller, referring to its habitat.>
<\b{}sabulum (L.) \b0{} = gravel, sand. Referring to the habitat in sandy places.>
<\b{}sarco\b0{} ? + \b{}clados (G.)\b0{} = branch.>
<\b{}saxatilis (L.)\b0{} = frequenting rocks, found among rocks. In reference to the habitat of the species in the coastal mountains.>
<\b{}scaber (L.)\b0{} = rough. Referring probably to the tuberculate culms.>
<\b{}scaber (L.)\b0{} = rough. Referring probably to the tuberculate culms.>
<\i{}Schoenus\i0{}, a genus of sedges, suggesting that this species looks like a \i{}Schoenus\i0{}. This is stretching the analogy, I fail to see much similarity . . .>
<\b{}secundus (L.)\b0{} = following, going the same way, successful. The connection to our species is not clear.>
<\b{}sejunctus (L.)\b0{} = a separation.>
<\b{}setiger (L.)\b0{} = having bristles, bristly. Referring to the spikelets, with acuminate awns which gives them a bristly appearance.>
<\b{}Sieber, F.W.\b0{}, commercial herbarium specimen collector, who visited the Cape in 1824, where he made a collection. He also took the large collections of Zeyher and Drege back to Germany.>
<\b{}similis (L.)\b0{} = like, resembling, similar.>
<\b{}singularis (L.)\b0{} = unique, single.>
<\b{}sporadicus (L.)\b0{} = here and there. Maybe referring to the rarity of the species.>
<\b{}stereo (L.)\b0{} = two, + \b{}caulos (G.)\b0{} = stem. Possibly referring to the flattened (two-sided) culms.>

<\b{}Stokoe, T.P.\b0{}, climbed extensively in the Cape Mountains, from 1913 to 1959. He collected very extensively, if somewhat chaotically. He was the first collector of many species, and contributed much to our knowledge of the mountain flora, expecially that of the Hottentots Holland and Kogelberg. There is an excellent biogeographical account of Stokoe.>
<\b{}strictus (L.)\b0{} = close, tight, brief, concise.>
<\b{}strobilus (G.) \b0{} = spinning top. Probably in reference to the spindle-shaped female spikelet.>
<\b{}subtilis (L.)\b0{} = finely woven, slender, fine. Maybe in reference to the slender culms.>
<\b{}verticellata (L.) \b0{}= whorled. Referring to the branches, appearing in poorly defined whorls at each node.>
<\b{}tetra\b0{} \b{} (G.)\b0{} = four, + \b{}goni (G.)\b0{} = angled. Referring the the four-angled culms.>
<\b{}tenuis (L.) \b0{}= slender \b{}+ spicatus (L.)\b0{} = spike, referring to the slender spikelets.>
<\b{}tenuissimus (L.)\b0{} = very slender, most slender. Referring to the very thin culms.>
<\b{}tri (L.)\b0{} = three, + \b{}flos (L.)\b0{} = flowers. Referring to three-flowered spikelets, found in this species.>
<\b{}triticum\b0{} = wheat. Suggesting the plant looks like wheat.>
<\b{}tuber (L.) \b0{} = swelling, hump. Referring to the coarsely tubercled culms.>
<\b{}unus \b0{}(L.) = one; \b{}florus\b0{} (L.) = flowers, referring to the single-flowered spikelets>
<\b{}unus (L.)\b0{} = one, + \b{}spica (L.)\b0{} = spike. Referring to the female inflorescences, which always bear only one spikelet.>
<\b{}venustulus (L.)\b0{} = charming. Maybe Kunth found this species particularly attractive?>
<\b{}vallis (L.)\b0{} = valley, + \b{}simius (L.)\b0{} = baboons. After "Baviaanskloof", the type locality.>
<\b{}verruca (L.)\b0{} = a wart. Referring to the roughly warty culms.>
<\b{}versatilis\b0{} = turning around, revolving.>
<\b{}vilis (L.)\b0{} = cheap, worth little. This is a terrible thing to say about this species!>
<\b{}villosus (L.)\b0{} = referring the remarkably densely villous bracts and flowers.>
<\b{}vimineus (L.)\b0{} = having long flexible shoots. Presumably referring to the spreading culms.>
<\b{}virgeus (L.)\b0{} = make of twigs. Maybe in reference to the finely branching habit?>
<\b{}Wallich, N.\b0{}, Superintendent of the East India Co. botanic garden in Calcutta, and collected on periodic visits to the Cape, especially in 1842-1843.>
<\b{}witteberg\b0{} = the mountain range behind Laingsburg where this species is restricted to.>
<\b{}zulus\b0{} = inhabitants of KwaZulu-Natal, the home province of this species.>
<\b{}Zwartberg\b0{}, the mountain behind Caledon, the type locality.>
<\b{}alpinus (L.)\b0{} = growing in the alpine zone. This species is restricted to the summits of the mountains.>
<\b{}aridus (L.)\b0{} = dry, withered. In reference to the dry areas in which this species is found.>
<\b{}capensis = \b0{}from the Cape of Good Hope.>
<\b{}foliosus (L.)\b0{} = leafy, full of leaves. The species usually has clusters of sterile branches at the nodes of the fertile culms, these look quite leafy.>
<\b{}fruticosus (L.)\b0{} = shrubby, bushy. A strange name, the species has simple culms.>
<\b{}giganteus (L.)\b0{} = giant, very large. This is a suitable name, as this is the tallest species in the genus.>
<\b{}gracilis (L.)\b0{} = thin, slender. It is possibly the most slender-culmed species in the genus.>
<\b{}Vleiberg\b0{}, a little known peak in the Swartruggens, from which this new species was first recorded.>
<\b{}ambiguus (L.)\b0{} =\b{} \b0{}of doubtful nature, uncertain.>
<\b{}aemulus (L.)\b0{} = more or less equalling.>
<\b{}Banks, J.\b0{}, wealthy patron of sciences, and a naturalist. Visited the Cape for a month in 1771, during which time he and Solander collected several hundred specimens.>
<\b{}cernuus (L.)\b0{} = slightly drooping, maybe in reference to the male spikelets.>
<\b{}di (G.)\b0{} = two, + \b{}stachys (G.)\b0{} = spikelet, thus "two-spikeletted". Often plants in this species have two spikelets.>
<\b{}multus (L.)\b0{} = many, + \b{}spicula (L.)\b0{} = spikelets. The species differs from its relatives by having several female spikelets, not one or two only.>
<\b{}ornatus (L.)\b0{} = adorned, embellished. In reference to the dissected and ornamented perianth wings.>
<\b{}remotus (L.)\b0{} = scattered, not close together. In reference to the populations being isolated from each other, restricted to the summits of mountains.>

<\b{}Stokoe, T.P.\b0{}, climbed extensively in the Cape Mountains, from 1913 to 1959. He collected very extensively, if somewhat chaotically. He was the first collector of many species, and contributed much to our knowledge of the mountain flora, expecially that of the Hottentots Holland and Kogelberg.>
<\b{}vaginatus (L.)\b0{} = sheath. Maybe in reference to the leaves reduced to sheaths.>
<\b{}acuminatus (L.)\b0{} = tapering from inwardly curved sides into a narrow point.>
<\b{}amoenus (L.)\b0{} = pleasant, delightful to look at. This is one of the most strikingly beautiful restios.>
<\b{}arenarius (L.)\b0{} = growing in sand.>
<\b{}Bachmann, F.E.\b0{}, practised medicine in Darling and Hopefield from 1883-1887, during which time he collected several new species on in the Sandveld along the West Coast.>
<\b{}cinereus (L.)\b0{} = ash grey. In reference to the colour of the female bracts.>
<\b{}dumosus (L.)\b0{} = of bushy habit. Possibly in reference to the clusters of sterile branches often produced by this species.>
<\b{}ellipticus (L.)\b0{} = elliptical, maybe in reference to the shape of the dispersal unit.>
<\b{}erectus (L.)\b0{} = erect.>
<\b{}fraternus (L.)\b0{} = brotherly. Maybe due to the similarity to \i{}T. paniculatus\i0{}?>
<\b{}fruticosus (L.)\b0{} = bushy. The fertile culms frequently have clusters of sterile branches at the nodes, giving the plants a somewhat bushy appearance.>
<\b{}glaber (L.)\b0{} = hairless.>
<\b{}gracilis (L.)\b0{} = very slender.>

<\b{}Guthrie, F.\b0{}, mathematician and botanical collaborator of Harry Bolus on the taxonomy of \i{}Erica\i0{} for Flora Capensis. He assembled and excellent herbarium, which is now incorporated in the Bolus Herbarium.>
<\b{}insignis (L.)\b0{} = remarkable for, outstanding, noted. Probably referring to the tall size of the plants.>
<\b{}Karoo\b0{} = arid interior part of southern Africa. This species is found along the margins of the Little Karoo.>
<\b{}Kammannassie\b0{} = mountain range at eastern end of Little Karoo, where the species is found>

<\b{}Levyns, M.R.B.\b0{}, lecturer in Botany at the University of Cape Town from 1916 to 1945. She revised several taxonomically difficult genera, and wrote several influential papers on the biogeography of the Cape Flora. She collected mostly along the arid fringes of the Cape Flora. Dr Levyns collected the type specimen of this species.>
<\b{}lucens (L.)\b0{} = shining, polished.>

<\b{}Muir, J.\b0{}, a physician at Riversdale, who made a comprehensive survey of the vegetation of the Riversdale area in 1929, in addition to other researches in natural history. He collected many new species in this area.>
<\b{}nutans (L.)\b0{} = nodding. Maybe in reference to the pendulous male spikelets.>
<\b{}obtuse (L.)\b0{} = blunt angle.>
<\b{}paniculatus (L.)\b0{} = paniculate. Maybe in reference to the paniculate male and female inflorescences.>
<\b{}papyraceus (L.)\b0{} = papery. In reference to the distinctly papery floral bracts.>
<\b{}pellucidus (L.)\b0{} = translucent by not glassy. This describes the female floral bracts.>
<\b{}platy- (G.)\b0{} = broad, + \b{}pterus (G.)\b0{} = winged. In reference to the dispersal units, which are the broadest winged in the genus.>
<\b{}pluri- (L.)\b0{} = many, + \b{}stachys (G.)\b0{} = spike. Thus "many-spikeletted", which does indeed describe the species.>
<\b{}pubescens \b0{} = referring to the velvety indumentum of the culms>
<\b{}pulcher (L.)\b0{} = beautiful. Pillans was clearly enamoured by this admittedly handsome species.>
<\b{}punctatus (L.)\b0{} = dotted. In reference to the dotted culms.>
<\b{}rigidus (L.)\b0{} = rigid. In reference to the leaf-blades on the sterile shoots, which are rigid, compared to those of the closely related \i{}T. cinereus\i0{}, which are long and soft.>

<\b{}Schlechter, R.\b0{}, superb orchidologist, collected extensively in South Africa at the end of the 19th Century. Although his major contribution was a new classification of orchids, he collected several new species of Restionaceae while in South Africa.>
<\b{}spica (L.) \b0{}= spike, + \b{}gerus\b0{} = ?making.>
<\b{}sporadicus (L.)\b0{} = sporadic, here and there.>

<\b{}Stokoe, T.P.\b0{}, climbed extensively in the Cape Mountains, from 1913 to 1959. He collected very extensively, if somewhat chaotically. He was the first collector of many species, and contributed much to our knowledge of the mountain flora, expecially that of the Hottentots Holland and Kogelberg.>
<\b{}affinis (L.)\b0{} = neighbouring, related to. But it is not clear to what?>
<\b{}arescens (L.)\b0{} = becoming dry.>

<\b{}Bolus, H.\b0{}, established the Bolus Herbarium, collected actively from 1870 onwards, and published on the taxonomy of orchids and ericas. He was the first really prolific plant taxonomist resident in South Africa, and his collections and library were central to the initiation of develop of indigenous plant taxonomy in the Cape.>
<\b{}glomeratus (L.)\b0{} = forming balls. Probably referring to the galls found on the type specimen.>
<\b{}humilis (L.)\b0{} = low, low-growing. This is indeed one of the shortest species of \i{}Willdenowia\i0{}.>
<\b{}incurvatus (L.)\b0{} = curved inwards.>
<\b{}pilleatus (L.) \b0{}= a felt hat, referring to the cap on the nut.>
<\b{}purpureus (L.)\b0{} = purple.>
<\b{}rugosus (L.)\b0{} = wrinkled.>

<\b{}Stokoe, T.P.\b0{}, climbed extensively in the Cape Mountains, from 1913 to 1959. He collected very extensively, if somewhat chaotically. He was the first collector of many species, and contributed much to our knowledge of the mountain flora, expecially that of the Hottentots Holland and Kogelberg.>
<\b{}sulcatus (L.)\b0{} = furrowed, grooved. Probably a reference to the striate culms.>
<\b{}teres (L.)\b0{} = circular in transverse sections. Maybe this refers to the nut, or the culm.>

data: <Restricted to Muizenberg mt and Cape Point Nature reserve. There is one poorly substantiated record from Kleinmond, in the marshy ground between Kleinmond and the Palmiet River mouth.>

<Common in the south-western and southern, wetter mountains: the species reaches Bainskloof to the north, is common on the Peninsula and the Hottentots Holland mountains, and spreads eastwards along the Rivierzondereinde mountains to Pilaarkop, and along the Langeberg to Garcias Pass at Riversdale.>

<Widespread along the inland mountains, from the Ceres Cold Bokkeveld eastwards along the Swartberg and Langeberg to Cockscomb. Along the coastal mountains the species is rare: it is found in the Slanghoek occasionally, but is absent from the Cape Peninsula, Kogelberg and Kleinriviersmountains, as well as from the Rivierzondereinde.>
<Known from very few collections from Franshoek Pass to Betty's Bay, with one collection from the Cape Peninsula. A nice population between the old Steenbras Station and N2, in marsh in hollow.>
<Endemic to the Ceres basin.>
<Recorded from Table Mountain on the Cape Peninsula, and from the mountains between Sir Lowry's Pass and Kleinmond.>
<Scattered in the Olifantsriver mountains, from Porterville (Groot Winterhoek) to Zuurvlakte in the southern Cederberg, south of Apex Peak.>

<Endemic to the Cederberg, from Sneeuberg and Kromriver in the south to Krakadouwsberg in the north. Widespread within the Cederberg, forming numerous populations, often quite large ones, where the habitat conditions are suitable.>
<Restricted to the Hex River mountains, from Mostert Hoek Twins to Milner Peak and Jan Du Toits Pinnacles.>

<Most common in the south-western mountains, from Bains Kloof to Sir Lowry's Pass, and including the western end of the Rivierzondereinde mountains at Olifantsberg. There are two collections from east of the Breede River: one from Hansies Berg near Ceres, the other from Brandwacht near Worcester.>
<Rangeing from Matroosberg and the Sneeugat near Tulbagh in the south, common along the Bokkeveld mountains, and reaching the Central Cederberg to the north.>
<Mostly recorded from the south-western Mountains, from Bainskloof to Kogelberg, with an eastern outlier on Pilaarkop above the village of Rivierzondereinde.>
<Known from only one population on Vleiberg, in the Swartruggens, which form the border between the Koue and Warm Bokkeveld, north of Ceres.>
<Endemic to the mountains from Villiersdorp to Somerset West, with most collections from the Jonkershoek and Nuweberg mountains.>

<Very restricted, found in less than 10 populations in the Hex River Mountains and the Koue Bokkeveld mountains. The only extensive populations are on Matroosberg. It does not occur either in the Waaihoek, Winterhoek or Cederberg areas.>
<Very local, from Turrett Peak in the Cold Bokkeveld mountains, south to Waaihoek Peak near Worcester. It seems to be recorded from less than 10 localities.>
<Quite widespread in mountains from Cederberg to Caledon.>
<Widespread from the Cederberg to Jonkershoek, thus both in the northern and south-western mountains.>
<Endemic to the Palmiet River basin in the Caledon district, from Houw Hoek mountain to Somersfontein and the Arieskraal Dam.>
<Only known from the southern end of the Olifantsriver, from the Warmbaths to Groot Winterhoek.>
<A sand-veld endemic species, that ranges from Somerset West in the south, to the Berg River, and between the coastal mountains and the sea.>

<Endemic to the inland margins of the Cederberg and Cold Bokkeveld mountains, with very few populations known. However, this area has been poorly botanised, and the species may be more common than currently documented.>

<Collected from Tulbagh to Bredasdorp, very common on the Bredasdorp plains around Elim, also from Jonaskop on the dry side of the Rivierzondereinde mountains, with a few collections from the inland margins of the Slanghoek mountains. In the Caledon area it occurs along the mountains from Houw Hoek to the sea at Kleinmond.>

<The distribution is still somewhat unclear, but it appears to be along the mountains from Tulbagh in the west to the Kamanassie in the east, but absent from the Peninsula. It has been recorded from the Great and Little Swartberg, from the Langeberg, Riviersondereinde, and the mountains from Caledon to Tulbagh.>
<Widespread in the Cape mountains, from the Cederberg to Blesberg at the eastern end of the Great Swartberg, found on all peaks above 1500 m.>

<By the strict delimitation followed here, the species ranges from the Hex River Valley in the south to Nieuwoudtville in the north. Inland the species reaches the Bonteberg. The records from Piketberg are dubious, and the plants from there might constitute distinct species. It is therefore found only along the main range.>

<Widespread in the mountains from Gydouw Pass to Clanwilliam, with most collections from the Cederberg - but this might reflect only the heavier collection intensity in the northern, more accessible mountains.>
<A northwestern mountains-Swartberg distribution within the Cape Floral region, absent from the wet coastal ranges.>

<Along the arid inland mountains from Karoopoort to Pakhuis Pass, with a single outlier population in the middle of the Koue Bokkeveld. This is the ridge of mountains between the Bokkeveld plateau and the Ceres or Tankwa Karoo, and along the inland slopes of the Cederberg.>

<A southern Cape species, common on the inland, drier mountains of Kouga and Swartberg, as well as the mountains of the Little Karoo. Reaches west to Touwsriver. Records from the Caledon area are probably misidentifications.>
<Found between De Doorns and the southern base of the Hex River Mountains, and Jonaskop near Villiersdorp. This species has been recorded from only four localities.>
<Widespread and often common along the coastal areas, if found in the interior it usually occcupies the south facing mountainous slopes.>
<Restricted to the coastal plain from the Klein River at Stanford to the Gouritzriver at Albertinia.>
<Along the coastal mountains from Kogelberg (above Kogelbay) to Galpin's Kop (above Herbanus), reaching inland to Babylon's Tower.>
<Along the more mesic mountains, from the Kogelberg and Sir Lowry's Pass, eastwards along the Rivierzondereinde and Langeberg, with the easternmost collections from Garcias Pass at Riversdale.>

<A species of the southern end of the Northern Mountains, and northern end of the South-western mountains: to the north the species reaches Turret Peak in the Cold Bokkeveld, while to the south it reaches Du Toits Kloof. It is common in the Hex River mountains, but absent from Matroosberg.>
<Endemic to the south slopes of the Clock Peaks at Swellendam, and the ridge north of the Clock Pks.>
<Restricted to the mountains between Kogelberg and Franschhoek.>
<Known from a single population near Elim, on the hills above Viljoenshof.>
<An alpine species, found along the highest mountains along the inner margins of the Cape Fold Mountains>

<Ranging from the Cape Flats north to Malmesbury, this species is known from very few localities: Riverlands (the only protected locality), Preekstoel, between Kraaifontein and Brackenfell (an area now probably under suburbs), and a couple of road-verge localities near farmlands.>
<Higher peaks in the Rivierzondereinde mountains.>
<Known only from the type collection from the south slopes of Mannetjiesberg, in the Kamannassie Mountains.>
<Local endemic restricted to the Slanghoek mountains, from Groot Wellington Sneeukop to Witteberg, as well as in the Wemmershoek mountains between Du Toits Peak and Winterberg.>
<Known from the coastal mountains between the Cape Flats and the Klein River at Hermanus.>

<Most of the collections are from the mountains around the Palmiet River, but there are single collections from Bains Kloof, and from the Langeberg at Swellendam. The identity of these collections is still in need of critical evaluation.>
<A very widespread species in the Cape Floristic Region, found almost anywhere on sandstone-derived soils or loamy sands, where there is ground water.>

<A curious distribution, with very few, but widely separated, populations known: Kenilworth Race Course, Bainskloof, Mitchells Pass and Kogelberg. The type of \i{}E. exilis\i0{} is from Rivierzondereinde, quite distant from any other collections.>

<Very common in the southern Peninsula, this species dominates large areas in the Cape Point National Park. In addition, there are collections from Riverlands near Malmesbury, and from the area around the mouth of the Palmiet River, near Kleinmond.>
<This species is restricted to the Klein River mountains, from Hermanus to Stanford.>

<Frequently collected from the Cape Peninsula, inland to Jonkershoek, and common along the coastal mountains to Hermanus, and inland to Caledon Swartberg. The eastern-most collection is from Phesantehoek near Viljoenshof, in the Bredasdorp division.>
<From Franshoek to Zuurvlakte in the southern Cederberg, but possibly much more widespread, depending on the species delimitations.>
<Very common on the Cape Peninsula, rangeing east to Garcias Pass along the Langeberg, and west and north to Bainskloof.>
<A west coast species, with its southern limit at Blaauberg, and the northern limit near Elandsbay, but most in the Hopefield district.>

<Probably very widespread, from the Cederberg to Port Elizabeth. Current estimates of the range of the species are underestimates, as many specimens are still erroneously included under \i{}E. juncea\i0{}.>

<High-altitude species, found along the inland mountains from Olifantsberg in the Riverzondereinde mountains, northwards to the Cederberg, taking in both Keeromsberg, the Hex River Mountains, and the mountains from Franschhoek to Bainskloof.>

<Only three widely separated populations of this lowland species are known: from the road to the Kluitjieskraal Forestry Station near Tulbagh, from the area around Joostenberg near Paarl, and from Rietfontein Farm near Bredasdorp.>
<Known only from the type collection, made by Schlechter in 1896 from "In montibus pone Mitchell's Pass, 1500' ".>
<A coastal species, known from Cape Point, the coastal flats in the Soetanysberg area, and with one collection from the mouth of the Rooipunt River near Humansdorp.>
<Ubiquitous in the Cape Floristic Region.>
<Widespread and common along the coastal plateaux and ranges from Malmesbury to Port Elizabeth, but absent from the inland ranges.>
<Restricted to Jonas Kop in the Wilde Paarde Berg, thus probably to a single population. I have not explored Olifantskop, some kilometers to the west, but it might also occur there.>
<Restricted to the arid inland slopes of the Langeberg, from Montague in the west to Oudtshoorn in the east.>
<Widespread in the south-western Cape Mountains, from Bainskloof in the north, to Pilaarkop above Riverzondereinde in the east, and the mountains around Houw Hoek in the south.>
<Widely distributed, forming isolated populations.>

<Most of the collections are from the Hottentots Holland mountains, between Betty's Bay on the coast and Victoria Peak at the head of Jonkershoek Valley. There are only two collections from the Cape Peninsula - these might be misidentifications for \i{}C. ebracteatum. \i0{}To the east the species reaches Pearly Beach.>
<From Bainskloof to Ceres and north to "Beverlac" at the head of the Olifants River valley.>

<As delimited here, this species is endemic to the Cape Peninsula, it is quite common on the Back and Top Table of Table Mountain. However, the delimitation from \i{}E. grandispicata\i0{} is somewhat dubious, so its endemism to the Peninsula is taxonomically dubious.>

<This species is found in the mountains from the southern Cold Bokkeveld (Hansiesberg, Groot Winterhoek) eastwards to the Cockscomb. Although it has been recorded from the Swartberg, it is absent from the Witteberg and the drier inland mountains. There is a single record from the Bredasdorp plains, but this record lacks a base and may be a misidentified specimen of \i{}E. equisetacea\i0{}.>
<From the mountains flanking the Olifants River (Keerom to Clanwilliam) and the Piketberg, reaching the hills between Aurora and Verlorenvlei.>
<Mountains from Bains Kloof to Kogelberg>

<This very common species has a patchy distribution from Yzerfontein north of Cape Town, to Port Elizabeth. The species is found around the Cape Peninsula, along the coast from Gansbaai to the mouth of the Gouritz River, and at Humansdorp and Port Elizabeth. These are areas with a low coastline and coastal dunes, and it is absent from areas where the coast is steep. It probably occurs on some of the intervening coastline, but more rarely, where-ever coastal dunes are found.>

<South-western Cape mountains, mostly in habitats receiving South-easter cloud cover in summer: Cape Peninsula, Hottentots Holland mountains to Klein Riviers Berg, and the Langeberg from Leeuriverpeak to Garcias Pass. To the north the species reaches Victoria Peak at the head of Jonkershoek, with a single collection from the Cossacks above Bains Kloof Pass (but this is a rather strange-looking specimen, and this northern extension should be corroborated).>
<Restricted to the coastal platform from the Soetanysberg in the west to the Gouritzriver in east - an identical distribution to that of \i{}Thamnochortus insignis\i0{}.>
<Two sites known from Kotzesrus area: Katdoringvlei and Wit Waters.>

<Widespread in the mountains from the Cederberg to the Cape Peninsula, and eastwards along the Langeberg and Outeniqua mountains to George. I have not yet seen specimens from the inland mountains from the southern Cape, or from the arid margins of the western Cape mountains.>

<A species of the coastal forelands. To the north it reaches the Langebaan lagoon, and Hopefield, while to the east it reaches De Hoop, east of Bredasdorp. It does not cross the coastal mountains, and is absent from the Breede River valley.>

<This species is primarily found in the mountains from Kogelberg on the False Bay coast to Olifantsberg near Villiersdorp, and eastwards along the Riverzondereinde mountains to Stormsvlei, and along the coastal mountains to Hermanus.>

<It is a coastal foreland species with a rather disjunct distribution. To the north it reaches Malmesbury, and well protected population on Riverlands, as well as several collections from road margins and areas now cultivated or built up, southwards to False Bay and Kommetjie, to another well protected population in the Cape Point Nature Reserve. To the east there are several collections from near Betty's Bay, with the next set of collections being from the foothills of the limestone hills from Pearly Beach to the eastern end of the Soetanysberg, near Cape l'Agulhas.>

<Appears to be restricted to wetter mountains, from the Cape Peninsula, the Slanghoek peaks and Mosterthoek Twins in the west, along the coastal ranges (Kleinriviersberg, Rivierzondereinde and Langeberg) to Cockscomb in the east.>

<Along the coastal plains from the Berg River to the Breede River, but with quite large disjunctions. In addition, there is a population in the Breede River valley, between Bains Kloof and Wolseley. The species was quite common on the Cape Flats, from Kenilworth to Stellenbosch and Paarl, but most of these populations are now extinct. It is quite common at Riverlands near Malmesbury, and there are also several scattered populations along the Bot River, near Elim, and at the inland base of the Potberg.>
<This species is known from the mountains between the Cold Bokkeveld (from Boboskloof and Beaverlac at the head of the Olifants River) and Bain's Kloof.>
<Found in the mountains from Hermanus to the Rivierzondereinde, and north-west wards to Bainskloof.>

<Largely restricted to the coastal forelands from Malmesbury to Bredasdorp, and absent from the Breede River Valley. The species is also found in the foothills of mountains. It may be quite rare, or least restricted to relatively few, widely separated, populations.>

<Largely a species of the coastal forelands, found between Kalabaskraal (near Malmesbury) in the north, and the Gouritz River in the east. It is common on low hills, and reaches in the the foothills of the mountains flanking and transecting the forelands.>

<Distributed around the margins of the Breede River Valley: from the northern end there are collections from the Hex River Valley, and from Ontongskop near Tulbagh. Along the western margins the species is known from Stettynsberg and has been seen on Olifantsberg, and there are collections along the eastern margin, from Keeromsberg to Cogmanskloof. This is an unusual distribution pattern, resulting in a rather rare species occurring in three phytogeographical regions.>

<Widespread from Clanwilliam to Port Elizabeth, the species is found primarily on the coastal forelands. Even in the Clanwilliam area it is at relatively low altitudes in the Olifants River mountains.>

<Rather widespread, from the coastal platform at Betty's Bay, to the Cape Peninsula, and inland to Bainskloof, to the Hottentots Holland mountains, the Rivierzondereinde to Pilaarkop. There are, however, surprisingly few collections: possibly because the plants are so big.>
<This species is a Langeberg-Outeniqua endemic, very characteristic of the dense vegetation on the seawards slopes of the mountains.>

<A very widespread species. It is found on the coastal plains from Malmesbury in the north to Bredasdorp in the east. Along the mountains it ranges from Pakhuis Pass above Clanwilliam in the north to Grahamstown in the east. There is a single collection from the Swartberg.>

<A species restricted to the coastal forelands, from Riversland near Malmesbury in the north, to Bredasdorp in the south. I have found only one record that could be from the foothills of the mountains: the rest are all on the plains.>
<Very widespread aloong the inland mountains, from the Cederberg to the Hogsback, but absent from the coastal ranges.>

<A very widespread species, from the Bainskloof to Cockscomb, recorded from all major mountain ranges: Peninsula, Klein River, Rivierzondereinde, Swartberg, Langeberg, Tzitzikamma, Kamannassie and Kouga.>
<Almost all collections are from the Palmiet River valley, from Kleinmond to Elgin. The few collections from beyond this area need careful investigation>

<Rather widespread and common species, from the Cederberg in the north to the Langeberg at Riversdale, and westwards to the Cape Peninsula. Most of the collections are from the south-western mountains.>

<A very widespread species, found on the moutains and flats from the Cederberg in the North, to the Cape Peninsula in the west, and eastwards to the Kouga mountains. It may be regarded as ubiquitous in the Cape Floristic Region.>
<Very widespread in the Cape mountains, but absent from the Cape Peninsula. To the north the species reaches the Giftberg at Van Rhynsdorp, and to the east Garcias Pass at Riversdale.>
<Endemic to the small summit plateau of Misty Point (Goedgeloof Pk).>

<Widespread along the arid margins of fynbos, from the Cederberg to the Witteberg at Laingsburg. The species is absent from the Olifantsriver mountains, and from the mountains forming the boundary between the Cold Bokkeveld and the Olifants River valley.>
<Rare along the limestone coast from Pearly Beach to Mosselbay, recorded to date from three populations only.>
<Endemic to the Bredasdorp limestones, from Soetanysberg in the west to Jongensfontein in the east.>

<A species of the lowlands, which ranges from Malmesbury to Bredasdorp (Potberg). It seems to have been rather common in the lowlands from the Cape Peninsula to Stellenbosch. It has also been collected from the Wolseley area, at the top of the Breede River valley.>
<This species is known from only two localities in the Riviersondereinde mountains: one at the western extreme, on Wolfieskop above Villiersdorp, the other at De Galg between MacGregor and Greyton.>

<A very widespread species, from Kamiesberg in the north to Bushmans River at Grahamstown in the east. It is absent from the wetter mountains of the south-western Cape, the Cape Peninsula and the West Coast.>
<A very rare species restricted to the area around Touwsriver and Matjiesfontein, with collections from the valleys around Bonteberg, and on the southern slopes of the Witteberg.>

<A common species from the mountains fringing the Little Karoo. To the west the species reaches the Klein Swartberg, to the east Grahamstown. It is most common in the Swartberg, Kamannassie and Kouga, but also reaches the summits and inland slopes of the Tzitzikamma. There is one dubious collection from Caledon.>

<This species is largely associated with plains and hills on the coastal forelands, from the Cape Peninsula to Hopewell in the Bathurst area. In the Western Cape it is also found inland, albeit rarely, reaching the Cold Bokkeveld to the north.>

<A species distributed mostly along the coastal mountains and plains from the Cape Peninsula to the Gouritz River mountains. The only recorded inland population is around the eastern base of Franshoek Pass.>
<A montane species, widespread in around the Little Karoo, from Cogmans Kloof at Montague and Anysberg at Ladismith, eastwards to the arid mountains at Willowmore and Cockscomb.>

<This species as a widespread distribution. To the west to is found on the Bredasdorp - Riversdale coastal plain, with the furthermost collections being from Viljoenshof. To the east the species spreads through the Langeberg, Outeniquas, Tzitzikammas, and inland into the Kouga mountains. The easternmost collection is from Cockscomb. The species is absent from the Swartberg and the moutains eastward to Willowmore.>
<Endemic to the Hottentots Holland, Kogelberg, and Klein Riviers mountains.>
<Known from a single marsh below Kanonkop, above the village of Genadendal.>
<Currently known from the Langeberg between Kortefontein and Garcias Pass.>
<Endemic to the summit valleys of Misty Point, locally common. This is one of the rarest species of Restionaceae, known from a single locality.>

<Widespread in the coastal mountains of the southern Cape, from Hermanus in the west to Joubertina in the east. The species is replaced west of Bot River by \i{}P. cascadensis\i0{}, and is absent from the Swartberg.>
<Very widespread species, from Port Elizabeth in the east to Ceres in the west. It is absent from the Cape Peninsula, but has been recorded from the Kogelberg mountains.>
<Restricted to the Kogelberg mountains, from Rooiels to Betty's Bay.>

<Very widespread, with the northern-most record from the Gifberg above Vanrhynsdorp, and the easternmost record from Grahamstown. The species appears to be absent from the drier inland mountains. Most records are from the Langeberg, and the absence of records from the Cederberg (there is only one record from the Bokkeveld) must indicate that the species is very rare indeed north of Ceres.>

<From Jonkershoek near Stellenbosch in the south, to Tulbagh Waterfall in the north. Most of the collections are either from the Stellenbosch area, or from the Slanghoek mountains, it appears to be rare or absent from the Wemmershoek mountains. A single collection from Paardeberg at Malmesbury constitutes and interesting outlier.>
<Restricted to the northern Drakensberg, from Cathkin Peak to Mnweni.>
<Widely separated populations: Mt Mulanje in Malawi, Mt Muhi in the Democratic Republic of the Congo, Mt Nkombako in the Uluguru Mts of Tanzania, and in Madagascar.>
<Restricted to the south-eastern corner of Madagascar.>
<A very erratic recorded distribution, with collections from Table Mountain, the area around Viljoenshof, Potberg, and the Rivierzondereinde mountains.>
<Restricted to the Sombani Valley on Mt Mulanje, Malawi.>
<Endemic to the Chimanimani mountains, where it is restricted to quartzitic rocks.>
<From Landdrostkop in the south to Bainskloof in the north, collected from rather few localities.>
<Known from only two localities. The southern, at Kraaifontein, is now extinct, and the species is now known only from Riverlands near Malmesbury.>
<Distributed along the south coast, from Cape Hangklip in the west, to the Gouritz River mouth in the east. The furthest inland the species reaches is to Houw Hoek.>
<Restricted to the area around Leeurivier Peak and west of Misty Point, in the Langeberg at Swellendam.>

<A southern Cape species, which ranges from Gysmanshoek Pass and the Breede River through the Langeberg, west of Riversdale, to Humansdorp near Port Elizabeth. It is restricted to the coastal platform, where it is most commonly found along the coastal pediments of the mountain ranges.>
<Restricted to the summits of the mountains between Wemmershoek and Bainskloof.>

<A Little Karoo species, absent from the Langeberg, but found on the hills and mountains of the Little Karoo, as well as the Swartberg from Sewe Weeks Poort, and eastwards to the hills around Willowmore.>
<On the Agulhas plains between Elim, Viljoenshof and the Soetanysberg.>

<Langeberg endemic, collected from the Garcias Pass area, and from the mountains behind Swellendam. It is not certain whether the disjunction between these two localities is real or not, since the Langeberg are still relatively poorly collected.>
<Known from the area around Touws River: Bonteberg and the Witteberg. There is a collection from Nieuwoudtville which fits this species, and one from Milner Peak, which differs somewhat.>
<Restricted to the coastal platform and mountains from Gordons Bay to Kleinmond, with an outlier on Shaws Mountain.>
<High mountain summits in the Hex River mountains (Matroosberg to Brandwacht Peak) and the Tulbagh mountains (Klein Winterhoek to Witzenberg peaks).>
<Known from a single collection from the slopes south of Blesberg>
<In the mountains from Betty's Bay and Kleinmond to Jonkershoek behind Stellenbosch.>

<Rangeing from Table Mountain on the Cape Peninsula to near Viljoenshof in the Bredasdorp area, and inland to Jonkershoek and Pilaarkop above Rivierzondereinde Village. Most of the collections are from Table Mountain, the Kogelberg area, and the mountains above Hermanus.>
<A very wide range, from Darling on the West Coast, to the Laingsburg Witteberg, the Rivierzondereinde mountains, and Cape Point.>
<Known only from one collection at Jonkerspoort at the summit of Blinkberg Pass>

<Along the Rivierzondereinde Range, from Franshoek to Somersfontein near Elgin, and on Fonteintjiesberg and Brandwacht. The species is absent from the Peninsula, and from the south-western mountains north of Franshoek.>

<A widespread species, known from the Swartberg and Witteberg, the western end of the Rivierzondereinde mountains, the south-western mountains from Villiersdorp to Bailey's Peak and from Sneeugat above Tulbagh, the Hex River mountains, and the Swartruggens from Baviaansberg to Vleiberg, and northwards to the Kamiesberg.>
<Endemic to the Cederberg, from Boontjieskraal near Heuningvlei to Welbedacht, but absent from the southern Cederberg.>

<Most of the collections are from the mountains around Kogelberg and Betty's Bay. However, there are collections from the Witteberg at Laingsburg, and Baviaansberg in the Ceres Bokkeveld. There is a single collection from the Meiringspoort area of the Great Swartberg, its identity needs verification.>
<Restricted to the plains and hills between the Rivierzondereinde Mts and the coast.>
<Limestone endemic, ranging from the Cape Peninsula to the Gouritz River mouth, along the coastal strip whereever limestone outcrops exist.>
<Ubiquitous in the Cape Flora, especially in more arid environments.>
<Very poorly known: one unlocalised collection from "Ceres", three from the Bainskloof - Du Toitskloof mountains, from from Louwshoek Peak, and one collection from Swellendam>
<Restricted to the southern Cederberg and the northern Bokkeveld, this species ranges from Bloukop, north of the Bokkeveld Sneeukop, to Gabrielspass in the Central Cederberg.>
<This species has a rather disjunct distribution: Peninsula, Hermanus, Riverzondereinde, and absent from the Kogelberg. It is very common on the southern Peninsula, but less so in the other areas.>

<A coastal mountain species from the south-western Cape, this species ranges between Rooi Els river in the west, to Hermanus in the east. It seems to be restricted to the first range of mountains above the coast, and is absent from mountains slightly more inland, like Babylons Tower.>
<Restricted to the area around Tulbagh Waterfall. This includes the slopes flanking the Suurvlakte.>
<Known from only two localities. The first is just below the summit of Pilaarkop (above the village of Rivierzondereinde), and the second from the mountains above Swellendam.>
<Restricted to the Cape Peninsula, and on the Peninsula to the low mountains between Constantiaberg and Fishhoek, specifically from Nellies Pool to the Silvermine dam.>

<Quite wideranging, from the Cederberg (Krakadouw), southwards to the Hex River Mountains (Milner Peak and Fonteintjiesberg), and with one collection (\i{}Stokoe\i0{} in BOL 24867) from the Seven Sisters near Wellington. The identification of this specimen seems to be correct, but this is the only collection from south of the Breede River valley, and maybe the locality data on the sheet are incorrect.>

<Wideranging on the higher peaks, from Sneeukop in the Cederberg to Mannetjiesberg in the Kamannassie and Meiringspoortberg in the Groot Swartberg. Most collections are from the Slanghoek mountains, reaching to Olifantsberg in the Rivierzondereinde, but the species is absent from the lower coastal mountains: the Kogelberg, Kleinriviersberg and the Cape Peninsula.>
<From the south-western mountains, between Betty's Bay, inland to Paardekop above the Franshoek Pass. Most collections are from the Jonkershoek - Nuweberg area.>
<A high-altitude species from the SW mountains between the Cape Flats and the Breede River Valley, ranging from Bainskloof to Sir Lowry's Pass.>
<Common in the western mountains, from the Cederberg to the Cape Peninsula, and eastwards to Swellendam, although it is rare east of Stellenbosch.>

<From Pilaarkop above the village of Rivierzondereinde, through the Rivierzondereinde Mountains, northwards to the Hex River Mountains, and to Slab Peak above Mitchells pass, and southwards throughout the Hottentots Holland and Slanghoek mountains. The species seems to be particularly common in the Hottentots Holland mountains.>
<Known only from the higher peaks along the Langeberg: Leeurivierspeak, Misty Point, Grootberg, and Cradock peak at George. The Langeberg has been poorly explored, and more populations may exist.>

<There are numerous collections from the mountains between Baileys Peak and Somerset Sneeukop: Du Toits Kloof and Franshoek mountains. In addition, there are two outliers: one from Slab Peak near Ceres (\i{}Esterhuysen 33382\i0{}) and one from Maanschynkop at Hermanus (\i{}Esterhuysen 31696\i0{}). The identification of these two collections needs verification, especially since both of them are somewhat atypical of the species.>

<Rare on the Cape Peninsula, but more common along the south-western mountains from Bainskloof in the north to Hermanus in the south. The species is found only on the western end of the Rivierzondereinde mountains, on Olifantsberg.>
<Restricted to the mountains around Jonkershoek, from Emerald Dome to Landdrostkop.>
<Widespread, from Cederberg to the Cape Peninsula, and along the Langeberg to Garcias Pass, but with surprisingly few collections over this distribution range.>
<Widespread on the mountains from Citrusdal to George and Oudtshoorn; absent from the Cederberg and the Cape Peninsula.>

<A very widespread high-altitude species; the type is from the mountains behind Graaff Reinett, and the species reaches to the Hogsback in the east and the Cederberg in the west. However, it is absent from the Cape Peninsula and the more mesic coastal mountains.>
<Endemic to Cape Point Nature Reserve, most common on the flats west of Pauls Berg.>
<Endemic to the Bredasdorp Plains, from Koueberg in the west, to the Arniston Flats in the east, and between Bredasdorp Mountains to the north, and the coast.>

<Endemic to the Cold Bokkeveld, north of Ceres, this species has a restricted distribution range from southern Cederberg to Op-die-Berg\i{}.\i0{} Over this range, it is known from only three populations: Boboskloof; above Op-die-Berg, and S-Cederberg Suurvlakte>
<Widespread on the coastal platform between Malmesbury and False Bay, with a few outlier populations from the Worcester valley. It has been recorded from most remnant patches in the lowlands.>
<From the mountains between Bainskloof and Sir Lowry's Pass, but absent from the Kogelberg>
<Recorded from the southern Peninsula, eastwards to Bredasdorp, in inland to the mountains above Villiersdorp. Most of the collections, though, are from the mountains between Elgin and Betty's Bay.>

<Recorded from a small number of widely separated localities: Beverlac in the Porterville Mountains, Bainskloof, Hottentots Holland, Rivierzondereinde at Silverstroom and Kanonkop, and the Langeberg near Misty Point and Tradouw Peak. Curiously, it is absent from the Cape Peninsula.>
<A coastal species, with is found on coastal sand, and occasionally coastal sand blown inland, from the Cape Peninsula to Gonubie Springs near East London.>
<Restricted to the mountains between Worcester and Ceres, from Matroosberg to Mostert Hoek Twins and Brandwacht Pk.>
<Restricted to the mountains between Karoopoort and Touwsriver. There is a single collection from Nieuwoudtville, raising the possibility that the species may also occur along the Swartruggens.>
<Restricted to the coastal platform from Rooiels to Betty's Bay.>
<Widespread on the lowlands and the foothills of the mountains, from Sir Lowry's Pass to near Viljoenshof and Elim. Most of the collections are nearer the coast, from Betty'sBay, and Stanford.>

<Very widespread species, from Nieuwoudtville to Garcias Pass. It is also found on the West Coast sandplains, and the Cape Peninsula. Surprisingly, it seems to be absent from the inland mountains: Swartberg and Witteberg.>
<Known only from the upper south-facing slopes of the Langeberg behind Swellendam, along the path to 10o'clock Peak.>

<Widespread in the mountains between the Breede River and the ocean, including the RZE (from Pilaarkop), the Kogelberg and Slanghoek mountains, and the isolated Riebeeck Kasteelsberg. There are no records from the Cape Peninsula.>
<Restricted to Audensberg (both the main peak and Audens Ridge Peak 1), above Worcester.>
