<Restricted to the mountains between Somerset Sneeukop and Kleinmond.>

<Very common in the Western Cape, found on the drier lower slopes of most mountains. The distribution to the east of the Hottentots Holland may be var. \i{}luxurians\i0{}, but the exact taxonomic limit between these two forms still needs to be established, and until then an exact geographical limitation is not possible.>

<The "typical" form of the species is found in the Bokkeveld and Cederberg mountains, with outliers on Piketberg and north to Kamieskroon. To the south and east somewhat deviant forms have been recorded from the Slanghoek mountains, the Langeberg and the Great Swartberg. However, the species delimitation here could be at fault.>

<A rare lowland species, known from the foothills of the mountains, or from coastal hills: Cape Peninsula, from the Atlantic slopes at Camps Bay; Somerset East, at Vergelegen; Bot River, between Bot River and Onrus, and the Bredasdorp plains between Elim and the sea>
<A very wide geographical distribution, almost ubiquitous in the Cape Flora, but with very few records. This is evidently a rare species.>

<Found east of Sir Lowry's Pass, to Caledon Swartberg, and to Soetanysberg near Cape l'Agulhas, but most commonly collected from the Kleinmond and Hermanus areas. The western-most collection seems to be from the summit ridge of Sir Lowry's Pass.>

<A very common restioid of the southern mountains: Swartberg, Langeberg, Outeniqua. To a large extent this species could be described as being typical of these mountains. It extends eastwards into the Mannetjiesberg, and the mountains at Willowmore. There are outlier collections further west, to Wemmershoek, Stellenbosch and Babylons Toring: their identification needs verification.>
<Known only from the summit of Grootberg in the Langeberg (Lemoenshoek Peak).>

<A typical West Coast Sandveld species, which reaches its southern limit near Kensington and the Bottelary Hills, between Cape Town and Stellenbosch, and its northern limits at Langvlei in the vicinity of Leipoldvillle. However, the populations around Cape Town are by now either extinct or no longer viable, and apart from the type specimen collected by Drege from Langvlei, the northernmost populations are from around Hopefield.>
<Fairly common along the Langeberg, from Swellendam to Knysna.>
<Endemic to the Riviersondereinde mts, from Jonaskop to Pilaarkop.>
<Throughout the northern mountains, from Matroosberg in the south to the Cederberg in the north. Most of the collections are from the Cederberg.>

<The distribution range of this species is rather narrow: its northern-most locality is in the Baviaanskloof, off Bains Kloof, while to the south it reaches Haelhoek Sneeukop, above Paarl. There are numerous known localities between these two stations: Seven Sisters, Witteberg, the Wellington Sneeukoppe.>
<Endemic to Karoopoort, and the Bonteberg, which is between Karoopoort and Touws River. Several other species are restricted to this area.>

<Ranges along the higher mountains from Van Rhynsdorp to Oudtshoorn, with an outlier population in the mountains above Graaff Reinett. It reaches the coast on the Kogelberg, but most collections are from the colder, inland mountains. There is also a small population on Nardouwspass, which might be the lowest occurrence of the species. It seems to have a very wide ecological tolerance.>

<Rangeing from New Years Peak to the north of Du Toits Kloof pass, to Betty's Bay, Table Mountain on the Cape Peninsula, and eastwards along the Rivierzondereind mountains to Pilaarkop. Most of the collections are from the mountains between Sir Lowry's Pass and Jonkershoek.>

<A species endemic to the arid margins of the northern mountains. It has been collected at three localities only: on the Suurvlakte in the northern Cold Bokkeveld, and on the Swartruggens at Katbakkies Pass, and on Waterfalls Berg.>
<Gifberg and Nieuwoudtville endemic.>
<A limestone endemic species, restricted to the southern Cape coast from Gansbaai to near Humansdorp. It is particularly common in the De Hoop area, and eastwards to the Gouritz River.>

<From Worcester to Uitenhage along the inland mountains, appears to be most common in the foothills of the mountains enclosing the Robertson and Little Karoos, but also found in the Kouga mountains. It is absent from the coastal sides of the coastal ranges, the Peninsula, and the mountains north of the Hex River valley.>

<\i{}I. macer\i0{} has a wide but patchy distribution, from Calvinia to Bredasdorp. It occurs in the mountains between Clanwilliam and Calvinia, on the Bokkeveld and Piketberg mountains, and on the coastal plains of Malmesbury and Paarl, as well as in the northern Breede River Valley, and on the Bredasdorp plains.>
<Ranging along the arid margins of the Cape Floristic Region, from Laingsburg and the Witteberg in the south to Calvinia and Nieuwoudtville in the north.>

<Historically the species ranged from Kenilworth on the Cape Flats, inland to Brackenfell and Kraaifontein, and northwards to Riverlands and Preekstoel near Malmesbury. The populations in the greater Cape Town to Brackenfell area are now probably extinct, leaving only the Malmesbury populations.>
<Slanghoek mountains, between Bains Kloof and Franshoek>
<Known only from the Mkambati Nature Reserve>

<A wide-ranging predominantly lowland, sandplain, species. It is common on the Bredasdorp plains, reaching to Cape Agulhas. Also recorded from the Sandveld, particularly the southern portion around Malmesbury, the Worcester valley. Further north the species is found at higher altitudes, on the Ceres Cold Bokkeveld, and on the plateau around Nieuwoudtville. It is also recorded from the lower mountains around these plains and plateaux.>
<A narrow endemic, restricted to the Langeberg between Misty Point and Garcias Pass, common in the Misty Point area, less so towards Garcias Pass.>
<Known only from two collections from Slanghoek Needle ("on cliffs facing Slanghoek Peak, N-W aspect").>
<This peculiar species has been recorded from the summits of a few mountains: Pilaarkop, Klein Winterhoek, Matroosberg, and a few peaks in between these mountains.>

<Known only from the the foothills of the Langeberg, from both the southern and northern entrance to the pass, but the best collected population is at the highest point of the pass, at the northern entrance. Two further collections from Rooiberg and Anysberg are intermediate between this species, and \i{}C. marlothii\i0{}.>
<On the lower slopes of the mountains, from Piketberg to Bredasdorp, including the Du Toits kloof mountains, as well as the Cape Peninsula.>
<On all higher mountains between Worcester and Clanwilliam.>
<Restricted to the Hex River Mountains, from Brandwacht Peak, in the south to Milner Peak in the north-east, and to Mostert Hoek Twins to the north west.>
<A species centered in the Kogelberg area, reaching inland to Victoria Peak at the head of Jonkershoek, and eastward to Hermanus.>

<Known from a single marshy spot in the Hottentots Holland mountains, between Nuweberg Forest Station and Landdrostkop. Also located in a ditch along the road from Nuweberg Forestry Station to Landdrostkop Hut.>
<Rangeing from the Wemmershoek to the Slanghoek mountains (Paardekop to Upper Wellington Sneeukop).>

<Probably restricted to the arid northern mountains, from the Cederberg to Witteberg at Laingsburg. The records from the southern end of the range are sparse, and need better corroboration. There are two records from Mt Lebanon near Elgin, these are probably identification errors.>

<Very common and widespread in the Cape mountains, especially the northern south-western mountains. The eastern mountains are much less a home for \i{}R. ocreatus. \i0{}It ranges north to Steinkopf in Namaqualand, and eastwards to Ladismith, and is particularly common from the Cederberg to the Laingsburg Witteberg. It is absent form the cool coastal mountains (Slanghoek, Rivierzondereinde, etc). There are no record from Kamiesberg, nor from the Van Rhyns escarpment north of Lokenberg, thus generating a major distribution disjunction to Steinkopf. Similarly to the east, there is a single collection from the Hoopsberg at Uniondale (\i{}Esterhuysen 6545\i0{}), none from the Kammanassie or the Great Swartberg, and then again several collections from the lower slopes of the Seweweekspoortberg in the Klein Swartberg. This, too, is a remarkable disjunction.>

<Common from Tulbagh Waterfall, through the Slanghoek mountains, and in particular around Bains Kloof. Less common in the mountains between Du Toits Kloof and Villiersdorp, and apparently absent from the Houw Hoek, Rivierzondereinde and Hottentots Holland, but collected numerous times on the Caledon Swartberg. There is a single collection from Milner Peak in the Hex River mountains.>

<A rather widespread distribution, mostly on sandy flats and plains, rarely in mountains. The southern margin is near Elim on the Bredasdorp plains, to the north it reaches the Piketberg and the southern Cederberg.>
<Restricted to the Klein Riviers Berge behind Hermanus.>

<Ubiquitous in the Cape Flora, not only along the main ranges, but often following the riverbeds with sandstone rubble away from the mountains. The species occurs occasionally through the Eastern Cape: on Hogsback, on Mt Baziya, and into southern Natal. Its range may still be an underestimate, since it is often not collected. The absence of the species from the Gifberg and Nieuwoudtville area seems almost unlikely, and the distribution map is an excellent example of an undercollected species. Well known, and widespread, species are often not collected.>

<Restricted to the coastal plains from Malmesbury to Elim, with a single outlier collection from the Kromme River near Humansdorp. There are numerous collections, indicating that it might be quite common in all the lowland areas.>

<Endemic to the Klein Swartberg, on the peaks between Seweweekspoort Mt and Towerkop, but absent from both of these high peaks. It might even be restricted to the peaks between Peak Wood and Elandsberg, but locality data are not precise enough.>
<From Brandwacht Peak above Worcester in the South, to Northern Cederberg above Clanwilliam in the North, and westward to Piketberg.>
<Known from only two collections, from the Suurvlakte at the northern end of the Cold Bokkeveld, and from the summit of the Skurweberg Pass at the southern end of the Cold Bokkeveld.>

<A relatively wide-rangeing species. The northern limit is at Tulbagh Waterfall, while the eastern limit is Garcias Pass at Riversdale. In between, the species if common on the Cape Peninsula, as well as the coastal mountains to Hermanus, as well as the inland slopes around Villiersdorp and the Riverzondereinde mountains.>
<Endemic to the Langeberg above Swellendam, and surprisingly common from Clock Peaks to Misty Point.>

<Widerangeing in the northern and south-western mountains, from the Cederberg in the north to the Cape Peninsula, and the hills around Elgin and up to Kogelberg. Absent from the inland and the eastern mountains.>

<Occurs commonly on the Peninsula, and the south-western mountains (but apparently absent from the Kogelberg and the wet coastal mountains: Kleinriviersberg and Rivierzondereinde). Inland the species ranges from the Ceres Bokkeveld to the Langeberg at Heidelberg, and has been collected most frequently from the Hex River mountains.>

<Restricted to the Langeberg, the species is common between the Clock Peaks and Misty Point, possibly endemic to here. There is a second collection from Garcias Pass, at a much lower altitude, suggesting that the species might occur all along the central Langeberg.>
<Occasional from Blokkop above Villiersdorp, to Maanschynkop above Hermanus and Pilaarkop above Riverzondereinde, but absent from the Cape Peninsula.>

<The distribution makes little sense. The species is quite common on the West Coast plains, and reaches into the foothills of the northern mountains, around Clanwilliam and Citrusdal. But there are also a few collections from the Du Toits Kloof area, and these include one of the types.>

<Found between the Cape Peninsula, Worcester and Malmesbury, with a possible outlier from the Matsikamma, the species is a typical lowland species. There are very few populations of this species: Romans River, Vergelegen, Paarl mountains, Kenilworth Race Course, Rondebosch Common, Durbanville, Somerset Strand . . .>
<Restricted to the gravelly hills around Elim, ranging from Pearly Beach inland to Elim, westwards to the Koueberg, and eastwards to Brandfontein and the Soetanysberg.>

<Known from few localities between Du Toits Kloof and Somerset Sneeukop: Du Toits Peak, Wemmershoek Pk, Stettynsberg, Kaaimans Pk, Victoria Pk, Emerald Dome, and Somerset Sneeukop. At Somerset Sneeukop the plants grown on almost inaccessible rock ledges.>

<Frequently collected from the mountains from Franshoek Pass in the north to Kleinmond in the south. The species seems to occur in a single locality on the Cape Peninsula (between Smitswinkel Pk and Swartkops Pk), and there is one collection from "Rivier Zonder Einde Mountains" by Stokoe. Possibly the label data on this last locality is incorrect.>
<A strange distribution, from Kleinmond to Jonaskop in the Rivierzondereinde mnts>
<Restricted to the high peaks flanking the Hex River Valley - between Matroosberg, Baviaansberg, Buffelshoek and Keeromsberg.>
<Frequently collected on the lower slopes of Table Mountain, occasional in the mountains from Slanghoek Peak, Du Toits vlakted, and eastwards to the dubious record from above Genadendal.>

<Restricted to lowland areas from Cape Point to Malmesbury and Yzerfontein. There is a single collection (\i{}Drege 25\i0{}), collected ca. 1830, from near Ezelbank in the Cederberg, but this range extension has not been corroborated.>
<Peninsula endemic, from Constantiaberg to Cape Point, but is quite common over this distribution range.>
<This remarkable species is known only from the southern slopes of Toverkop, above Ladismith, where it occurs along the access path between the shelter and the base of the long scree.>

<A species of the drier inland mountains. To the north the species reaches the Ceres Cold Bokkeveld. We have one collection from Baviaansberg, and the type, which is from an unspecified locality in the Cold Bokkeveld. There are collections from the mountains on both sides of the Hex River valley, and along the Langeberg only as far as Sawedge Peak. Then the species is found in the Witteberg at Laingsburg, and eastward along the Swartberg to Tierberg and Anysberg.>

<Predominantly a coastal species, common between Malmesbury and False Bay, with an outlier at Karbonkelberg, and another in the Breede River valley near Darling Bridge. It seems also to be quite common on the Bredasdorp plains, with a few populations in between, such as at Houw Hoek.>
<Restricted to the Bokkeveld plateau, from the southern Cederberg (Zuurvlakte) to Op-die-Berg.>
<Found in the northern areas of the Cape Floristic Region, from Piketberg in the south, to the Cederberg, and the Kamiesberg.>

<A widespread species in the drier, colder mountains along the inland ranges. To the east, the species reaches the Rooiberg at Ladismith, whilst to the north it reaches the Kamiesberg in Namaqualand. It seems to be most common in the Hex River mountains, and northwards across the Bokkeveld, with relatively few collections from the Little Karoo mountains. The specimens from Kamiesberg are morphologically somewhat divergent, and their inclusing in this species may not be warranted.>
<\i{}Restio rupicola\i0{} is known from a single localityon Matroosberg, above De Doorns.>
<Restricted to the coastal plains from the Cape Peninsula and the Bredasdorp areas>

<Recorded from the Cape Peninsula, from the summit of Table Mountain to the flats at Paulsberg, and also from the Klein River Mountains at Hermanus, from Babylon's Tower, and from the Hottentots Holland mountains from Betty's Bay to Jonkershoek.>
<Restricted to the mountains between Franschhoek and Sir Lowry's Pass>
<Known only from one population on the Caledon Swartberg>
<From Garcias Pass, eastwards along the coastal mountains to Knysna and Joubertina.>
<From the Eastern Cape, north to the Limpopo, in montane grassland.>
<There are two localities in the Langeberg: the Clock Peaks above Swellendam, and further east at Sleeping Beauty, above Garcias Pass. The record from the Kogelberg is probably erroneous.>
<Extremely widespread species>
<This is a very unlikely distribution pattern, and the Swellendam collections should be a separate species. In which case this species is endemic to the Brandewyns Rivier area.>
<Ubiquitous in the Cape flora, with outliers reaching the Orange River in the Richtersveld.>

<Most of the collections are from the Kogelberg mountains, between Rooiels and Kleinmond. However, there are outlier collections north to Mostert Hoek Twins, inland to Jonaskop, and eastwards to Viljoenshof.>
<Known only from the summits of Witteberg, Du Toits Peak, and Wemmershoek Winterberg: all mountains flanking Du Toits Kloof.>
<Mostly restricted to the coastal forelands from Malmesbury to Bredasdorp, with one collection from Bainskloof, and several from the Cape Point Nature Reserve.>
<Rangeing from Bailey's Peak above Wolseley, to Witzenberg Pass in the north, to Buffelshoek Pk. A remarkably restricted distribution, that crosses the upper Breede River valley.>

<The distribution range is from Somerset Sneeukop, to Kleinmond, and eastwards to a gorge below Pilaarkop, at the village of Rivierzondereinde (a somewhat dubious record), and further across the Breede River valley to the high mountains behind Swellendam.>

<Mostly along the inland margins of the mountains, from Kaaimansgat just north of Villiersdorp, to Lebanon near Elgin, to Pilaarkop above the village of Rivierzondereinde. However, the species has not been recorded from the coastal mountains: Table Mountain, Kogelberg, or the Kleinrivers Mountains. It has also been collected from the length of the Langeberg, from Robertson to George, mostly on the summits and along the inland slopes.>

<Common between the Hex River Valley and the Cederberg, to the inland side of the Olifants River Mountains. There is a single record from the Jonkershoek area, and another from the Laingsburg Witteberg, but both these are likely to be misidentifications. The species is also found on Keeromsberg, immediately east of the Hex River Valley.>
<Restricted to the Hottentots Holland: most collections are from the slopes of Landdrost Peak, while one collection is the Kogelberg, from the plateau between Louwsbos and Rooiels.>
<Recorded from valleys in the mountains from Caledon to Paarl, and with one record from the Hex River mountains.>

<Widely distributed, from Malmesbury in the west to Port Elizabeth in the east. Most collections are from between the mountains and the sea, but one collection is from the inland margin of the Langeberg.>
<This species is quite common in the Overberg, from Sir Lowry's Pass to Cape Agulhas.>
<Found in mountains from Swellendam to the Ceres Cold Bokkeveld, and is quite common on the Cape Peninsula.>

<This species ranges from the Cape Peninsula to Grahamstown, mostly in the lowlands and along the foothills of the mountains. It has a rather patchy distribution, and this might be the result to undercollecting, rather than a genuinely rare species.>

<A widespread species, mostly from the lowlands and foothills of the mountains, but occasionally also found on the middle slopes. It reaches Grahamstown to the east, and the Cape Peninsula and Franshoek to the west.>
<A species with a restricted arid area range, from the Central Cederberg (Algeria) in the south, to Gifberg in the north. It reaches inland to Bidouwsberg and Boontjieskloof.>
<Found at two stations along the Great Swartberg, between Kariegaberg and Tierberg.>
<Very widespread throughout the Cape Floristic Region, but absent from the more mesic coastal mountains adn in particular from the Cape Peninsula>
<Found on the higher mountains from Du Toits Kloof to the Cederberg, including the Piketberg.>
<Known only from the eastern end of the Baviaanskloof mountain, along the south-facing slopes below the highest part of the range.>
<Restricted to Houw Hoek mountain, above the Houw Hoek railway station>
<The distribution is restricted to the lower slopes of the mountains and plains between Villiersdorp and Kleinmond. It seems to particularly common in the Kogelberg area.>
<Kamiesberg endemic, found on Sneeukop, Eselkop, Kamiesberg and Rooiberg.>
<Known only from the Kogelberg, from one population near the Arieskraal Dam, and the second from below 5-beacon ridge, also from Solva.>

<A very widespread species. The taxonomic limits of the species are still inadequately understood, and the construction here is not at all clear. The range might, consequently, become much narrowed with better taxonomic revision.>
<Widespread in the northern mountains, it is not found on the Swartberg or Langeberg.>
<From Caledon to Nieuwoudtville - a very spotty distribution, possibly due to the complex habitat requirements, possibly due to undercollecting.>
<Described from the Witteberg, it is also known from Matroosberg, and slightly different looking plants have been collected from the Klein Swartberg.>
<This species has been recorded from near sea level, from the Vuzi Swamp at Manzegwenya in Ingwavuma. It is the only "tropical" restioid in Africa.>

<This species is mostly found along the inland edge of the south-western mountains. To the north, the species reaches the Witteberg above Du Toits Kloof, while to the east it reaches the Rivierzondereinde above Greyton. It is common in the Jonkershoek area, with one collection from the Kogelberg, and several from Caledon Swartberg and Babylon's Tower.>
<Restricted to the Swartberg, from Sewe Weeks Poort Berg in the west to Blesberg in the east.>
<Defined narrowly, this species is restricted to the Little Karoo, on sandstone slopes and outcrops throughout the area: from near De Rust in the east, to the Klein Swartberg Pass to the west.>
<Widespread along the inland margins of the Cape Fold Mountains, from the Cederberg to Grahamstown.>
<Langeberg endemic, found between Garcias Pass in the east and Swellendam in the west.>
<Widespread on lower slopes from the Cape Peninsula to Grahamstown, and at middle altitudes in the Drakensberg.>
<Restricted to the coastal mountains from George to Port Elizabeth, found rarely on the inland slopes of the Tzitzikamma mountains.>
<Known only from the Outeniqua mountains in the vicinity fo Robinsons Pass, and from the foothills of the Kammanassie Mountains near De Rust, and from the Rooiberg.>
<Ranging from the Bonteberg at Touwsriver, northwards via Baviaansberg, Vleiberg to the Bokkeveld Sneeukop. A typical element of the western margins of the Tanqua karoo.>
<Recorded from the Cape Peninsula along the coastal ranges to Hermanus, and inland to Pilaarrkop behind Riverzondereinde Village, and Caledon Swartberg.>
<This species is found along the higher peaks between the Cedarberg, Klein Swartberg, Rivierzondereinde mountains and Caledon Swartberg, but is absent from the Cape Peninsula.>

<\i{}S. banksii \i0{}is best know from the southern Cape Peninsula, where it is a common element on the lower, well-drained hills. Records from the Hex River Mountains, and from the Bredasdorp plains, are somewhat suspect. It has also been recorded from Bainskloof.>
<Almost ubiquitous in the Cape Flora, but with few collections north of Ceres or east of Swellendam.>
<A widespread species on sandy plains>
<Known from only a few localities on the Bredasdorp plains, from Baardskeerdersbos to Soetanysberg.>
<From the Cederberg to the Hex River Valley, only on higher summits and plateaux.>
<From the mountains between Bainskloof and Jonkershoek, and apparently rare from the Hex River mountains, with collections from Milner Ridge Peak. Very common on Matroosberg.>
<Common along the upper ridge of the Great Swartberg Range. A very narrow endemic.>
<Rather scattered distribution.>

<On the summits and upper slopes of the dry, inland ranges of the northern mountains, from Matroosberg and the Voetpadsberg \tab{}in the south, along the Swartruggens to the eastern ranges of the Cederberg, terminating near Pakhuis Pass.>
<Along the northern slopes of the Langeberg, between Tradouw Pass and Garcias Pass.>

<This species seems to be common on the southern Peninsula, from Silvermine to Cape Point. It has also been collected from Betty's Bay, from Kleinmond, Hermanus, and from the sandy flats at the inland entrance to Franshhoek Pass.>

<The distribution reflects a typical sandveld species, with a southern boundary against False Bay, and a northern boundary at Hondeklip Bay. It also occurs in the Worcester valley. It is also found in the foothills of the Cederberg. At a finer scale the distribution is quite patchy, possibly reflecting the occurrence of acidic sands: it is common in the Sandveld from the Berg River to Joostenberg. In the Worcester valley is has been recorded only from Romansriver, and from the sandy plains at the exit of the Du Toits Kloof. It is rare along the coastal margins of the Olifants River mountains, and is found at the sand plume inland from Hondeklip Bay, as well as on the Kamiesberg.>

<The main distribution of this species is along the southern coastal mountains, from Van Staadensberg near Port Elizabeth, to Lemoenshoek Peak in the Langeberg between Swellendam and Robertson. It has also been collected from the Great Swartberg, between Swartberg Pass and Tierberg, from the Riviersondereinde, from Potberg and from Matroosberg. These outlier collections are are curious, and need further investigation.>

<This species has been collected from between the Soetanysberg to the south, and Steenbras Dam to the north. It has been collected from only six localities: Soetanysberg, several from the Viljoenshof - Pearly Beach - Elim hills, Babylons Tower, Houw Hoek and Steenbras River dam.>
<Known only from the northern slopes of the Langeberg between Gysmanshoek and Garcias Pass.>
<A common species of the western and southern coastal plains, and it also occurs on the foothills of the surrounding mountains.>
<A coastal species, which follows the coast from Cape Point, to the mouth of the Gouritz River.>

<A remarkably widespread species, and probably very under-collected. It ranges from the southern Cederberg to the Cape Peninsula, inland to Touwsberg and the Great Swartberg, and east to Uniondale. Yet it has not bee recorded from more than 10 localities. I have often seen the species, and consequently suspect that it is not rare, just rarely collected.>
<This is the only restio from the coastal bluffs east of East London, reaching almost to KwaZulu-Natal. To the south the species has been recorded occasionally as far south as George.>

<Very common and widespread on the Cape Peninsula, it has been only occasionally collected off the Peninsula: Franshoek Pass, the Pringle Bay area, Swartberg at Caledon, Pilaarkop above Rivierzondereinde, and at the farm "Brandfontein" in the Bredasdorp area.>

<A species of low hills and the foothills of the mountains, which ranges from the Cape Peninsula (where it is relatively rare), to the Elim area, and eastwards to the Bredasdorp Plains (where it is relatively common), with the eastern-most record from Bredasdorp mountain, above the village. The westernmost locality for this species is from Paardeberg at Malmesbury.>

<The original distribution of this species was along the coastal plains from the Gouritzriver in the east, to the Soetanysberg in the west, and between the sea and the "Hardeveld", the shale interior margin of the coastal plain. However, since the species has been used extensively for thatching, naturalised populations are now found as far east as Cape St Francis, and to the west to Cape Town.>

<This species is restricted to the inland margin of the Langeberg, from Attakwaskloof in the east to Barrydale in the west. It is found on the very edge of the sandstone, where they join the Karoo formations, and also seems to occur occasionally on the silcrete pediments. There is one collection from the Warmwaterberg in the Little Karoo.>
<Known only from around Kammanassie, currently from a single population on the watershed between the Vermaaks and Huis Rivers>
<This is one of the few species of Restionaceae endemic to the Cape Peninsula, and is found in the mountains from Table Mountain to Kalk Bay mountain.>

<A very common species on the Cape Peninsula, and also in some parts of the south-western mountains. It is commonly collected from Bains Kloof, less commonly from the mountains towards Hermanus, and with an eastern outlier on Pilaarkop above Rivierzondereinde Peak. To the north our species reaches Saron, and Mitchells Pass. It again appears on the barren sandstone plateaux between Botterkloof Pass and the Gifberg. The eastern-most collection is from the coastal platform at Soetanysberg, but this is a single, fragmentary collection.>

<A rather rare species of the coastal plain between the Langeberg and Indian Ocean, with the easternmost collections from Mosselbay, and the western-most collections from Potberg near the Breede River mouth. There is a single, rather incomplete collection from Robinsons Pass.>
<This is one of the few Restionaceae which are endemic to the Cape Peninsula: it is restricted to the summit plateau of Table Mountain, and the summit of Constantiaberg.>

<\i{}T. obtusus\i0{} is a lowland species with a disjunct distribution. Historically it was probably common on the sandy plains between Malmesbury and Cape Point, and also on the plains between Pearly Beach and Potberg. Now the populations in the middle section of the western plains are extinct, and the species is found in a few localities in the Malmesbury area, and again on the southern Peninsula. There are only two records from the southern coastal plains, but this might be an underestimate of the true situation.>
<This is one of the limestone-endemic Restionaceae, restricted to the limestone hills along the southern coastal forelands, between Cape Agulhas and Still Bay.>
<Endemic to the Klein Swartberg, this species is restricted to the summit ridge of the range between Sewe Weeks Poort Berg and Toverkop.>

<A species of the coastal platform, with its western-most populations at Betty's Bay, and the easternmost populations at Soetanysberg, near Cape Agulhas. This distribution has a major interval, from Kleinmond to Pearly Beach.>
<As delimited here, this species is north of Pakhuis Pass, and has been recorded from the Brandewijns River area, Nardouwsberg, Gifberg, and from Botterkloof to Van Rhynsberg pas>
<Known from a number of scattered populations, from Bredasdorp in the west to the Kafferskuil river in the east: Mierkraal, Wydgelee, Cape Infanta, and Kransfontein.>
<Endemic to Riverlands>

<Fairly widespread in the south-western mountains, the western-most border of the species is at Kaaimansgat, in the mountains just north of Villiersdorp. To the east this species reaches the mountains above Hermanus, and more inland to Bredasdorp mountain. However, the vast majority of the collections are from the Kogelberg area.>

<A typical southern "Sandveld" species, with a distribution range between False Bay and the Berg River. The type locality is from Retreat Station, and this is also the southern-most collection. It is still common in the Malmesbury and Hopefield areas. There is a single collection from Oorlogskloof near Nieuwoudtville: either a huge disjunction, or the areas in between should be collected in more detail.>

<An arid-fringe species that is found along the inland margins of the Cape mountains. To the north the species reaches the southern Cederberg at the Breekkrans Range, while to the east it ranges to the Kamannassie. There is also a collection from Cockscomb, but I am not sure whether it is best placed here or in \i{}T. cinereus\i0{}.>

<A widespread species along the arid fringes of the northern mountains, from the Cederberg in the north, through the Cold Bokkeveld, to Bonteberg and Laingsburg Witteberg, with a single collection from the Anysberg in the Little Karoo.>

<A typical West Coast species, with its northern limits on the Vredenburg Peninsula, near Paternoster, and its southern limit at Olifantsbos in the Cape Point Nature Reserve. Historical collections suggest that it was once common on the Cape Flats, but the current distribution is on the Peninsula in protected areas, and on the West Coast north of Atlantis.>
<Restricted to the south-western Cape lowlands, from Piketberg mountain to the north, to Genadendal in the east, and from the Cape Peninsula to Wolseley and the Breede River Valley.>

<Found in the mountains around Wemmershoek, to the east to Blokkop above Villiersdorp, and on the western end of the Rivierzondereinde Range, from Olifantskop to Jonaskop, with a single outlier collection from Caledon Swartberg.>
<Endemic to the north slopes of Table Mountain near Kloof Corner.>

<This species has a typical western Cape distribution. To the north the species reaches the Kamiesberg, and to the south to reaches Kaaimansgat near Villiersdorp. Its inland border is the Bonteberg at Touwsriver, and there are a few collections from the West Coast - from near Cape Town, and Malmesbury.>
<A species of the Little Karoo, found at the bases of the mountains that fringe the Little Karoo, from Toverkop to Rooiberg, and along the Langeberg from Cloetesberg to Robertson.>

<This species is almost ubiquitous in the Cape Floristic Region. To the north the species reaches Van Rhyns Pass, but does not occur in the Kamiesberg. It is widespread in the northern mountains, rather rare on the West Coast, common on the Cape Peninsula, and then there are occasional collections eastwards to the Kouga, and absent from the coastal plain of the Southern Cape.>
<Widely distributed in the western and northern mountains, from Gansbaai in the south to the northern Cederberg. It is (or was?) also found on the Cape Peninsula.>

<A western Cape species: to the north it reaches Hondeklip Baai, to the south the Cape Peninsula, and inland it spreads along the sandy intermontane valleys to Robertson and past Touwsriver to the western base of the Laingsburg Witteberg.>
<Known only from one locality>
<Known from two localities: the top of Viljoenspass, and at Rusbos, ca. 3 km south from the entrance to Franshoek Pass, between Viljoenspas and Franshoek Pass.>
<This species is a very narrow endemic from the mountains between Kleinmond and Kogelberg, and is known from only three localities.>

<\i{}Willdenowia stokoei\i0{} ranges from the highest peaks in the Cederberg, south through the Bokkeveld to the Hexriver Mountains and Matroosberg, and east to the Witteberg and Klein Swarberg. There is one collection from Keeromsberg, and a single collection from the coastal side of the Breede River valley, from the summit of Stettynsberg.>

<Quite widespread in the Western Cape, this species reaches from the Cederberg in the north to the Nuweberg at Somerset West and the western end of the Rivierzondereinde at Villiersdorp and the Cape Peninsula. It is also common in the southern half of the West Coast, from Malmesbury to False Bay.>

<The species has a peculiar allopatric distribution pattern: from Karoopoort eastwards to the Kouga mountains, with numerous collections from the drier mountains; Swartberg and inland slopes of the coastal mountains. The second pattern is from the Peninsula to Bredasdorp along the coastal plains. But this could reflect unsatisfactory taxonomy at species level.>

characters.name: occurrence in Provincial Conservation Areas or National Parks in the Western Cape
<general ecological comments>
data: <Common to locally dominant as understory in permanent seeps, forms mats and hummocks. Although restricted to the Peninsula, not endangered as the populations are extensive, and there are at least five (two on Muizenberg, three at Cape Point).>

<Cushion-forming in seeps, or forming tangled mats on cool cloud-catching ledges. Very widespread, and is the most common hummock-restio on Table Mountain. This is probably the most common hummock-restio in the Western Cape.>

<Widespread in seepages and on the wet steep upper south-facing slopes in the Langeberg and Outeniquas. May form either mats or hummocks, and may occupy the same sort of habitats as \i{}A. crinalis\i0{}. It has also been recorded from along small streams.>
<Recorded from marshes and along small streams, possibly part of the seepage hummock vegetation. Forming dense mats when mature.>

<Found in rocky streambeds of a few permanent streams in the Ceres area. Usually growing with their roots in running water. It is restricted to high-energy streams, and is also absent from several potentially suitable streams. This is possibly the only restio found only along permanent streams. A very large population at the Ceres Dam grows in seepages, not near a stream.>
<Found in seeps and swamps, where it forms typical hummocks. Not clear how it differs ecologically from \i{}A. crinalis\i0{}.>

<Scattered on well-drained sand-plains, possibly waterlogged in winter, very dry in summer. On the Suurvlakte in the southern Cederberg the species is quite common , one of the dominants on the plain with \i{}Restio unispicatus, Restio durus\i0{} and \i{}Willdenowia sulcata\i0{}. However, it seems to be restricted to the south-eastern end of the plain.>

<Locally common along streams and seeps, requiring some additional moisture, forming dense unispecific stands, rather localised. However, these small populations appear to be found in many localities. On the summit plateau of Skerpioensberg the species forms large unispecific stands, the plants eventually forming pedestals to 0.5 m tall, with the 1 m tall tussocks growing on top of these pedestals.>
<Recorded from among rocks, on ledges with trickling water, on steep south facing rocky slopes, and along streams. On Waaihoek Peak the plants are very local, among rocks and over shallow soil.>
<Rocky places on upper slopes S and W aspect near streams, also recorded from ridges and shale bands. The common feature appears to be the association with rocks.>

<Locally common, often dominant. The plants are found on well-drained, stony places, as well as seasonally moist vlaktes or plains. Most records, however, are from ridges, rather than sandplains. In the southern Cederberg it is a typical element of the higher, well-drained slopes.>

<Conspicuous dense stands or scattered at streamside or seasonally marshy places. The species is replaced where conditions become too wet. The soils range from stony places, to deeper sand, to shale bands.>

<In deeper sands along valleys and in seeps, usually with \i{}Staberoha ornata\i0{} and \i{}Thamnochortus acuminatus. \i0{}This area receives little rain, as it is in the rainshadow of the Olifantsriver Mountains, and is also very cold in winter, thus making it a very harsh environment.>
<Locally dominant in marshy habitats and along streams with \i{}A. chartaceum\i0{} in shallow soil. In the mountains around Jonkershoek the species may form extensive stands on steep slopes.>

<This species is restricted to marshy areas or swamps with seasonally standing water, near the summits of the mountains in what might be termed alpine conditions, where they receive regular snow in winter. They probably always need some groundwater seeps, even in the dry season. On Matroosberg the species is particularly common, being the most dominant element of seasonally wet (but probably always damp) seepages and swamps between Matroosberg and Sonklip, as well as along the shaleband along the southern flanks of Roodeberg. It reaches below 1800 m only along the stream.>

<Local to even common, but I have seen only a single population. Herbarium lables indicate a stony or pebbly soil habitat, rather level areas, often with slight seeps. Sone collections are from "marshy" places, others from dry, north-facing, stony slopes.>

<Forming small to extensive populations in areas with some ground water - along stream margins, in seepages, and generally in damp places. The populations may be along deep cut streamlines in sandstones, or on shale bands. Many records are from seeps on shale bands. Where the species co-occurs with other species of \i{}Askidiosperma\i0{}, it usually occupies a wetter habitat (e.g. \i{}A. capitatum\i0{} in the Cederberg).>

<Well-drained mountain slopes, often recorded from among large rocks or boulders, but never from seepages, swamps, or areas with ground-water. It is found in drier and lower altitudes than \i{}Askidiosperma esterhuyseniae. \i0{}However, at Beaverlac near Porterville it is found only in light seepages.>
<Marshy areas, moist, steep, gravelly slopes; many collections recorded from shale bands and shaley soils.>
<Locally common on well-drained soils, both on sandy plains and rocky slopes. Absent from seepages and wet places, and from rock ledges. Forming quite extensive local populations.>

<This is a common element in the Sandveld vegetation, and can locally dominate the vegetation, although it can also in places be a rather minor component. It is restricted to well-drained sandy soils, absent from damp hollows and seepages areas. It is also associated with the more acid sands, and absent from coastal dunes. It also seems to be absent from areas underlain by limestone.>
<Very local on dry, well-drained slopes on sandstones, generally between rock outcrops on deeper sands. Also recorded from sandflats which may be waterlogged in winter.>

<On well-drained soils, most populations seen on deeper soils. In the Bredasdorp - Elim area the species is common on TMS derived soils, both pebbly and sandy. On Jonaskop the species avoids TMS stony slopes, but is common on the sandy plateau. It avoids seepages areas, and steep rocky slopes. Often locally common, and very striking when in full flower.>

<Most common along stream margins and in seeps, mostly on deeper soils, almost never with rock outcrops. Often recorded from gorges or deep valleys. It appears to occupy places slightly wetter than the \i{}C. saundersii\i0{} habitat. Occasionally forming large stands or thickets. May also form a bambusoid fringe to forest patches on the Langeberg, or isolated clumps on the wet south-facing slopes.>

<An alpine species, often locally common to dominant. It is generally found in well-drained habitats, on shallow soils and stony habitats. At these upper altitudes there are few wet, deep-soil areas, but the species appears to be absent from them. This species is a characteristic element of the fynbos "alpine". It is found at higher altitudes than \i{}Cannomois primosii\i0{} and \i{}C. congesta\i0{}.>

<As defined here enormously variable, but always in well-drained habitats. On the West Coast it is found in coastal sand, while in the mountains it occurs both on stony well-drained slopes, as well as on sandy "vlaktes". It often forms extensive patches or stands, due to the spreading rhizomes.>

<Locally common on well-drained slopes, often forming quite extensive stands. The species ranges from sandstone slopes to shale bands, and often is also found on rocky plateaux. It is the only dominant \i{}Cannomois\i0{} above 1200 m in the Cederberg, on dry slopes: below this altitude the long-rhizome form of \i{}C. parviflora\i0{} dominates. At its upper altitude limit it is replaced by \i{}C. nitida\i0{}: the two species do not appear to co-occur.>

<Along streamlines and in seepages, often when the water is quite deep down. The plants often form large, extensive stands or thickets. Most common on deeper sands, but also found on stony soils, but rarely associated with rock outcrops. On the inland mountains it commonly forms stands where some groundwater can be predicted.>

<Common in arid fynbos mostly with \i{}Passerina\i0{} and other shrubby elements, generally not in typical proteoid fynbos. Generally in rocky areas, particularly where there are sandstone outcrops adjacent to karroid shales. Well drained situations.>

<A southern Cape species found on well-drained soils on sandstone slopes. It is absent from the wetter sea-facing mountains (Langeberg, Outeniquas, Tzitzikammas), and is largely a species of arid environments. It is a common component of the "arid-fringe" species of the southern Cape fynbos.>

<Locally common on well-drained stony dry slopes, often rocky, but not on cliff faces or in seepages. Often found over bedrock outcrops or among boulders, and absent from sandy plains. Associated with dry hot condition on the lower inland slopes of mountains.>

<Most common on shales, but also on sandstones. Can form large patches in over-burnt vegetation, and is often recorded as being locally abundant. Plants appear to require mesic fynbos, with a relatively high rainfall. Not associated with seepages and stream-margins in drier environments. Most flowering appears to occur in the first years after fire, after which the plants flower very poorly.>
<Common on welldrained acidic sand and loamy sand, often forming small populations of 5-15 plants, or occurring as scattered individuals.>

<Locally common on stony, well-drained slopes. One record from near a stream. The aspect appears not to be important. In the mountains above Hermanus the species is very widespread over the slopes of the mountain, and not contained in discrete populations.>

<Wide ecological range, absent from wet seepages and cliffs, but occasional on well-drained slopes to deeper soils. The species differs from its nearest relatives in occupying the same general habitat, but in wetter mountains.>

<Often in light seepages, but also widespread in drier habitats, often in deeper colluvial soils; on stony slopes and sandplains. In the mountains above Du Toits Kloof the species is found in all well-drained habitats, as well as on seasonally waterlogged sandplains.>
<Steep upper southfacing slopes in the Langeberg, sometimes near rock outcrops, usually in deeper soils, almost always associated with \i{}Elegia mucronata\i0{}.>
<Local on well-drained slopes, not in seepages or on rock-ledges. Most populations seen on south-facing slopes, but this does not seem obligatory.>
<Scattered in restioid/proteiod fynbos, on well - drained soils, sandy, no bedrock visible but on a sandstone ridge.>
<Occasional on well-drained, north facing slopes along the upper ridges of the inner, highest mountains.>
<Locally common on well-drained sandy soils, it forms an integral part of the west coast sandveld vegetation, but has a curiously restricted distribution.>
<Among rocks in well-drained habitats, sometimes (often?) in fire-refuges among rocks.>
<Occurring as large scattered tussocks on dry slopes at higher altitudes, mostly on south aspects, forming rather sparse populations. At least some populations occur on large boulder screes.>

<A very common restiaid in seepages and damp habitats. The plants tend spread through the general seepage vegetation, sometimes making up half or more of the vegetation. Almost always in full sun, but in Kogelberg it also grows in the understory of tall \i{}Berzelia\i0{} thickets. This is a common species, occupying almost every wet locality in the Cape.>
<Most collections indicate marshy conditions, sometimes in shallow soils, with the plants sometimes being locally common, on sandstones or shale-derived soils.>
<In mesic mountain fynbos in seepages or along streams, often scattered in the vegetation, or forming small populations.>

<Usually where some ground water is available. The species is particularly common in seepages and along streams. It forms large, dense stands that effectively exclude all other species of Restionaceae, and most other species of plants. The stands may become difficult to walk through. The plants are strongly rhizomatous, and large areas may be dominated by a single sex, and thus presumably by a single clone. The species seems to avoid high-energy streams.>
<All populations occur in seepage areas, at least damp in winter. Most appear to be on sand, too, or at least sandy soils. The populations are also all associated with some degree of disturbance.>
<This species forms extensive populations are seasonally wet or inundated areas, mostly on sandy soils, near the sea. It is largely absent from the better drained areas.>

<On well-drained, stony slopes to peaty, slightly marshy habitats, but absent from boggy places, wet underfoot. Common on slightly deeper soils on south-facing slopes. Rarely co-occurs with \i{}Elegia ebracteata\i0{}, but can be found in close proximity. Plants occur isolated, not forming dense monospecific stands.>

<Common on well-drained slopes on wetter mountains, especially those receiving substantial rain in summer. On the Peninsula and in the mountains to Hermanus found on the south-facing slopes, usually in black peaty soils.>
<Forming populations in very wet habitats, often with the plant bases in water, in seeps and along the margins of dams and streams.>

<Common on well-drained slopes, often forming quite extensive stands. On Table Mountain it is particularly common on shallow soils over bedrock, along the edges of the mountain, and is one of the dominant species on the Upper Table of Table Mountain. In the inland mountains it usually forms populations on ridges and stony slopes. It is also often found in slight seepages along these bedrock outcrops.>
<Locally dominant in seepages in the acidic sands of the west coast plains. It may also be found in hollows, but appears to prefer the vicinity of fountains.>

<Locally common, forming distinct populations which at times can be very dense, and which have been described as "impenetrable". Mostly found in slight seepages and along streams, but in the southern Cape the species is often found on well-drained slopes. It is a rather common species, and should be encountered on most mountains.>

<The species appears to be common at higher altitudes, and has been recorded both from shale bands and from sandstone slopes. It forms large colonies, and is often noted to be from slight seepages. On the Matroosberg massif it is very widespread above 1900 m, often dominant or at least common on shale bands, sandy plains, and gravelly slopes. When flowering it is quite striking.>

<The three populations are all from the interface between renosterveld and sandstone, probably indicating a sandstone alluvium. The plants are said to form small colonies, and occur in areas which are wet in winter, but dry in summer. The population at Wolseley is on sandstone gravel over shale, in loamy soils, and forms a very extensive population.>
<All records are from marshy areas, and the banks of small streams, often mixed with tall vegetation. In several cases the species shares the habitat with invasive alien \i{}Acacia\i0{} species.>

<Very wide ecological amplitude. Found in damp hollows and wetlands, on montane sand plains or "vlaktes", on stony well drained slopes, and along the summit ridges of the Klein Swartberg. On the Suurvlakte in the southern Cederberg the species is locally dominant, forming extensive stands, both on the sandy plain in deep sand, as well as on the rocky slopes. Both habitats are very well drained, and the species is absent from the wet hollows it characteristically inhabitats at Cape Point. It remains a very puzzling species ecologically.>

<This species is almost restricted to damp habitats, seeps and along stream margins. In the wet Outeniqua mts it occurs on the upper south-facing slopes, where it may at times dominate the vegetation. It usually grows with its roots in running water, especially in drier places with a more pronounced dry season.>

<Locally common, usually in seeps and along streamslines, often in deeper soil. It is absent from the well-drained ridges. The species is almost restricted to the N slopes, with only a few plants reaching the upper S slopes.>

<Dry fynbos on N slopes of Langeberg, near base of the mountains, occasionally up to the lower wetter slopes, but also right to the renosterveld margin. Always found in well-drained habitats, on often stony ground.>
<Generally the species forms distinctive small or large populations, on well-drained soils, often on stony mountain sides. In some places the plants can become quite large and robust with age.>

<This species often forms large, almost monospecific stands in marshes and along streamside seeps, in high mountain basins. The plants usually grow in very organic soils, but are usually dry around the base, and so do not need to be waterlogged throughout the year. In general, the habitati of this species is quite variable, with some populations growing on well-drained slopes, while others are restricted to seasonally waterlogged areas, or seepages on "vlaktes" in the higher mountains. It remains possible that several distinct elements have here been included under one name.>

<It grows on well drained slopes, and can be locally abundant. In Kogelberg often adjacent to, but never syntopic with, \i{}E. ebracteata\i0{}: it is found on flats and gentle slopes with some impeded drainage, while \i{}E. ebracteata \i0{} is restricted to the well-drained slopes.>

<Associated with rock outcrops or ledges, and with groundwater. At Beaverlac the plants grow along the boulders and rocks of the Ratelriver flood-plain, where plant cover is sparse, and where ground-water is available.>

<Seepage area and streamlines, in areas almost perennially wet, locally common. It seems never to totally dominate the vegetation, but is most common along seepage lines with \i{}Elegia mucronata\i0{}.>

<A common element in fynbos, the species rarely forms dense stands, but instead occurs intermingled with other species, especially dicots. It is usually found on open slopes, both in well-drained habitats as well as in slight seepages. It appears to prefer higher rainfall areas, and is largely absent from drier mountains.>
<Locally very common on well-drained sand, often near bedrock. Not usually found on steep stony slopes, more common on sandy plateaux. Not associated with seepages or any form of groundwater.>
<Among rocks in well-drained habitats>
<On coastal sands, common in dune-slacks, forming extensive carpets. Sometimes also associated with limestone outcrops. The species can be very common in places.>

<Locally dominant in seeps and wet areas; mostly this species is found in the cloud-zone from the south-easterly winds. However, it is most common in seepages. Often it may be the dominant restio in the area.>

<Quite common on the sandplains of the Riversdale - Albertinia plains, in well-drained habitats. A weak association with limestones, but more frequently found in the loamier sands associated with dune hollows.>
<Well drained sandy plain>

<Covers a wide ecological amplitude: on sandy plains, often near seeps; sometimes mat-forming near streams or in seasonally wet sand. However, the plants appear to avoid well-drained habitats, and is a common component of seep vegetation, or along stream margins.>

<Quite common in damp hollows on the coastal sandy plains, often forming small stands. However, the extensive populations so characteristic of \i{}Elegia tectorum\i0{} are not formed. A single collection is from clayey soils; mostly they are seen on sandy soils. The rhizomatous habit means that the plants are often more or less integrated into the surrounding vegetation.>

<Well drained mountain slopes and plateaux, often locally common to even dominant. The soils are described as stony or sandy soils. The plants reseed after fire, and sometimes form extensive stands, although some collections also note the species to be of occasional tufts.>
<Generally occurs in sand at lower altitudes. Most plants seem to grow in well-drained habitats, although some are recorded from damp sand.>

<Widespread on well-drained sandstone slopes, in areas with good rainfall. The species grows intermingled with other plants, and does not form extensive stands. When flowering, it can be quite striking.>

<Seasonally waterlogged habitats, over a wide range of soils. At Riverlands it is the most common restioid in waterlogged habitats, it covers a very large area. The soils vary from sand at Riverlands to heavy clays below the pallid zone at Potberg.>

<Can form very large monospecific stands, like wheatfields, with a sharp boundary to them. On Milner Vlakte it co-occurs with \i{}Elegia filacea\i0{}, but grows in wetter habitats on sand, while \i{}E. filacea\i0{} grows on gravelly hillocks. Locally dominant on winter-wet sandy flats.>

<Locally common on sandplains or little "vlaktes", often dominant. Often in slightly deeper colluvial soils. Generally seems to prefer deeper soils, and seems to be absent from rocky slopes. On the Kleinrivers Berg some 3-4 years after fire dominating large areas of the plateau.>

<Only on heavy soils, such as shales and silcretes. Often recorded from below renosterbos. Sometimes in quite waterlogged conditions. The species is also found on the lower slopes of mountains, where the soils are heavy.>
<Most common on well-drained slopes, the species often forms dense stands. It is not found in seepages or wet places. It is most common on deeper sandy flats, but may also be found on stony slopes.>

<Locally common on well-drained stony slopes, on the hot, lower slopes of the mountains. On Olifantsberg it was restricted to below the plateau, on N-facing, bleak slopes. The species forms rather extensive stands, suggestive of a reseeder strategy.>

<Very common in seasonally damp habitats on sandy soils. On the Bredasdorp plains the species forms very extensive stands in the shallow flat depressions that abound in the area. Over the rest of the range it is typical of ditches and depressions on sandy plains, and often proliferates in roadside ditches.>

<Forming a large stand in a seepage, with \i{}Cannomois grandis\i0{} and \i{}Anthochortus ecklonii\i0{}. Even in summer the ground is mossy and wet. It is possibly that other populations are of fewer plants. All records indicate marshy habitat, either along streams or in strong seepages.>
<Locally common on wet seaward facing slopes of the Outeniqua mountains, growing in dense heath, often locally dominant.>

<It is difficult to characterise this widespread species ecologically. On the coastal plains it is frequently associated with areas with impeded drainage, thus waterlogged in winter and very dry in summer. The collections from montane areas are also generally recorded from marshy areas or from rock shelves or ledges.The Eastern Cape collections are more difficult to place ecologically, but seem to be from south-facing slopes, in cool and possibly damp habitats, but not from seepages.>
<Seasonally waterlogged habitats, on the sandplains largely restricted to hollows, where it forms dense mats excluding other species.>
<Found along streams and along the margins of wet seepages in arid areas, usually twined among other Restionaceae, occasionally forming distinct tussocks.>

<This species has been recorded from a wide range of habitats, mostly well-drained or with slight seepages. However, it is most common on shale-bands, where it is often the most common or even dominant restioid. It seems to prefer the somewhat heavier soils, and off shale-bands is also found in lenses of heavier soils.>
<Occurs in marshy as well as rocky areas. At Somersfontein the species is generally found on well-drained, stony slopes, with almost crystalline white sandstone pebbles.>

<Common on well-drained slopes, often thriving with some disturbance. Often growing among rocks, and more rare on deeper sands. It is thus an element of the pebbly well-drained slopes of the western Cape mountains.>

<Common in a wide range of habitats, always in well-drained habitats. The species is particularly striking on sandy plains (Suurvlaktes) in the mountains, but is also found in most other habitats. It rarely forms dense stands, but tends to occur as well-spaced individuals. It is absent from seepages and streambanks, and from cliff-ledges and shallow-soil habitats.>

<Common on dry, hot, well-drained slopes throughout the western Cape, usually on stony slopes. Restricted to well-drained slopes. The frequency of the species ranges from common to locally dominant, to scattered and rare. It seems as though it is very widespread, and that every mid-altitude well-drained stony slope contains this species.>
<found on shallow soils along ridges, but not between big boulders, and absent from deeper seep soils. Localised with some 200 plants altogether.>

<Well drained sandy to stony plains and slopes, often locally subdominant. On the Bonteberg the species is common over the whole altitude range, and is also found on the broad shale areas, with \i{}Pentameris eriostoma\i0{} and \i{}Tenaxia stricta\i0{}.>

<On deeper sand among limestone outcrops, often growing among limestone pebbles, but not in limestone cracks. The plants are very cryptic, with small tufts of very small culms well hidden among the remainder of the vegetation.>
<This is a typical limestone species, found on well-drained slopes, growing rooted in limestone pavement, sometimes locally common.>

<This is one of the few species of African Restionaceae that is found in renosterbosveld. It grows in either sand or clay, and seems to be able to tolerate various soil mixes, typical of the lowlands. Most of the habitats seem to be wet in the winter but dry in the summer months, and many are areas of impeded drainage.>
<Herbarium records indicate a habitat on gravelly sand with rocks for both localities. In the one site the plants were found growing among rocks. It seems to be quite localised.>

<This very widespread species is characteristic of the arid margins of fynbos, and is often one of the last species before Karoo vegetation takes over. It is found on a diversity of substrates, often forming quite large patches, or a broken understory under woody vegetation. It is always found in well-drained habitats. Only in the Southern Cape does it enter wetter conditions, on the summits of the Outeniqua mountains.>

<Restricted to heavy loamy soils, with renosterbos (\i{}Elytropappus rhinocerotis\i0{}) and scattered fynbos elements (Proteaceae, Restionaceae), but near sandstone outcrops. Very local, and absent from sandstone derived soils.>
<This species is a common element of the mesic to dry mid-altitude fynbos of the Little Karoo mountains. It can be locally common on well-drained, stony slopes.>

<This species is usually found in well-drained sandy habitats, generally avoiding stony soils. The plants often form small probably clonal patches. It is most common on coastal sands, on sands derived from various bedrock types. There are a few collections from the northern and south-western mountains (the northern-most collection, from Skoongesig in the Bokkeveld, was made by Schlechter and needs corroboration), these are also from sandy plains at the base of the mountains.>
<Often forming extensive stands on well-drained slopes and flats, it can become very common locally.>

<This species is a typical element of the lower slopes of mountains in the southern Cape, receiving substantial rain in summer. Thus it is part of the mesic fynbos. However, the species is also found in much more arid parts of the southern Cape, on well-drained soils.>
<A species of well-drained soils, from arid to mesic fynbos, apparently absent from seepages, swampy areas, or rock ledges. Many collections are from somewhat deeper soils.>

<Local in slight seepages, often quite common, usually on deeper soils. Around the Steenbras River catchment this species has become very common, often found under pine plantations, and may be an early succession plant into disturbed areas.>

<Found along margins of a marsh on a shale band, and on the rocky slope directly below the shale band. It is absent from the wet central portion of the marsh, but also from the well drained general slope: the plants are thus found along the damp margins of the marsh.>

<Locally common to dominant on seepages, in full sun, on loamy soils. It has also been recorded from the summit of the Langeberg on shallow soil over rock, and on seepages on both north and south aspects.>
<Grows in seeps along streams, where it forms dense hummocks.>

<This species requires water throughout the year, and is found either on steep upper south-facing slopes, where it receives regular orographic rain, or in seepages or on streambanks. Sometimes described as being common.>

<\i{}Platycaulos callistachyus\i0{} appears always to be associated with ground water. It is most mostly found along streams, and in the southern Cape can be regarded as a typical streamside element. It is found both on deeper soils along streams, as well as in rocky streambeds. Maybe the strongly developed rhizome enables it to cope with floodwaters. In the George area the species will grow in light shade in riverine forest.>
<Common in areas with some ground water: along streams, and in seepages. The name derives from a typical habitat: along a streambank at a waterfall.>

<Generally found in seeps and wet habitats. In the wet Outeniqua mts the species is often found on the steep upper south-facing slopes, with other seep-loving species. On the coastal plains, and on mountains not receiving very regular summer rain, the species is restricted to ground-water areas.>
<Collected from places with some ground water, usually in seeps or marshes, occasionally from damp ledges. The plants often form hummocks, and are associated with \i{}Anthochortus crinalis\i0{}.>
<Locally common on grassy slopes>
<This species appears to be restricted to marshy habitats, where it can be locally very common. These seeps on Mt Mulanje are commonly found in shallow soils over rock.>
<Found in peaty soils, often among rocks, in ericoid high-altitude vegetation.>

<On Table Mountain this species grows along permanent streams, and the recorded habitat from several other localities agrees with this. In the Rivierzondereinde mountains there are also collections from steep upper south-facing slopes, these receive cloud and orographic moisture throughout the year.>
<Locally common on shallow soils over bedrock, forming quite extensive stands, almost monospecific.>
<Locally common in montane heathland, often recorded from rock ledges.>

<Recorded from marshy habitats, either in seepages or along streambanks, rarely from rock ledges. Plants often associated with \i{}Anthochortus\i0{} in tussock marshes. Above Du Toits Kloof the species was seen in a raised bog with ericas and copious \i{}Anthochortus crinalis\i0{}, mostly the culms tangled through the other species.>
<Very local on well drained sand.>
<Occasional to rare in fynbos on well-drained sandy flats, or stony slopes, often near limestone outcrops. However, it does not seem to grow on the limestones.>
<Recorded from moist areas, and on rocky south slopes, often with tall vegetation.>

<Occasional on well-drained slopes, often part of general well-drained fynbos. Seems to be most common on the silcrete plateaux on the coastal side of the Outenique mountains. The occurrence at Verkykerkop between Heidelberg and the sea suggest a once much more common distribution along the coastal plains.>
<Restricted to rock ledges and among rocks on south-facing slopes, in apparently somewhat fire-protected habitats.>
<One of the most drought tolerant restioids, found in extremely dry conditions, at the very margin of fynbos vegetation, in well drained habitats. The soils are generally stony or pebbly.>
<Locally common on gravelly soils or damp sand, often with impeded drainage. Often only females found.>
<Common on steep south facing slopes, but only in the lower portions, where it virtually dominates the understorey.>

<Most of the collections are from the lower margins of fynbos in dry hot conditions, on stony well-drained soils. A single collection from Milner Peak suggests radically different ecological conditions. Associated with renosterveld and arid fynbos. On the farm Corona the species is very common from the base of the hills to the summit of the mountain at 1100 m, often dominant. Locally it is replaced as dominant by \i{}Restio marlothii\i0{} or \i{}R. luxurians\i0{}.>
<Well-drained coarse sandy soils, locally common to even dominant, in dry fynbos. At Somersfontein the species is found in the driest habitats, on stony slopes.>
<Common on well-drained habitats on stony soils and sandy plains, often very common to even locally dominant.>
<Locally common to dominant on dry to moist slopes, usually quite well-drained habitats. Absent from seeps, but found on stony slopes as well as sandy plains.>

<Locally common to dominant in seepage areas. These range from extensive damp areas, often shallow sand over bedrock, or as occasional plants along drainage lines. In the swampy areas of the Upper Table of Table Mountain this is one of the more common Restionaceae.>

<Local on damp habitats on sandy plains, and on rocky slopes. In the mountains the species is generally recorded from the lower slopes, but many records indicate ground water: along streams, seepages, in tall streamside vegetation.>
<Local along margin between shale and sandstone, on both substrates. Very dry habitat, disturbed, old fields.>

<On well drained soils. At Somersfontein the species is found on sandy flats, while most of the montane populations occur in rocky habitats, often along the ridges, with the plants placed among the boulders.>

<A species mostly associated with ground water supplies, either along streams or in seepages, where it may form a ring around \i{}Restio confusus\i0{} marshes. Recorded from both rocky slopes and from shale bands.>

<Generally found along seeps and streamlines, often forming relatively dense colonies, with intertwined plants. In some places the plants are found away from streams - this seems to be especially the case at higher altitudes - but these may be over seasonal seepages.>
<Well drained habitats, or on rocky banks of seasonal streams, on sandy or rocky soils.>
<Gravelly soils, well-drained to impeded drainage. It can be locally very common, forming a matted understorey to the vegetation.>
<Well-drained habitats, often exposed to seasalt, or also among bushes in more sheltered habitats. Often quite common, but not seen to dominate the restioid vegetation.>

<Very widespread on well-drained often stony soils, near the lower and arid margins of fynbos, and also on shales. This is a common species on shale bands in the mountains, and is also found on Malmesbury and Bokkeveld shales at the base of the mountains.>
<Recorded for marshes or under rocks.>

<Locally common on well-drained soils, often described as rocky. Several collections are from shale bands, and I have seen the species grow next to renosterveld, where sandstone meets shale, as well as on typical dry TMS soils. The species appears to prefer hot, dry, well-drained localities.>

<Locally common on sandy plains in the southern Peninsula mountains; also found on rock ledges and gullies (for the Hermanus and Riverzondereinde populations). Often forming an "understorey" to other restios and fynbos plants, and can act as a ground-cover over substantial areas.>
<The plants occurs in seasonally wet areas, either in marshes or in shallow sand over rock, and may be locally dominant in these areas.>
<Slight seepage areas near bedrock outcrops, forming almost monospecific populations, near \i{}Restio curviramis\i0{}. It is locally common, forming distinct populations.>

<Steep S-facing slopes on black organic soils. Forming large mats and a tangled undergrowth under the other restios and other plants. Usually in shady places. Clumps and mats along the path up the Clock Peaks above Swellendam.>
<Seepages and damp sand localities, often forming an extensive ground cover.>

<This species is restricted to perennially wet swamps, where it can often be the dominant plant, forming large, distinctive tussocks, which appear to exclude all other species. These swamps can be located either on shale bands or on sandstone, and can also form along streamsides. Possibly the species is always associated with perennial surface water, but this is more difficult to substantiate.>

<This is a species of rocky summits. On Matroosberg I found it growing on shady rock ledges, well protected from fire, and quite cool, but dry. This is consistent with most habitat notes, which indicate cool, dry places, associated with rocky or rock pavement, or ledges. Possibly these are all fire-protected habitats. In the Swartberg it is very common on the upper ridges, where it is matforming, and a dominant element.>
<Mostly recorded from slight seepages, both on sandstone slopes and shale bands. Some populations also occur in relatively well-drained areas>

<Locally dominant or at least very common on stony, dry slopes. Often associated with the typical dome-shaped shaley summits, like Wellington Sneeukop and Victoria Peak, but also found on sandstone summits.>

<Very common on sandy plains in seepages and on rock ledges in damper conditions. At lower altitudes found in wetter sands or even loamy soils. This species is remarkably common, part of the guild of low, matforming species that can form extensive understoreys to the general vegetation.>

<Locally common on sandy plains, forming a dense fine understory under taller Restionaceae, also on generally well-drained slopes. Many collections also indicate the presence of the species is slightly marshy areas, and in disturbed areas.>

<On steep south-facing slopes, possibly among vegetation. The herbarium labels do not give any further information. Extensive populations in seepages in the valley towards Sleeping Beauty from De Tol, plants forming extensive mats in the undergrowth.>
<Locally dominant and mat- forming on steep southfacing slopes, often associated with bedrock or scree slopes. The plants are also often found hanging off ledges, and seem to like cool shady places.>

<Generally found along streams and more rarely in seepages. Often the tall plants overtop the other streamside vegetation, forming very visible stands. It is also often found among rocks. This species is mostly found at lower altitudes, often in deeper soils.>

<Usually found associated with rock outcrop and ledges, often on the steep broken cliffs below shale bands. In well drained localities, or in the slight ephemeral seeps found on these outcrops. The plants form cushions and mats among the rocks and other plants.>

<Mostly found on dry stony slopes, in well-drained habitats. However, some collections are from boggy habitats, such as the southern aspect of the mountains above Hermanus. It may be that the species is variable in its ecology. It seems rarely to be locally common, but seems to occur as isolated plants, part of the general vegetation.>

<Recorded from a wide range of habitats: shalebands, slight seepages, seep earthy south slopes, rock ledges, stony slopes, peaty places. Some records also refer to granitic soils. In general, the species appears to require some seasonal seepage, which is often found over rock ledges, and near the base of shale bands. It is sometimes locally dominant.>

<A typical alpine species, often dominant in the alpine areas, it may at times form extensive monospecific stands. It seems to cope well with snow-cover. The coastal mountains appear to be too mesic for it. On the Matroosberg massif it dominates the shale-bands, but does also occur elsewhere.>
<In damp habitats, in seepages and along stream margins. In the Reserve this is a common element of seasonally waterlogged habitats, which it shares with \i{}Elegia cuspidata\i0{}.>
<Generally found in waterlogged areas, or in seepages which are wet most of the year. The plants often form extensive stands, and may dominate the vegetation, or occur as a few isolated tufts.>

<This species is rare and local, and is found on sand on suurvlaktes, in well-drained conditions, or in stony, well-drained habitats. On the Suurvlakte in the southern Cederberg it is a common element on well-drained sand, but only in a portion of the plain.>

<Quite widespread on loamier soils, often in slight seepages, and rare to absent from well-drained dry sites. It seems to be one of the more common species of the lowlands. On the Paardeberg it is restricted to seepage areas, where it can at times be quite common, while at Steenboksberg it was found in riverine rubble>
<Common on damp or well-drained slopes, rarely forming monospecific stands but integrated into the general restioid vegetation. Most collection records indicate black soils in seepage areas.>

<Scattered on well-drained slopes, rarely locally dominant, often among rocks, or at least on rocky slopes. Absent from deep sandy plains or suurvlaktes, or from seepage areas. Although often common, this species does not form dense stands.>

<Locally common from areas with ground-water, and ample bedrock. Typical habitats include rocky streambanks, ledges, edges of small cliffs. The plants are usually described as tangled, often as pendulous from cracks on the rocks or on ledges. The substrate is often described as peaty or mossy.>

<Common along coastal sands, often matforming on the dunes directly behind the beaches. The deepseated spreading rhizomes is ideal for moving sands, and being deeply seated, is not readily exposed by moving sand.>

<Very common on rocky slopes, in well-drained habitats, this species can be locally dominant. It appears to occupy the same habitat as \i{}I. virgea\i0{}, and the two species alternate on the stony slopes between Zebasberg and Mt Superior.>

<Well-drained slopes. On the Bonteberg, at Corona, the species is very common along the lower slopes below the first set of cliffs, and is the dominant restio at this altitude. It is absent from the upper parts of the mountain here, being replaced by \i{}I. karooica\i0{} and a host of other species. These lower slopes appear to consist of sandstone rubble overlying shale.>
<Restricted to coastal marshes on the 5m platform around Betty's Bay.>
<Locally common in seepages and damp areas at lower altitudes, often on loamy soils.>

<One of the most typical species of well-drained, gravelly steep sandstone slopes. The plants are often among stones and rocks and general gravel. The species is also found on sandplains, both as "suurvlaktes" on the mountains, and on the West Coast. It is less common in well-drained habitats in the Langeberg. Throughout its range it is able to grow in exposed rocky habitats on ridges.>
<In marshy places, sometimes on south-facing slopes, or in seepages. Along the Krom River above Du Toits Kloof the species grows on the river bank in slight seepages.>

<Almost all records are from rocky places on summit ridges, these include "among rocks" (very common reference), "rocky summit ridge", "rocky places" and "ledges near summit". In the Slanghoek mountains the species is very common indeed on rocky platforms and cliffs (eg along the edge of shale bands). This is particularly the case around Slanghoek Pk. On the two Wellington Sneeukops it is more rare, but still in fire protected habitats.>

<On the lower slopes of Audensberg in rugged, but hot and dry country, with \i{}Heeria argentea\i0{} and \i{}Crassula rupestris\i0{}, while near the summit it is found in dry, rocky places.
