Thus found over a surprising altitude range. I have seen it only at the summit of Audensberg, where it occurs on block-ridges amongst huge boulders, where fire never penetrates. The lower altitude records need checking.>
<In marshes in wetland, and along stream-margins.>
<Common on dry TMS slopes, especially in the arid parts of the fynbos region. Generally found on stony or rocky slopes, and tends to form big clumps next to boulders and along ledges.>

<This species is found in damp to wet habitats, often in seepages or along the margins of seepages, or on plains which are seasonally waterlogged. It is common on the summit plateau of Skerpioenberg, where it forms large tussocks in the seasonally wet hollows. It is also found in seasonally waterlogged sandy flats, and in slight seepages in the mountains further east.>

<Recorded from granitic soils, and sandstone rubble, or pebbly slopes. The populations appear to occur in well-drained localities, often in vegetation with at least some \i{}Elytropappus rhinocerotis\i0{} in it. Observed along the road from Elim to Baardskeedersbosch on shale soils, in renosterveld.>
<Some records from sandy plains in river valleys at the base of mountains, where the species is recorded to form extensive stands. Most records are form near streams, or along stream-beds.>

<A species more or less restricted to well drained slopes, often on deeper sands. It seems to be absent from seepages, or from rocky habitats. There is one record from "somewhat peaty sand", and another from "TMS gravels", which probably indicate extremes in the habitat range.>

<Common in fynbos on well-drained soils, ranging from fairly stony, gravelly slopes on the Swartberg to slopes with deeper, organic soils in the Langeberg. It is absent from seepages and seasonally wet conditions.>
<Forming great masses on the upper south-facing slopes, where the plants receive rain and fog throughout the year.>

<Occasional on leached coastal sands, not common. It is generally integrated into the general vegetation, and although I have seen several populations, it never seems to be locally dominant. It is found in well-drained habitats.>

<A common element of the dense restioid fynbos on well-drained steep south-facing slopes in the Langeberg. These areas receive substantial moisture in summer off the south-easter driven clouds and rain, and the soils are generally deep and peaty. The species is absent from drainage lines, and is not associated with dry rocky outcrops, but is often found where the bush is less dense.>
<On south facing rock ledges and steep slopes, in black organic soils. Locally common, forming dense clumps with finely branched culms.>
<Among rocks or on rocky slopes, on ridges and summits. The plants occur scattered, not forming populations.>

<Associated with very rocky environments: ledges, among boulders in valley bottoms and rocky streambanks. The habitat is often described as "rugged". The species seems to prefer growing in the shelter off, and between, huge boulders. Along the Krom River above Du Toits Kloof the species grows in the river floodplain, sheltering behind huge boulders, while on the Limietberg it grows on rock ledges, often in fire-refuges.>

<Well-drained, dry stony slopes. On the slopes N of Corona, the species is very common above the cliffs, and is absent below the first set of cliffs, where the vegetation is dominated by \i{}Restio esterhuyseniae\i0{}.>

<An alpine species, often locally dominant above 1500 m; on Milner is almost only restioid in snowfields. It may co-occur with \i{}I. distracta\i0{}, differs ecologically from it by its ability to sprout after fire. Occasional populations are found at much lower altitudes, and on Nardouwspass a population is in dry fynbos at 550 m.>

<Restricted to marshy or wet places. Many collections are from seepages and marshes, where the species is often found with \i{}Anthochortus crinalis\i0{}. However, the most common habitat appears to be on wet rock ledges, often on south-facing aspects where the plants collect moisture from south-easter clouds. Here they form great masses and hang down the rocks. On the south slopes below Kogelberg the species is very common in gaps in the vegetation and on small ledges.>

<This species occurs occasionally among rocks on sandy plains. It may prefer the shelter of large sandstone boulders or outcrops, but grows in deep, well-drained sand. It forms large clumps next to these rock outcrops. Described as common on sandstone slabs with \i{}Protea glabra\i0{} on the arid margins of fynbos.>

<Very common in deeper sand along streams, often growing under tall \i{}Cannomois saundersii\i0{} stands, thus lightly shaded. Also higher on mountain in light seeps. Local along rock outcrops and ledges.>
<Very common on limestones, especially on pavement or ledges. The plants seem to prefer to grow among bushes or rocks, where it is somewhat cooler. Often among the more common plants.>

<A common element of hot, dry fynbos on the lower slopes of the mountains, and from the renosterveld over shales adjacent to the sandstone outcrops. The species avoids seepages and sheltered localities, and is not usually associated with big sandstone boulders.>

<This species is largely restricted to deep sandy soils, usually not associated with bedrock outcrops or a rocky surface. These are found along stream valleys, and on the coastal plains. It is generally associated with seasonally waterlogged habitats, sandstones, recent sands, and sandy loams derived from shales. Also in drier habitats, where there is seepage in winter.>
<In dry fynbos, on well-drained, stony soils. Many of the herbarium labels indicate moist sand, suggesting slight seepages.>
<At Riverlands the species was observed on well-drained acidic sand. All herbarium records indicate a sandy habitat, but most indicate moister conditions, often near streams or seepages.>

<This species is characteristic of wet raised bogs and seepages, where it often forms large, almost monospecific stands. Very frequently (always?) it is associated with permanently wet seepages, thus with surface water. These seeps are found on the margins of sandy plains, on shale bands, and also on sandstone.>
<Very common in permanently wet areas and seepage areas, often adjacent to streams, the habitat is burnt regularly.>
<In deep, dry sand, or in very temporary seepages, locally common but usually widespread. It is rarely recorded from rocky or stony habitats, with most populations growing on deep sand.>
<Most collections have been recorded from damp, peaty soil, on seeps and somewhat marshy places, or where some additional moisture is available. Often locally common.>
<Very rare in seepage cracks below high cliffs.>
<All records are from rocky habitats: on ledges, on rocky summits, among large boulders. The plants form large springy cushions in these locations.>
<Local on well-drained sandy or gravelly soils, in general proteaceous fynbos. The plants are isolated, as as tall as the surrounding proteas.>

<Common on well-drained soils in the Bredasdorp plains, on the Cape Peninsula the species is generally found on steeper slopes, often on south facing slopes (such as Nursery Ravine) in dense vegetation. Also on the lower granitic mountains around Paarl among rocks and on south-slopes. Thus in cool, well-drained habitats. The species is also often associated with somewhat richer soils - granites on Paardeberg, Bokkeveld Shale in the Elim basin.>

<Locally common to dominant at higher altitudes, is the dominant on Hexberg plateau and Fonteintjiesberg summit, common on Milner, growing on sandy plains, and on shallow soils over bedrock. These habitats are frequently waterlogged in winter, and often received at least some snow.>

<Mostly found in seasonally wet flushes over bedrock, in small gullies and in seepages or on ledges. Sometimes recorded from partially shaded habitats, but most common fully exposed, on both north and south aspects. The cushion growth-form suggests and alpine species.>

<All records indicate seasonally wet or marshy habitats. These can be montane swamps, or damp ledges, or seasonal wet marshes on the well-leached sandplains in the Rockview Dam area. At Nuweberg the plants grow along a jeeproad in a pine-plantation, in a slight seepage and along a drainage ditch.>
<In marshy places where the growth is low and the more aggressive marsh Restionaceae are absent, rather local and inconspicuous. Also in road-side ditches.>

<In the mountains north of Du Toits Kloof this species is common on well-drained slopes, often with some stony outcrops. Around the stony, drier margins of the sandy Suurvlakte it can even be locally dominant. It is absent from the seasonally waterlogged sandy parts of the plain, and can reach quite high up on the stony mountain sides. The larges populations, though, are on the rocky and stony fringes of the sandy plain.>

<Generally found in places with ground-water. Most commonly along stream-margins, where the plants are often found hanging over the streams. It also occurs in seepages, but less commonly so. On Skerpioensberg in the Northern Cederberg it forms large monospecific stands in the occasionally waterlogged basins. Plants usually form colonies, rarely of isolated individuals.>

<Most commonly found on well-drained slopes among rocks. In more heavily burnt areas the species appears to be restricted to areas with rocky outcrops, it is not clear whether this is to avoid fire, or for some other reason. Even in unburnt areas the species is mostly associated with rock outcrops. It is characteristic of the drier inland edge of the mountains, and is missing from the cooler, moister mountains. In the cooler Hex River mts, the species is restricted to the lower slopes.>
<This species seems to be associated with rocky habitats: along streamlines, on ridges. Often also found in seepages or places with ground water. It seems rarely to form large stands.>

<The species has only been recorded from seasonally waterlogged conditions. Most collections are from deep sandy areas, usually with impeded drainage, but some are from mountain slopes, presumably from shallower soils.>

<In wet habitats, in seepages with \i{}Roridula\i0{}, and along stream margins. These are found on the south facing upper slopes of these low mountains, where they receive ample rain throughout the year. The plants from a dense tangled understory under the other vegetation.>

<Restricted to stream margins or strong seeps, found over a wide geographical and edaphic range in this habitat. Growing both in streams, and in thicket vegetation flanking streams. May also be found in light shade in riverine forest, in which habitat plants can reach 3 m tall. This is one of the few species that (a) is found along river banks and (b) will grow some distance from the nearest sandstones, on sandstone rubble washed down the river beds. The species can often form extensive, very dense stands.>
<Most collections indicate a seasonally wet or marshy habitat, and in some cases the plants might be inundated in winter. The collections are from a wide range of soil types.>

<On south-slopes, at base of cliffs, on rocky ledges at base of cliffs, on damp south-facing ledges, locally frequent. This seems an almost analogous habitat to that of \i{}Staberoha stokoei\i0{} from the Great Swartberg. These habitats are extremely cold in winter, but cooler in summer.>

<This species is found in rocky habitats, either on ledges, or among boulders. Also in recesses on rocky slopes and in gullies, habitats typical of the upper rocky slopes of the Cape mountains. Most collections are from above 1500 m, but at Beverlac, near Keerom at Porterville, the species is very common in cool, rocky habitats at below 500 m.>
<Very local populations on deep sand over groundwater. Both locations showed some disturbance, the Skurweberg Pass population showed substantial disturbance.>

<This species is quite common on dry, well drained, stony slopes. It is usually well intergrated into the surrounding vegetation, with isolated shoots rising from spreading stolons. This effectively makes the plants difficult to see, and has probably resulted in an undercollecting of the species. The males, which at flowering are much more visible than the females, have been collected more frequently.>
<This species is found on shallow, well drained soils, often stony. It avoids the deeper, organic soils on the south-facing slopes, and seepages. There are no deep sandy flats in this area.>

<Very common on dry sandy to stony slopes, may be the dominant restio in some areas, often in slight seepages, sometimes even in wet conditions. Often alongside temporary streams, and in seepage areas on sandy plains or "vlaktes". This species appears to have a wide ecological tolerance. But it is always found on sandy soils, rarely if ever among rocks.>

<Mostly on found on rock-ledges or on steep slightly shady slopes, can be very common in understory of shrubs in the wetter mountains. This is a common cushion-forming species in cool, damp, somewhat shaded habitats, but is absent from wet seepages and bogs.>

<This species has been recorded from marshy habitats: at the Toll House in Garcias Pass, and above Swellendam. It has been observed black peaty soil, not in deep marshes are on dry rocky slopes. On the Clock Peaks the population was in well-drained soil among rock, so the habitat characteristisation based on Garcias Pass might be incorrect.>

<Locally common, but in several diverse habitats, the common theme being proximity to rock. In Jonkershoek the species is found on rocky slopes, among rocks, on ledges, possibly where there is a slight seepage. On Pilaarkop it is found on peaty south-facing slopes, along the edge of rock outcrops.>

<I am treating this species as restricted to the well-drained acidic coastal sands, or the dry foothills of the northern mountains. Here it grows away from seepages, scattered in the general vegetation.>

<Seasonally waterlogged habitats on loamy sand, usually over an impervious laterite layer, in lowland conditions: the Worcester valley, and the flats between the Cape Peninsula and Wellington. Often in somewhat heavier soils, loams, but not seen in clayey soils.>
<Recorded from well-drained gravelly or sandy soils, often forming an understory under other plants. The species is often recorded as being common.>
<Restricted to rock ledges on southern aspects, also somewhat off ledges on steep slopes, or rarely at the base of cliffs.>

<Plants forming small localized populations, often in rocky, sheltered places like scree slopes. One collection indicates a marshy habitat, and on the Nuweberg they are common in seepages. Above Betty's Bay the plants grow on the damp, black soils on south-facing slopes, mixed into the general vegetation.>
<Mostly recorded from among rocks and on ledges on cool, somewhat sheltered, south-facing slopes. On Jonaskop it may be locally common on ledges on south-facing cliffs.>

<On the Matroosberg massif (Sonklip, Matroosberg, Roodeberg) the species is very common above 1800 m. It is found on stony slopes, sandy plains, and shallow soils over bedrock. It appears to occur where other species are excluded: both on well-drained habitats, and in slight seepages over bedrock. Maybe the critical factor is not the soil environment, but competition from taller restios. On the summit plateau of Matroosberg peak \i{}I. pygmaea\i0{} is the only restioid in large areas in the very harsh environment, with larger tussocks of \i{}Staberoha remota\i0{}.>
<Damp localities, often near seeps. In the Du Toits Kloof mountains I have seen the species both on sloping seeps, and along the drier edges of a marsh on the Du Toits Kloof Suurvlakte.>

<Restricted to "Tertiary" sands, along coastal dunes in the southern Cape Peninsula, acidic fynbos at Malmesbury, Yzerfontein and Kenilworth Race Course. The species is found both on well-drained sands and slight seepages.>

<Most common on south-facing slopes, often slightly concave, at low to mid-altitudes, usually pebbly but not too rocky, often forming extensive stands. Also quite common in other habitats, but always well-drained. Well protected, and although with a restricted range, not in any danger of extinction.>
<Locally frequent in marshy or seepage spots, as well as on rock flushes. Rarely locally dominant, more commonly as occasional plants in the general vegetation.>

<Recorded from heathy vegetation on the mountain slopes. At Tierberg on the Great Swartberg I saw it growing in short fynbos along the summit ridges, and on the Witteberg on the south-facing slopes at and below the summits. From Keeromsberg it has been recorded from gullies. There seems to be no indication of a preference for seepages and rockledges.>

<Most populations are found in sandy localities with impeded drainage, which are waterlogged or at least damp during winter. I have seen a number of populations throughout the range that fit this definition. It is possible that the few montane populations are in similar conditions, possibly on coastal sand blown into the mountains. A second peculiarity is the shortage of male plants, and in several populations only females have been recorded. The possibility of apomixis should be investigated.>
<Locally dominant along seasonal streams on sandy suurvlakte plains, plants forming extensive mats, which appear to be a tangle of many different plants, as the sexes are well mixed.>
<Generally found in damp sand over rock, where there are slight seepages. Mostly in quite loamy soils. Excellent population at Kliphuis in damp loamy sand in seasonal seepage.>

<Occasional on well-drained, exposed, rocky or stony slopes. The species does not seem to form populations, and avoids seepages or shady rock ledges. It is found most frequently on dry, stony slopes.>
<Locally common in crevices and cracks in rugged rocks on the southern flanks of the mountain.>
<Restricted to habitats which are waterlogged in winter, often growing partially submerged in water>

<All records are from moist places: along seasonal streams, in cleared spaces (firebreaks, along roads), local among rocks, and on the south slopes below higher peaks. The species is very common on the upper parts of Table Mountain (Cape Town).>
<This species is found on rock ledges and in seeps, occurring where there is some moisture available, sometimes growing in moss, often in the vicinity of waterfalls.>
<Locally common (dominant) in valley bottom seep (marsh really) on south side of main peak of Caledon Swartberg \par{}>
<Local on damp moist slopes, in full sunlight or in lightly shaded habitats, also along stream margins in riverine forest.>
<All collections from from montane grassland, often near seeps, near the edge of small pools, or on shallow soils near the edge of cliffs.>
<Very common on wet south-facing slopes, in black peaty soils. Plants forming part of the generally tangled vegetation.>
<Common along upper among rocks and in cool cliffs at higher altitudes, often the dominant in dense south-facing fynbos.>
<Locally common on shallow sand over sandstone outcrops and among sandstone ridges.>

<This species often dominates vegetation in the first years after fire, thus it appears to be stimulated by fire. It is generally found among stones and rocks, or on stony slopes. It is much rarer on sandy plains or "vlaktes", where it is replaced by the segregate species \i{}Resetio unispicatus\i0{}. In the Matroosberg area it is very common at the northern base on shales and sandstones, often being locally dominant.>
<The collections all appear to be from well-drained habitats, but the soil varies from sandy to stony or rocky. Most collections are also from exposed habitats.>
<On ledges, in gullies, at bases of rocks, and in recesses in rocks on the very rugged summits of these peaks, and generally on the south facing slopes.>
<From sandy, rarely clayey soils, usually deep sand, but occasionally with rock. The habitats appear to be well drained, not waterlogged in winter, but this may not be generally true.>

<Generally recorded from wet habitats: marshy streambanks, marshy slopes, marshes, dripping ledges, marshes on wet soil. In these habitats the plants are described as forming dense masses, which suggests that they are part of the typical marsh flora.>

<I have observed this species on rocky summit ridges, often exposed to south-easterly cloud, thus on steep south-facing slopes, among rocks, where it often forming tangled mats. This seems to fit most fieldnotes, as well. This might account for the enormous range in the species, as plants growing in shadier places might be lankier, than those in more exposed places.>

<Most of the herbarium labels mention a habitat in slight seeps or heavier soils; but I have also seen the species on well-drained stony slopes on Pilaarkop. It is absent from the higher-rainfall areas closer to the coast.>

<The plants are most common where there is some ground-water, either along stream-lines, watercourses, or seepages. Where conditions are suitable it may become locally dominant, both on sandy plateaux, and on stony mountain slopes. It is a very common element in the southern Cederberg, rarely dominant, but widespread in most available habitats.>
<This species is restricted to wet areas: wet area near stream, very wet marshes on level areas, or marshy stream sides.>

<One of the few restio species that can tolerate some shade, this species is typical of streamlines, where it receives some groundwater throughout the year, and is often found along the margins of the riverine scrub-forest. It is also found along the rubble and lower valley sides in the Kogelberg, where it forms either large isolated clumps, of clusters of plants.>

<This is a lowland species, mostly found on somewhat richer soils. All populations observed are in seepages, in damp hollows, or near streams. Some populations, such as the ones next to the University of Cape Town campus, are in very slight seepages, while others, in drier habitats, require strong seepages.>

<Locally common on well-drained soils, sometimes over laterite, usually on sandstone. It can form an important part of the restioid flora in some parts. Seems to avoid seasonal waterlogging. Soils notes refer to sandy, stony soils, to compact sands, and to sandy hollows.>

<Widespread in damp sand, along streams or in seepages, often in shallow soil over rock. It can often be very common, forming monospecific populations in moss beds in seepages, or growing under other restios in seepages.>

<This seems to be a "silcrete" species, restricted to heavier soils either along the silcrete pediments of the Langeberg, Outeniqua and other southern mountains, or along the gravelly shaley or silcrete derived soils of the Bredasdorp plains. The species is often associated with renosterbos.>

<One of the commonest restioid species of the lower slopes and lowlands in the southern part of the Cape Floristic Region. The species is found on well-drained slopes, generally on stony or gravelly soils. Occasionally it also occurs in slight seepages. It never seems to form monospecific stands, but occurs mixed with the rest of the vegetation - typical of a resprouting restioid. In the Great Swartberg the species ascends to the middle slopes of the mountains, otherwise it rarely seems to exceed an altitude of 500 m.>

<Local in dry fynbos. On Gifberg found in taller vegetation by rock ledges on South-facing slopes, whilst in the Cederberg it is very common on west-facing hot dry slopes above Algeria. It is often the dominant restio under \i{}Widdringtonia cederbergensis\i0{} stands, where it grows in half-shade, but also occurs outside the stands on rocky slopes.>
<Found in marshes with \i{}Anthochortus ecklonii\i0{}. In one marsh the species is dominant.>

<This species is common on dry slopes, and often dominant on the seasonally waterlogged sandy plains or "vlaktes". It avoids streams, seepages and rocky slopes. It is probably the single most characteristic restioid of the typical sandstone mountain "suurvlaktes", which are mostly deep-sand habitats, waterlogged in winter and very dry in summer.>

<Mostly restricted to areas amoung huge boulders. The plants often fill the gullys and passages among the rocks, and the species seems to be able to grow on the cold, shady south sides of these typical gaint sandstone blocks. Most of the populations will regularly receive snow, and at least some will be snow-covered from several weeks, due to the micro-habitat. Thus it is often dominant on the rocky summits of some Cape mountains.>
<South facing slopes receiving sea-air, growing dispersed in the vegetation on well-drained slopes. Often among rocks in fire-protected habitats, but also on open slopes.>
<Found on somewhat marshy ground on a shale band, and in seepage areas above a rather wet marsh.>

<Locally common to very common, often forming a springy mat understory under other plants, on sandplains. Several records indicate a slightly moister habitat, but I have seen it in the Kogelberg on well-drained sandy flats, forming the most common understorey restioid.>

<Locally common among granitic rocks. Forms extensive stands along streamlines on deeper loamy soils, possibly where there is some groundwater in winter. While the populations on Sneeukop were associated with seepages, those on Kamiesberg were not.>
<Very local on stony sand and in sparse low bush, might be a short-lived post-fire species.>

<Common in dry fynbos, often on stony well-drained soils, along the arid inland margins of the fold mountains. The species is typical of hot, exposed habitats, in well-drained conditions, often without any shelter which would allow other species to persist. It also occurs, albeit as a morphologically rather different form, on the West Coast sandveld.>

<This species is generally found on dry, exposed slopes, often quite stony. It is particularly common to locally dominant on the upper slopes, above 1500 m, and may be the most common species in this habitat.>

<Found mostly along permanent streams, where the plants are found in sandbanks, or in cracks in bedrock or rock paving. The plants are usually within the flood zone, and persist by remarkably tough bases. The species may be locally quite common, but also seems to consists of rather few, isolated populations. From herbarium records it appears that some collections come from valley bottoms, where they seem to form extensive stands. This seems to be the only Restionaceae species that regularly occurs in streambeds.>

<Very common on well-drained stony slopes, often the dominant species, sharing the habitat with \i{}Cannomois nitida\i0{}. The species is found on the summit ridge and the upper south-facing slopes, but is absent from the north-facing slopes. On Roodeberg it is found on the harsh, dry west-facing slopes.>
<Locally common in seasonally waterlogged areas. At Malangeni it is recorded from black soil at the edge of the swamp forest, from seasonally inundated soil.>

<The species is found both on granites and sandstones, and seems frequent on gravelly soils. Several records indicate shallow soils over rock, in places where otherwise bare patches would occur. Also recorded from around ant heaps, and on rock flushes. Collected in the Rivierzondereinde mountains from a well drained, pebbly slope, in an area where a pine infestation had been cleared.>
<An alpine species, found only on the summit ridges of the Swartberg. The plants grow in well-drained habitats, very exposed, in stony soil. They seem to be absent from cliffs and shady habitats.>

<Restricted to sandstone outcrops in the very arid fynbos on the low hills and lower slopes, in well drained localities. The species is often locally dominant, forming extensive and quite dense populations. However, it can also occur as scattered individuals.>

<A widespread species of the arid inland margins of the Cape ranges, generally in areas of low rainfall. The species is most often found in damp localities, in loamy soils along streams or in seeps, or in shallow soils over rock, in western Cape in deep colluvial soils, somewhat richer than Table Mountain sandstone. Towards the east, the species is typical of quartzite outcrops.>

<A relatively common species in the mesic fynbos typical of the south-facing slopes and cool valleys of the Langeberg. The species is found generally in well-drained habitats, often on shale bands, and often associated with occasional rock outcrops. It does not form large populations, occurring more as isolated plants.>

<This is one of the most widespread restionaceous species in South Africa. In the winter-rainfall areas it is associated with dry fynbos at lower altitudes, often in very dry habitats. It is generally found on gravelly soils, derived either from sandstone or laterites. This is particularly striking in the western parts of its distribution range. Towards the east it is more associated with Witteberg quartzites and sandstones. In the Drakensberg the species is found on Cape Sandstone outcrops. It appears to thrive in over-grazed areas, particularly around Grahamstown.>

<A species of mesic fynbos, found on deeper soils usually, on the wet coastal slopes of the mountains. It is a typical element of this dense vegetation, the tall plants often overtopping the other species and making a spectacular display. There is a report of at least the male inflorescences being eaten by elephant (pers com G. Patterson, 6 Nov. 2001)>

<The species is typically found on moist, loamy soils, where there are slight seepages. On Robinson Pass it grows along a jeep road in very shallow loamy sand over bedrock, possibly waterlogged with rain and very dry in summer, and regularly disturbed. It is absent from the general dense vegetation typical of deeper soils, and so seems to be localised in areas where the general vegetation is not able to grow. It is also locally dominant on small cliffs, in the shallow soil over the bedrock, and in slight seepages. From the Rooiberg Hugh Taylor recorded it from "On bed rock of ridge".>
<Common on rocky slopes, especially where bedrock crops out, absent from sandy plains, occasional to absent from gravelly slopes. Always in well-drained habitats.>

<Along streams and in marshy places, often on shale bands or slightly heavier soils. Occurring as large, isolated clumps, rarely forming dense stands. Often associated with the sedge-grass vegetation of deep soils on shale bands. On Kogelberg summit it is a very common understory restioid, forming extensive mats.>

<An alpine species, forms relatively dense local patches on plains, both sandy and somewhat gravelly, and on gentle slopes, a very striking species. In the Northern Cederberg it is a common element on the seasonally arid sandplains around Heuningvlei.>
<Locally common on well-drained, usually stony sandy soils. Often forms quite dense and extensive stands.>
<Well-drained slopes, in Swartberg common in mesic upper south-facing vegetation, quite diverse in its habitat, while in the Langeberg it is found on the dry inland base of the mountains.>
<Common on dry sandy habitats, well-drained. Often forming small populations, but never forming extensive stands.>
<Well-drained sandy slopes>
<Common on `suur- vlaktes' in the Ceres - Cederberg area, where it grows in well-drained habitats. It can be locally quite common, possibly even dominant.>

<Most collections indicate a marshy or peaty habitat on small sandy plains, or also from rocky areas on shale bands. Winter waterlogging appears to be typical for this species. On Matroosberg the species is very common above 1900 m, occurring in all rocky habitats, but absent from seepages or deep sandy plains. It is, with \i{}Restio pygmaeus\i0{}, the dominant restioid on the bleak summit plateau of Matroosberg peak. Below 1900 m the species is found in a few seeps at the lower margins of shale bands.>

<Restricted to south-facing ledges on the upper rocky peaks, absent from deeper soil around the cliffs, and from the summits of the ridges and the north-facing slopes. These cliffs intercept substantial cloud drifting in from the Indian Ocean, and also substantial snow and ice in winter. The species is locally very common, restricted to these fire refuges.>
<Moderately drained scrubby fynbos, often among rocks near seeps, often only a few plants>

<Locally common or rare (usually the latter) on well-drained soils. The plants have been seen either as isolated individuals on rocky slopes, or as small populations on sandy plains. It appears to avoid seepages and damp habitats.>
<Known from well-drained, gravelly slopes and alluvial fans at the Northern base of the Langeberg.>
<Mostly collected from sandy slopes, well drained or slightly damp. It does not appear to occur on stony slopes.>

<Often common on sandy flats, in well-drained localities, on deep sand. Often co-occurs with \i{}T. punctatus\i0{}, but flowers some months later. Together with \i{}W. incurvata\i0{} it can be regarded as a typical sandveld restio. The few mountain occurrences deserve some more investigation.>

<Found in a wide range of conditions, from well-drained soils to seepages and stream-margins, and even in light shade under riverine woodland. On the whole, the plants require a good water supply in summer - either from streams and seeps, or from substantial summer rain and fog. It is one of the most common species on the south-facing slopes of the Langeberg - Outeniqua - Tzitzikamma fynbos, usually occurring as scattered individuals.>
<This species seems to be locally abundant, mostly in sandy areas which might be seasonally wet. One collection is from near the margins of wet hollows. Others refer to stony sand.>
<This species grows in dry fynbos along N slopes of Langeberg. The collections are from well-drained gravelly soils on sandstone.>
<The species is found in well-drained soils, from coastal dunes inland to coastal sand blown over sandstone bedrock.>

<This species is locally common on well-drained limestone slopes and pavement. Usually with short vegetation, and locally dominating the vegetation. Some records indicate a mixture of sandstone and limestone, but the whole distribution seems to be restricted to lime-stone outcrops, suggesting that our species is a calciphile.>

<Widespread on sandy slopes, more rare on stony slopes. This species is found both in marshy areas, as well as well-drained habitats. It ranges from near sea level, to mid-altitudes on the inland mountains. It ranges from fairly wet mountains (like Bainskloof), to the arid fringes of fynbos on Touwsberg and Slypsteenberg. Although most records are from sandstone, there are also indications that it can also grow in loamier conditions.>
<Typically found on grassy bluffs overlooking the sea, often with other fynbos outliers. In the Humansdorp area it is on deep coastal sand and sanddunes, no rock. Probably quite alkaline.>

<This species is common on well-drained soils, and often seems to prefer sandy soils. However, there are also collections from very rocky places (ledges along the Left Face route up the North Wall of Table Mountain). I have not seen the species in seasonally waterlogged or damp habitats.>

<This species is typically found in gravelly soils on low hills and along the bases of the mountains. These could be derived from laterites or sandstone gravel, or granite. It occurs in well-drained conditions, and may at times become quite common. It appears to respond well to light disturbance, and becomes common in grazed areas.>

<The natural habitat of the species is on well-drained sands, generally found in dune slacks or on somewhat loamier conditions along the inland margins of the dunes. The species will naturally form quite extensive stands, but veld management is used to make these stands much denser. It is rarely found directly on limestone (and then the plants usually look rather poor), but more commonly on deeper sands, probably derived from the limestones.>

<An aridity-loving species, found in very dry fynbos along the northern (inland) base of Langeberg, as well as on the Little Karoo mountains. The species is only found in well-drained habitats, where it can be locally common to dominant, sometimes forming almost monospecific stands.>
<Deep red sandy soils in river valley, disturbed vegetation with Protea repens, Leucadendron salignum, Elytropappus rhinocerotis, Aristida sp.>

<This species is restricted to south-facing slopes, where it is found in cool moist habitats. It is most common on ledges, often partially pendent on the ledges, and usually occurs tangled in other vegetation.>
<Widespread on sandstone slopes in the Western Cape, this is a common species of well-drained, stony mountain slopes. It is absent from sandy plains and marshy places.>
<A species of deep sand habitats in limestone country, but not necessarily on limestone. It seems to be an early succession plant, found in abandoned fields. It is ecologically rather poorly known.>

<One of the dominant species of the Upper Table on Table Mountain. The species grows in shallow soil over bedrock, in a habitat which is often waterlogged, especially when the south-easter clouds lie over the mountain. The plants are effective in trapping moisture from the clouds, as is evidenced from the moss-beds at the base of the plants. The area is often waterlogged in winter, and if there is a prolonged period in summer without a south-easter cloud, can become very dry. The species avoids the wetter waterlogged areas, which are mostly dominated by \i{}Restio bifidus\i0{}.>

<Almost all records are from deep sand. This seems always to be of coastal origin, and where the species is found on Table Mountain Sandstone, it grows in sand which might have been blown in. It is found in well-drained habitats, and often forms a sparse understory under other fynbos species, and in gaps between other species. There is an excellent series of collections by Elsie Esterhuysen from the southern Peninsula documenting the phenology and habitat of the species. The species seems to consist of isolated and rather scattered individuals, but each occupies a considerable area, spreading by means of its formidable rhizome.>
<A species restricted to well-drained slopes, usually over limestone pavement. This is a bleak, exposed habitat, and \i{}T. paniculatus\i0{} is often the only species there.>

<This high-altitude species is found in well-drained habitats in stony places, or in shallow, stony soil over rock. It is absent from steep south facing slopes or rock ledges. It is quite common along the upper slopes, often dominant in suitable habitats.>

<\i{}Thamnochortus pellucidus\i0{} is generally found in well-drained sand, occasionally slightly more peaty conditions. It seems to prefer loose sand, and I have seen it on road verges in very loose sand, and one of the herbarium records also indicates windblown sand as a habitat. It often forms small populations. The interval between Kleinmond and Pearly Beach is curious, since suitable habitat should occur in the Walker Bay area, but maybe this large sandy plain has not been adequately botanised.>
<Locally common in arid fynbos, usually on sandy soils or open areas, less common among rock outcrops. Often forming small local stands.>

<This is a limestone endemic, only recorded from lime-stone pavement, with the plants growing in cracks in the limestone bedrock. Found only in well-drained habitats, rather exposed and harsh. The species tends to be locally common or even dominant.>
<Scattered on deeper, well-drained sand in Riverlands>
<This is a common species on well drained slopes, often somewhat stony. In altititude it ranges from near sea level to the middle reaches of the hills.>

<Locally common, but never dominant, on acidic coastal sand plains, often spreading into disturbed areas. The plants are particularly common along roads, and their striking golden inflorescences in autumn are distinctive. The species avoids wetter areas, and may often co-occur with \i{}T. bachmannii\i0{}.>
<A species of well-drained slopes, often on stony or rocky soils and in exposed habitats. It is associated with arid fynbos, at higher altitudes, also co-occurs with renosterbos on rubble.>

<A common species on sandy, well-drained plains, it is often locally common to locally dominant on some sandy areas. It is found only on the arid inland margins of the mountains. The typical form of \i{}T. schlechteri\i0{} is found at the summit of Matroosberg in harsh alpine conditions.>

<This species is restricted to well-drained, deep coastal sand. It is one of the few Restionaceae found in "strandveld", a vegetation of largely tropical woody species, found in the more alkaline recent sands along the sea front. The species is locally common in the thickets, with its tall growth it can compete directly with the shrubs.>

<This species has been collected most commonly from alluvial / sandy plains or river valleys along the pediments of the mountains, or on lower plateaux: typically where large mountain streams exit from the mountains, forming broad flat sandy valleys. Rather fewer collections are from sandy or gravelly plateaux, such as Silvermine on the Cape Peninsula, and Avontuur on Piketberg. Rather fewer collections are from clayey lower mountains slopes. Generally the species occurs as isolated plants, not forming dense stands. The plants appear to be clonal, and can form fairly extensive patches.>
<Quite common on well-drained, stony slopes, with the plants forming small populations, but not widespread.>
<The ecology of this species is unknown - there is both granite and sandstone in the area, but no seepages, so presumably the species grew on well-drained slopes.>

<This is a low-growing plant typical of well-drained sandy habitats. It is found on a diversity of bedrock types, usually in sandy soils. It is often found co-occurring with \i{}W. sulcata\i0{}, and is quite a common species. Common found on suurvlaktes>

<In dry fynbos on the inland slopes of the Langeberg, found at the base of the mountains on the interface to renosterveld. Growing in well-drained localities on TMS derived soils and rubble, often locally common.>

<Widespread on well-drained soils, from the wetter conditions on Table Mountain to the very arid fringe of fynbos along the inland slopes of the Cederberg. It is a common species, common in most areas, but rarely dominating the vegetation. In the northern mountains it is one of the more typical species of dry, well-drained stony slopes.>

<This species is generally associated with seepages or slight ground water. It is usually local in damp deep sand, often among rocks, appears to avoid dry areas. It is rather local over its wide distribution range.>

<This species is probably the most typical element of the "Sandveld", and as such is very common on deep, well-drained acidic sand along the length of the West Coast. It is found inland in similar conditions, where there is deep, often windblown sand in intermontane valleys, reaching its highest altitude in the Touwsriver area. It is absent from seepages, wet places, or shallow, rocky soils. It seems to be very good at colonising wind-blown places.>
<sandy disturbed habitat with many invasive species>
<Sandy flats, possibly somewhat damp in winter, at the base of the sandstone mountains. The plants appear to be clonal, and form large extensive clumps or carpets of a single sex.>

<This rare species is locally common on coarse sand, seasonally damp in winter. Along the Highlands Hiking Trail I have seen in quite common in the disturbed areas along the jeep road, and in the ditches were additional moisture was available.>

<A typical element of alpine restio veld, this species is restricted to well-drained habitats, often on stony soil or among rocks; it seems to be absent from sandy plains. It is often very common. Male inflorescences often attacked by galls; culms heavily damaged by grazing by \i{}Otomys karoensis\i0{}.>

<The plants vary from discrete tussocks to occupying large, clonal patches. In the Northern Cederberg this species is common on the sandy "vlaktes", where it is striking during the flowering time, while in the south-western mountains it is found on well-drained stony slopes. The plants are often "diffuse" with the above-ground culms well spaced.>
<This species is found in two distinct habitats: sandy plains along the coast, and inland on mountain slopes. Both are well-drained habitats.>

states: killed by fire, regenerating from seed
coppicing from the rhizome or base after fire
killed by fire, seed regeneration apparently poor or absent
characters.name: plants <fire-survival strategy>
seed dispersal mode <inferred from circumstantial observations>
<taxonomic notes>
data: <In only the type specimen are the outer tepals as long as the inner - all other specimens appear to have shorter outer tepals. Since the type is from a well-collected area, it may be assumed that the species is either polymorphic for this feature, or that the type is aberrant.>

<In the mountains around Bains Kloof and further south is a form which differs from the typical form\i{} \i0{}in the dehiscence pattern where locules 1 and 2 are infertile and only locule 3 produces a seed that is not dehisced but is kept in the capsule and whole flower falls off. It appears to be restricted to Bailey"s Peak, Steenboksberg, Matroosberg and Easter Peak in Bankoek Mts (eg \i{}Esterhuysen \i0{}31557).>

<This is part of the \i{}C. parviflora\i0{} complex. At Grootfontein two forms are present: this form, which has short rhizomes or none, is caespitose, and has obtuse to acute male bracts; and the long-rhizome form, which has long spreading rhizomes, the plants are clumped, the male bracts acuminate. The two forms do not flower at the same time: the long-rhizome form flowers earlier than the tussocky form. The two occur intermingled: there can be no doubt that they are separate species - the problem is more relating the other populations to these two forms, particularly the populations from the Piketberg.>

<Very close to "typical" \i{}Cannomois parviflora\i0{} from the sandstone mountains, as it shares the possession of a long rhizome. It differs in the plumper nut, and fewer female spikelets per culm, and the generally much lower reliance on seed for survival. The rhizomes are also longer, and the plants form lines, rather than shrubs. I am not yet sure whether this warrants recognition at specific level, but it certainly does at infraspecific level.>

<The single collection from Tulbagh is dubiously placed in this species - it differs in a much shorter perianth. This is need of further investigation, since the collection is some 50 km further north from the next nearest collection.>

<Contains variation in perianth length and culm thickness on an altitudinal scale. It is similar to \i{}C. aristata\i0{} by the aristate bracts, but differs by the caespitose growthform, and the bony bracts.>

<I have followed here the very narrow delimitation of the species, including only populations with spreading rhizomes and acuminate male bracts. This may not in the long run be possible to maintain, but this form and the tussocked, obtuse-bracted form co-occur at Grootfontein without any intermediates, and flowering at different times, suggesting that they are indeed distinct species. More difficult is the separation of the collections from the Piketberg, which also appear to constitute several species.>
<Distinctive by the persistent sheaths, and by the dominant pale-brown colour of the plants.>

<Similar to the common \i{}E. ebracteata\i0{}, but the spikelets have more flowers (2-4 instead of 2), and the flowers are bigger. This species is probably identical to \i{}E. marlothii\i0{}, and the two may well form a facies of \i{}E. ebracteata\i0{} that is found in fire-protected habitats, where the plants grow to a large size. The differences among these three species are not convincing.>
<This species is known from only the type collection, and has not been studied adequately to reveal relationships.>
<This species may not be correctly separated from \i{}E. racemosa\i0{}, and some plants can only be determined with some difficulty.>

<This is a very variable species. A caespitose form is separated from the form with long creeping rhizomes. The male inflorescences also vary - either consisting of a dense cluster of spikelets or a loose aggregation. There appears to be much variation in the degree of laceration of the tepals and bracts.>
<Allied to \i{}E. thyrsifera\i0{} and \i{}E. fenestrata\i0{} by the inflorescence, but the plants are caespitose, the tepals are more papillose, and the habitat differs.>
<This species is related to \i{}E. asperiflora\i0{} by the acuminate bracts and persistent sheaths, but can be separated by the absence of a rhizome, and the much more flattened culms.>

<The species, with its robust growthform and whorled branches, is highly distinctive and cannot be confused with any other species. There are two flowering seasons in this species: spring and autumn. In the Cederberg both flowering types appear to co-occur in the same marsh. The plants show a remarkable degree of variation, with higher-altitude plants generally short, less than 1 m tall, while lower altitude plants may grow to three meters.>

<Distinct by the weakly persisting sheaths, and the long spreading rhizomes, which result in large clumps forming. From the remaining short-culmed species \i{}E. coleura\i0{} is also distinct by the broad, papery tepals, that end in a broad membranous margin. In most other species the tepals are more rigid, more clearly keeled, and lack a membranous apical margin.>
<This species can immediately be recognised by its long-acuminate bracts and dark flowers.>
<Distinctive in \i{}Elegia\i0{} by the culms clustered on the slender, spreading rhizomes, as well as by the persistent sheaths with long mucros.>

<This is a segregate from \i{}E. asperiflora\i0{}, with which it shares the bracts longer than the flowers, and the persistent sheaths; differs by the adpressed rather than patent sheaths, the caespitose rather than spreading habit, and the densely globose inflorescences. The two forms co-occur in both localities seen, and are readily separated. However, it is not as easy to separate the herbarium material, and the exact boundaries between the two species still need investigation. For convenience sake, the two are listed separately here.>

<This is a very variable species, which most likely contains several distinct forms. These are: (a) a slender form, that is generally less than 50 cm tall, with slender culms adn small flowers. This appears to be most common along the coastal mountains, and seems to flower after Christmas (b) a robust form, to 2 m tall, with stout culms and large flowers. This forms massive tussocks on the inland mountains (\i{}E. marlothii\i0{} and \i{}E. aggregata\i0{}). In addition to this variation, the species is close to \i{}E. hookeriana\i0{}, which differs in its smaller flowers, more gracile habit, and maybe in flowering time.>
<This species is very close to \i{}E. tectorum\i0{}, from which it primarily differs in being bigger. However, both species co-occur in the West Coast, and no intermediate plants have been seen.>

<This species has been much confused with \i{}Elegia juncea\i0{}. \i{}E. juncea\i0{} is a rhizomatous species, which resprouts after fire, while \i{}E. equisetacea\i0{} is tufted, and reseeds after fire. In addition, \i{}E. equisetacea \i0{} has larger and more striking inflorescences, and the juvenile forms have whorled sterile branches at the nodes. In the past the presence of these branches was taken as diagnostic of the species, but they are not developed in more mature or older plants, which are then mis-identified as \i{}E. juncea.\i0{}>

<Related to \i{}E. juncea \i0{}and \i{}E. vaginulata\i0{} by the spreading rhizomes, but distinct by the large, solitary flowers in each spathe. It is also easily recognisable by the tightly wrapped around spathes in the female, completely obscuring the flower.>
<Distinct by the long spreading rhizome making clusters of flowers, similar to \i{}E. galpinii\i0{}, but different by the smaller plants.>
<This may be an aberrant form of \i{}E. asperiflora\i0{} or \i{}E. rigida\i0{}. It differs from these two species largely by the well-developed spathellae.>
<Close to \i{}Elegia thyrsifera\i0{}, but this is a gaint mat-forming plant with stout rhizomes, while \i{}E. thyrsifera\i0{} is caespitose with slender, short rhizomes.>

<A very variable species, possibly contains several distinct forms: caespitose plant from Baviaansberg flowers in October. The variation should be investigated: it includes very slender-culm species, as well as robust plants.>
<Unique in \i{}Elegia\i0{} by the hollow culms, the shape of the inflorescences, almost square in outline, is also distinctive.>
<A very distinct species, largely by the large spathes which turn red as the flowers mature.>

<A very distinctive species, not obviously related to any other species of \i{}Elegia\i0{}. The most striking features are firstly the growth-form, with spreading rhizomes with clusters of culms; and secondly the black, almost round flowers. The tall size of the plants makes them even more striking.>
<A very handsome plant, distinctive by its green-golden colour when in flower, and by the greenish spathes with yellow margins.>

<Distinct by the often rough culms, bluish in colour. These often feel rough when a fingernail is scratched over them. However, the species contains much variation, and the delimitation from \i{}E. intermedia\i0{} is dubious. This complex is in need of critical evaluation. Another variable is the habit. On Milner Vlakte the species is rhizomatous, plants spreading, while on the Du Toits Kloof suurvlakte they are very distinctly caespitose, with no rhizome developed at all.>
<Distinct among its relatives by the large nut, solitary flower, and habit.>
<Very close to the hyper-variable inland species \i{}E. grandispicata\i0{}, differs by the paler and thinner spathes. However, some collections can only be identified on geographical origin.>

<The species, as delimited here, is much narrower than delimited by Pillans, as the tall, reseeding form has been transferred to \i{}E. equisetacea\i0{}. However, even so there is still quite substantial variation in this species. It is not yet possible to unambiguously assign specimens lacking rhizomes to either species. Investigation of a larger sample of complete material might well indicate the presence / absence of spathellae can be used to distinguish between the two species.>
<The large one-flowered female spikelets are unique in the family. Associated with the peculiar rhizomes and branching culms, the species can always be diagnosed.>

<This species is probably identical to \i{}E. aggregata\i0{}, and the two may well form a facies of \i{}C. ebracteatum\i0{} that is found in fire-protected habitats, where the plants grow to a large size. The differences among these three species are not convincing.>
<Distinct in the genus \i{}Elegia\i0{} by the branching culms, the long creeping deep-seated rhizome, and the coastal sand habitat.>

<A very distinctive species. It is almost twice as big as any other species in \i{}Elegia\i0{}: the culms, sheaths, flowers, and tussock size are much bigger than the other species. It is not immediately evident what the closest relatives of this species are.>
<A very distinctive species.>

<A very distinct species, superficially somewhat similar to \i{}Elegia nuda\i0{} or \i{}E. tectorum\i0{}, but differs by the smaller flowers, the ovary with a single functioning locule and a nut, rather than a capsule. The long creeping rhizome is also quite unusual. I have not seen any male material.>

<A variable species, with two perianth forms, which Pillans recognised as distinct varieties. However, it seems unnecessary at this stage to name the perianth types as distinct forms. A member of Sect.\i{} Lamprocaulis \i0{} by its branching culms and persistent sheaths, but differs by the paired, stout styles with the free parts shorter than the stylopodium. It is most similar to \i{}E. prominens\i0{}, from which it differs by longer sheaths (30-60 mm vs. 10-15 mm), less branched culms, and longer perianth (2-4 mm vs. 1 mm).>

<Close to \i{}E. tectorum\i0{}, forming more or less cylindrical very dark inflorescences, and with small flowers, less than 3 mm long. However, the species is separated by the rough tepals with the midribs raised the full length, and by the better developed rhizomes.>

<Sharply distinct from \i{}Elegia racemosa\i0{} by the smaller flowers and rounded tepals with fimbriate margins. Difficult to tell apart on male plants or spikelets. Possibly also distinct by fire survival mode. Spathes golden-coloured when flowering, and plants so very distinct in the general vegetation.>

<Similar to \i{}E. neesii\i0{}, but distinct by the smaller inflorescences, and particularly by the perianth reduced to a very short skirt around the base of the flowers. In addition, the sheaths are shorter (10-15 mm vs. 30-60 mm long), and the culms are more branched. Ecologically the two species replace each other, with \i{}E. prominens\i0{} restricted to coastal sands, and \i{}E. neesii\i0{} to mountains and sandstone derived sands.>

<In its present circumscription a very variable species. It is possible that it might contain several segregates, but there appear to be no obvious characters by which these can be separated. I have separated Pillans's \i{}E. amoena\i0{} again, largely on the absence of rhizomes. \i{}E. persistens\i0{} similarly lacks rhizomes, but in addition also has much smaller perianths on the female flowers. The species has in the past been confused with adult forms of \i{}E. juncea.\i0{}>
<Distinctive by the spreading rhizomes, with clusters of culms at the nodes. Plants from Malmesbury look very different from those from Potberg.>

<Very closely related to \i{}E. spathacea\i0{}, and the boundary between the two species has not been resolved. The typical form differs from \i{}E. spathacea\i0{} by the much shorter female bracts, the obtuse to truncate tepals, often with a membranous upper margin, which are shorter than the fruit. This form is found in the northern mountains, around Groot Winterhoek and the Hex River. However, the collections from the Bainskloof area have slightly longer spathes, and the perianth is as in \i{}E. spathacea\i0{}. This form has in the past been separated as \i{}E. spathacea\i0{} var. \i{}attenuata\i0{}, and this might still be a useful solution. The problem with this solution is that the type of \i{}E. rigida\i0{} comes from Bainskloof, although it matches the typical form of the species exactly! No such plants have since been collected from Bainskloof. It can readily be distinguished from \i{}E. filacea\i0{} by the smaller flowers (perianth less than 1.5 mm long) and the tepals with rounded apices.>

<Very closely related to \i{}E. rigida\i0{}, from which it differs by the female bracts longer than 2 cm, and making an almost square, tower-like inflorescence. In addition, the tepals are acute, and overtop the fruit. The typical forms are relatively easy to distinguish, and are also allopatric. However, the material from the geographically intermediate area, around Bains Kloof, cannot be readily assigned to either species. Pillans separated this material as his var. \i{}attenuata\i0{}, and this might be a useful solution. Another possible solution might be three subspecies. The complex is in need of critical revision.>
<Related to \i{}E. verreauxii\i0{} by the small stature and rhizomatous growth, but is readily distinghished by the densely spaced culms on the rhizomes.>

<Part of sect. \i{}Lamprocaulis\i0{}, distinct by the persistent sheaths and branching culms. Within the section the species is separated by the much-branched habit and two slender styles. The population from Riverlands near Malmesbury (\i{}Esterhuysen 34630\i0{}) differs from the normal by the possession of spreading rhizomes. There are also other, difficult to quantify differences in the appearance, and this population could represent a distinct species.>

<Usually included in sect. \i{}Lamprocaulis\i0{}, but probably erroneously so. It seems to be more closely related to \i{}E. filacea\i0{}, but occasionally the culms do branch. In the field it is immediately distinct by the colour and morphology of the inflorescences.>

<A commonly cultivated species (but rather rarer in nature), with cylindrical dark inflorescences and flowers less than 3 mm long. It is close to \i{}E. nuda,\i0{}but differs by the tepals without ornamentation, and the stouter culms. On the West Coast, it is replaced by \i{}C. elephantina\i0{}, from which it differs by the smaller stature.>

<This species may be very close to \i{}E. grandispicata\i0{}, but differs by the looping rhizomes and the green rather than blue colour of the culms. The plants also spread, and do not form tightly defined tussocks like in \i{}E. grandispicata\i0{}. In growthform the plants approach \i{}E. fenestrata\i0{}, but the latter is a low-altitude species. Shares the trigonous ribbed to winged fruit with \i{}E. fenestrata, \i0{} and also the general measurements fit here. Similar to \i{}E. fenestrata\i0{}, but differs by the acuminate tepals and winged nutlets, as well as the absence of rhizomes. This is a caespitose plant, \i{}E. fenestrata \i0{}is a gaint mat-forming plant. These is substantial variation in the size of the female flowers, with the flowers of the eastern populations at Garcias Pass almost twice as big as those from the Cape Peninsula. The pattern in this variation has not yet been explored.>
<Distinctive species, allied to the \i{}E. racemosa\i0{} complex. However, the large size and cylindrical inflorescences are typical.>
<The material from east of Garcias Pass is more robust, and may represent a distinct species.>
<Distinctive among the species of \i{}Elegia \i0{}by the clumped culms along the rhizome. Closest probably to \i{}E. vaginulata\i0{}, from which it differs by the different type of rhizome.>
<This is probably a species of \i{}Anthochortus, \i0{}distinct by the white papery spikelets.>

<There is some variation in the species in the size and colouration, and apical shape, of the male bracts. This has in the past been recognised at varietal level. I do not think that there is sufficient pattern to justify formal recognition.>

<It is a very variable species, which might have geographical subspecies in it. The variation affects largely the size and colour of the spathes and bracts, as well as the size of the nuts. I have not yet investigated the species in detail to establish whether there is any pattern to the variation.>
<This species contains substantial variation in the degree of compression of the culms.>

<Readily distinguished by the cone-like, usually reflexed male spikelets. The plants are also distinct, with decumbent culms spreading from a very weak base. The species is easily separated from the other two species in the genus by the male spikelets.>

<The nuts covered in the perianth, and the somewhat reflexed male spikelets are typical of the genus. This species is distinct from other two species by erect caespitose habit and purple culm bases; it also has highly reduced petals, but this is very difficult to see since the flowers are difficult to dissect.>

<The nuts covered in the perianth, and the somewhat reflexed male spikelets are typical of the genus. \i{}M. spathulata\i0{} can be separated from \i{}M. digitata\i0{} by the shorter, ovate rather than oblong male spikelets. It is also allopatric, being found to the east of Bredasdorp. From \i{}M. purpurea\i0{} it is distinct by the decumbent growthform (\i{}M. purpurea\i0{} is erect), by the lack of purple colouring, and by the fully developed petals. However, the last two characters are difficult to use.>
<Distinctive by the elliptical, almost cone-like male spikelets. The females are very obscure, and usually only found after some searching, but the males are very visible.>
<Distinct from \i{}N. obtusissima\i0{} by the smaller male spikelets, and the female spikelets taller than the spathes.>
<Distinct among the species of \i{}Platycaulos\i0{} by the 4-6 mm long flowers, which are only about half as long as the bracts, and the unilocular ovaries.>

<Within \i{}P. anceps\i0{} there is some regional variation, with the collections from the Tzitzikammas with the sepals about 1/3 taller than the petals, while they are the same length in the Langeberg. The collections from Hermanus are rather divergent from the rest, in having single female spikelets, and smaller flowers generally. This might indeed constitute a separate entity.>

<This species is very distinctive in \i{}Platycaulos\i0{} by the huge size, and the almost round culms. However, it has the same sheaths, seed structure and spikelet structure as the other species in the genus.>

<Very close to \i{}P. anceps\i0{}, both species have strongly compressed culms, usually faintly papillose, with a distinct ribs, as well as 1-3 flowered female spikelets more or less enclosed in the spathes. The plants form dense mats. However, our species can be separated from \i{}P. anceps\i0{} by the possession of a bilocular ovary (\i{}P. anceps\i0{} has a unilocular ovary) and by villous lateral sepals (the lateral sepals of \i{}P. anceps\i0{} are glabrous). The whole plant is also somewhat more robust. I am, though, of the opinion that these characters do not hold, and the populations from Kogelberg are variable for locule number, and the indumentum on the tepal margins is very sparse.>

<Clearly a member of the genus \i{}Platycaulos \i0{}by the compressed culms, the green sheaths, and the construction of the spikelets. The large spikelets and robust plants ally it to \i{}P. major\i0{}, but it differs by the female spikelets, which are less than 2.5 cm long. \i{}Vlok 361\i0{} (BOL, Z) from the Blesberg (Great Swartberg) differs from the typical form by the smaller stature (0.5 m), the solitary male spikelets, and possibly most importantly by having only 2 styles.>

<Similar to \i{}P. subcompressus\i0{} in forming fine flattened culms, and a tangled undergrowth. It is distinct by the unilocular ovary, and by the male inflorescences with very numerous spikelets, and much branched.>

<There is substantial variation between the populations, documented by Linder (Kew Bulletin 41:99-106 (1986)). The species is very close to \i{}P. mlanjiensis, \i0{}from which it differs by the flowering season and growth-form.>
<This subspecies differs from subspecies \i{}mahonii \i0{}by the bisexual spikelets and clustered spikelets.>
<Still a poorly known species.>
<Very close to \i{}P. mahonii\i0{}, from which it differs by the caespitose habit, more numerous female spikelets, and earlier flowering time.>
<The species is a segregate from \i{}P. mahonii\i0{}, but it can be distinguished by the longer bracts, and the seed ornamentation. The two species are also geographically separated.>

<\i{}Calopsis adpressus\i0{} is close to \i{}R. calcicola\i0{}, but is distinguished by the sheaths which are closely rolled around the culm, and by the petals which are often taller than the sepals.>
<Very close to \i{}R. setiger\i0{} by the long awned floral bracts. Male plants can be separated by teh much larger spikelets and bracts.>
<Distinctive by the combination of loosely convoluted bracts, and dense, white tubercles on the culms. The detailed structure of the spikelets appears to be somewhat variable.>

<Distinct by the thick culms, long sheath shoulders and large female spikelets. In addition, both male and female inflorescences have a single spikelet. Possibly related to \i{}R. rarus\i0{} and \i{}R. dispar\i0{}.>
<The tightly convoluted sheath, with a wide membranous margin, and with a straight awn, associated this species with \i{}R. tenuispicatus\i0{}. It can be separated by the larger female spikelets.>

<The western populations of this species have only from the female material, and since it can be very common locally, these are presumably apomictic. The populations at De Hoop, though include both male and female material.>
<Distinctive by its very curly stems and tangled growth. Included in the \b{}Restio perplexus Group\b0{} by its tangled growthform, solitary spikelets.>
<The limits of the species may need investigation. It seems to be near \i{}R. vilis.\i0{}>
<Distinct by the sepals puberulous all over the backs, but also with the paniculate inflorescences.>

<A variable species with three distinct forms: material from the Cape Peninsula regarded as typical, then there is a small spikeletted form with reflexed bracts, and a large spikeletted form, both from the Caledon mountains. The herbarium sheet locality data does not help in indicating whether these forms are geographically or ecologically separate, or whether they co-occur, and the complex would benefit from detailed fieldwork. The species may be related to \i{}R. bifarius\i0{} on bract morphology, but this could be erroneous, and the affinities of the species are best regarded as unknown. I have included \i{}R. exilis\i0{} in this species. There seems no good reason for not doing so, since there are no clearcut characters.>

<A very variable species, distinct from \i{}R. praeacutus\i0{} by the compressed culms. It seems to contain too much variation, particularly in flowering time, habitat, and size of female flowers. Maybe a critical analysis of the species might result in subdivision.>

<This plant does not match any of the species currently known in Ischyrolepis. From the ecology and size a relationship to \i{}R. marlothii\i0{} is possible, but it differs by the absence of membranous shoulders on the sheaths and bracts. From most species of the red-styled group it differs by the acute, rather than truncate, bracts. We still need the male material and preferably a second collection to confirm the reality of this species.>

<Specimens from the lower slopes of the mountains in the Little Karoo have flowers about half the size of the rest of the species, and the flowers are much more hairy. It is possible that the Swartberg harbours a segregate species, this is still in need of investigation. Restio cymosus and R. brachiatus cannot be separated morphologically. This widespread species does have some geographical patterning, but the variation ranges from the different mountain blocks overlap substantially, making it impossible to assign specimens with any confidence to either of these two species.>
<This is a very handsome and striking species, readily identified by its large, bristly spikelets. The foveolate black bract cells clearly ally the species to the \i{}R. bolusii\i0{} complex.>
<The species is still poorly delimited, and is a member of the \i{}R. bolusii\i0{} group.>

<Closely related to \i{}I. cincinnata\i0{} and \i{}I. saxatilis\i0{} by the one-flowered spikelets, very curling terminal branchlets, and red stigmas. It differs by the perianth reduced to 4 tepals, and hte unilocular ovary, as well as by its distribution in the Overberg.>
<Distinct by the long awns.>

<Often with smut fungi in the female spikelets. The plants can be quite variable in growth-form, from a sprawling, untidy plant to a near erect tussock. After fire the plants may have quite dense vegetative shoots around the base. Distinctive by the recurved bracts and the membranous bract margins. Plants from the Klein River Mountains and from Salmonsdam are much larger than the typical form, and approach \i{}R. ocreatus\i0{}.>

<Undoubtedly very near \i{}R. perplexus\i0{}, with the same isolated spikelets with bracts with broad membranous margins. Pillans (1928) distinguished it from \i{}R. perplexus\i0{} by "stems filiform; branches usually capillary" compared to "stems slender; branches usually filiform" for \i{}R. patens \i0{}and \i{}R. perplexus\i0{}.>

<This species was previously included under \i{}I. ocreata\i0{}, but it differs by the slender culms, and much smaller spikelets. On Gabrielspass the two species co-occur, without intermediates. Our species has finer culms and smaller spikelets, and forms lower, more tangled plants, while \i{}I. ocreata \i0{}is much stouter, with larger spikelets, and a more erect growth-form.>

<This species has three disjunct populations, which appear to differ somewhat in ecology. The Hermanus population has finer culms than the other two populations, but the spikelet morphology appears to be identical to the other two populations. I have not seen seed from the Hermanus population. My impression is that there should be separate species, but the morphology is not backing this up.>

<\i{}Restio clandestinus\i0{} is related to \i{}C. pulcher,\i0{} both of which have the characteristically upper half of bracts and sheaths membranous, and the lax spikelets. However, \i{}R. cladestinus \i0{}can be distinguished from \i{}R. pulcher\i0{} by its glabrous flowers, and the similarity between male and female spikelets.>

<Rather poorly known species, which could be confused with \i{}R. curviramis\i0{}, but from which it differs by the 1-2 rather large spikelets, and the woolly sheaths. It is also close to \i{}R. unispicatus\i0{}, but differs from this species by the awned bracts and sheaths, as well as the caespitose growth-form.>

<Superficially similar to \i{}R. fragilis\i0{}, sharing with it the habit, single-flowered spikelets, unilocular ovary and glabrous lateral sepals. However, \i{}R. colliculospermus\i0{} can be distinguished from \i{}R. fragilis \i0{}by the spathes which are shorter than the spikelets, and by the colliculate seed.>
<The geographical variation in the species is in need of investigation: there could be a change across the Breede River valley.>

<The plants from the Swartberg are generally smaller, with smaller flowers, and a more slender growth-form. It is possible that these could be segregated taxonomically from the plants from the main part of the distribution range. The fire biology of the plants on the western mountain summits should be investigated: maybe that is the reseeding form.>

<Close to \i{}R. nanus, \i0{}but the spikelets are often finer and the culms more slender. It can also be confused with \i{}I. duthieae\i0{}, but the latter has numerous female spikelets on the terminal branchlets, compared to the single spikelet for \i{}R. curviramis\i0{}. It is also similar in inflorescence structure to \i{}R. sporadicus\i0{}, but differs by the larger spikelets, and the more straight culms.>

<The affinities of \i{}R. debilis\i0{} are still obscure. The species is variable, particularly in the size of the plants, and the degree of development of the sheaths. Pillans (1928, p. 237) separated these larger forms as var. \i{}subulata. \i0{}There is no obvious geographical pattern to this variation, and superficial investigation suggests that there are intermediate forms.>

<A typical member of the fine, tangled Restionaceae, with single flowered spikelets, and with the ovary reduced to a single locule. Among the distinctive features of this species is the roughly papillose culm, the sheaths with tall membranous shoulders and a clavate mucro, and the glabrous flowers.>

<The current circumscription of this species is somewhat broad. Several further elements have in the past been included in it, these are here excluded. It is clearly a member of the \i{}Restio fragilis\i0{} group.>
<Related to the \i{}R. fragilis\i0{} group by the few-flowered spikelets, unilocular ovary, and tangled growth. It is rather exception in this group by the bracts without membranous margins.>

<This species is probably related to the \i{}Restio \i0{}species with winged flowers, such as \i{}R. hyalinus\i0{} and \i{}R. impolitus\i0{}. These also share the bracts with the broad membranous margins.>
<A very distinctive species with its broad membranous shoulders.>

<This taxon hardly differs from var. \i{}dodii\i0{}, except in the characters already mentioned by Pillans in 1928: the more purple spathes, large female flowers, and generally larger female inflorescences. There are also small differences in the growth-form and general habit of the plants. These differences may be enough for geographical subspecies, but certainly not for species recognition.>

<The spreading sheaths and general habit suggest a relationship to \i{}Calopsis viminea\i0{}. Our species is, however, immediately distinct by the single-flowered spikelets, and the very short female spathes.>
<Distinctive by the numerous female spikelets arranged along the terminal culms. In addition, many populations appear to consist only of females.>

<Probably related to \i{}Restio saroclados\i0{}: the bracts are much taller than the flowers, and the female flowers are oblique. There is substantial variation within the species in female flower size, but it is not clear whether this indicates any phylogenetic or geographical pattern.>

<Distinctive species by the long spreading rhizomes. It is most easily confused with \i{}C. microcarpa\i0{}, which has a similar growth-form, grows to a similar size, and occurs in the same sort of habitats.>

<Similar to \i{}R. karooicus\i0{}, with which it is sympatric. Both species have very roughly tuberculate culms, but \i{}R. esterhuyseniae\i0{} has a glabrous stylopodium, while that of \i{}R. karooicus\i0{} is pilose. The two species also differ dramatically in appearance. The other close relative is probably \i{}R. vilis\i0{} from the Kamiesberg, as was already noted by Pillans in 1945.>

<Only females known, despite extensive search. Related to the \i{}I. paludosus\i0{} complex, but distinct by the single style, the pilose style base, and by the culms branching prolifically just below the inflorescence.>

<Related to the \i{}R. bolusii\i0{} compex by the floral bracts with large areas of foveolate cells, and the densely villous sepal keels, but generally distinct by the smaller spikelets, and the neat tufted habit. The species has a very wide distribution, and substantial variation, which complicates the distinction from related species.>

<Near \i{}Restio colliculospermus\i0{}, but it can be distinguished by the spathes taller than the female spikelets, by the smooth seed, and by the fused style bases. It is allied to the \i{}R. decipiens\i0{} complex, which is delimited by the single-flowered male adn female spikelets, adn by the spathes overtopping the flowers, and the smooth shiny seeds with two concavities. It differs from \i{}R. decipiens \i0{}in the much more slender culms, the possibly smaller flowers.>

<The loosely convoluted sheaths relate this species to \i{}R. ocreatus \i0{}and \i{}R. elsiae\i0{}, as does the structure of the inflorecences. However, it differes in the less acuminate floral bracts. It seems not to co-occur with either of these two species, although \i{}R. elsiae\i0{} is geographically not far removed from it.>

<Pillans regarded \i{}R. fusiformis \i0{}as related to \i{}R. filiformis\i0{}, and differentiated them on the basis of thw bicoloured bracts and the winged outer lateral perianth segments of the female flower. However, there is also a close relationship to \i{}R. bifurcus,\i0{} but \i{}R. fusiformis \i0{}differs by the indumentum on the lateral sepals being fused into a keel, which is sometimes lacerated.>
