<Within the species there is substantial variation in the female spikelet, from a 1-2 flowered spikelet where the bracts are much shorter than the tepals, to a many-flowered spikelet where the bracts overtop the flowers. Possibly there are several entities in this species.>

<Distinct by the villous style bases. At least one population only female. The plants are enormously variable in their growthforms, with some caespitose populations (especially in the north) and other stoloniferous populations (especially towards the east). Often the bracts have long, erect, distinctive awns. The eastern populations could be constituted as a distinct species, by the different growthform.>
<Distinct by the slender, acute spikelets, and the stoloniferous growth-form.>

<There is some variation in the development of the awns on the bracts. This can lead to problems in the identification of female material, especially in the distinction from \i{}R. sieberi\i0{}. However, the males of the two species are quite distinct.>

<This species is related to \i{}R. intermedius\i0{} (Pillans) Linder and \i{}R. arcuatus\i0{} Mast. in the matted habit, the loosely convoluted sheaths with membranous apices, the glabrous flowers and the unilocular ovaries. The seed is similar to \i{}R. arcuatus\i0{}. It can be distinguished by the much smaller single-flowered female spikelets. The very distinctive clavate awns of \i{}R. implicatus\i0{} also occur in \i{}R. arcuatus\i0{}, but the culms of \i{}R. implicatus\i0{} are always straight.>

<Allied to \i{}R. triticeus\i0{} Rottb., although it lacks the dense tubercles on the culms typical of the \i{}R. triticeus\i0{} group. However, the seed morphology and spikelet construction is the same, giving the plants a very similar overall appearance. It is distinctive in this group by its spreading rhizomes and smooth culms.>

<\i{}Restio ingens\i0{} is related to \i{}R. communis\i0{} by the shiny seed, papery bracts, many-flowered spikelets and tuberculate culms. \i{}R. communis\i0{} is restricted to the Cape Peninsula and always has several spikelets and very stout awns on the sheaths. The plants are also smaller.>

<Very similar to \i{}R. esterhuyseniae\i0{}, from which it can be distinguished by the more numerous, lax, fewer-flowered male spikelets, by the pilose stylopodium and by the reticulate-foveolate testa. The growth-form of the plants is also quite different, not being tangled, but forming a neat branching plant.>

<This species is similar to \i{}R. distractus\i0{}, with the same thick, curly culms, more or less solitary spikelets, and woolly leaf axils. It is also found in the same alpine habitat. The two species differ as follows: (1) \i{}R. distractus\i0{} has a tuberculate culm; in \i{}R. laniger\i0{} it is smooth. (2) \i{}R. distractus\i0{} anthers are less than 2.2 mm long and brown; in \i{}R. laniger\i0{} they are more than 2.3 mm long and white. (3)\i{} R. distractus\i0{} culm colour is more blue; \i{}R. laniger \i0{}more green. There are also reported differences in fire survival strategy.>
<Distinct by the oblique flowers and extended internodes in the spikelets.>
<A very distinctive species, with its large growth-form. It is not immediately evident what its relatives are.>
<Very distinctive broadly membranous sheaths and coarsely tubercled culms.>
<Distinctive by the growthform, with whorled branches at the nodes.>
<Close to \i{}R. gaudichaudianus\i0{}, but the plants grow upright. This complex is in need of further study: the initial impression is that the two taxa should be recognised as distinct species.>

<Distinctive by the combination of the truncate sheaths and the large, curved male spikelets. Some variation in the size of the female spikelets. The individual female spikelets look like those of \i{}R. curviramis\i0{}, but there are several along the terminal inflorescence branches.>
<Very distinctive by the large solitary female spikelets and the long hyalines shoulders on the sheaths. Some specimens with 6 tepals.>
<Very distinctive by the ornamentation on the female bracts, as well as by the pendulous male spikelets.>

<Very similar in general to \i{}R. zuluensis\i0{}. The most striking difference is in the underground parts: \i{}R. zuluensis\i0{} has a very well developed rhizome, while \i{}R. pondoensis\i0{} spreads with culms.>
<Distinctive by the mostly single-flowered spikelets, with the long stylar-peg. The species as currently circumscribed is rather variable.>

<Very similar to \i{}Restio rudolfii\i0{}, and the distinction between these two species is dubious. On the currently delimitation the two species are allopatric, and \i{}R. muirii\i0{} differs from \i{}R. rudolfii\i0{} by: (a) the inflorescence of obconical, while in om \i{}R. rudolfii\i0{} it is linear and interrupted; (b) the male spikelets are much longer in \i{}R. muirii\i0{} than in om \i{}R. rudolfii.\i0{} The problem is that two collections, \i{}Esterhuysen 25931\i0{} from Touwsberg and \i{}Esterhuysen 17187\i0{} from Roodeberg are intermediate between the two species. As I do not wish to solve this problem here, I have included the two in \i{}R. muirii\i0{} (although not in the descriptive database). It seems most likely that \i{}R. muirii\i0{} is merely a somewhat aberrant southern extension of the more widespread \i{}R. rudolfii\i0{}. However, this would need careful study of the variation of the species on these Little Karoo mountains.>

<The form from the Bredasdorp plains differs from the Table mountain form by being caespitose,and not with spreading underground culms. The species is distinct by the ciliated bract margins. Very close to \i{}R. sejunctus\i0{}, see under that species for comparative comments.>

<A rather variable species, and poorly distinguished from \i{}R. curviramis\i0{}. I think that the complex needs further investigation. Variation effects culm colour, bract apex shape, the number of flowers per spikelet. Note that the plants from the summit plateau of Skerpioensberg have the correct seed morphology, and flower in autumn, not spring as documented. These are clearly distinct from the population at lower altitude: here typical \i{}R. curviramis\i0{} was very widespread and flowering in October, 2008.>

<This species contains much variation. The higher altitude forms have much smaller spikelets and flowers than the lower altitude, more coastal forms. However, all have a similar inflorescence construction, with several very distant spikelets, and often with curved spikelets. The flower construction is also identical within the species. The closest affinities are probably with the \i{}Restio pulcher\i0{} group, based on the bracts with a membranous apical half.>

<Related to \i{}Restio nodosus\i0{} and \i{}R. obscurus\i0{} by the triangular seed, the large oblong spikelets, and the numerous fertile female bracts per spikelet. It differs from \i{}R. nodosus\i0{} in its more tightly convoluted sheaths, the larger spikelets and the acute, rather than obtuse, bracts. In most of these characterss it approaches \i{}R. obscurus\i0{}, but it differs in the larger spikelets and the many-flowered female spikelets.>
<A distinctive species by the hanging spikelets. The affinities of the species are still unknown.>
<There is substantial variation in the species as defined here, particularly in the length of the female spikelets.>

<Clearly related to the \i{}R. bolusii\i0{} complex by the large, many-flowered compact cone-like spikelets, the densely villous large flowers, adn the colliculate, triangular seed, as well as the foveolate cells in the bracts. However, it can be distinguished by the acuminate bracts, which give the spikelets a bristly appearance. However, at least some populations of \i{}R. pachystachyus \i0{}complex cannot be confidently assigned to species.>

<Distinct by the swollen red culm bases, but it is very close to \i{}I. papillosa\i0{}, from which it can be separated by the male spikelets with more than one flower, by the straight culms, and colliculate seed.>

<The closests affinities appear to be with \i{}Restio tetragonus\i0{} and \i{}R. quadratus\i0{}, with which it shares a similar perianth and inflorescence structure, and also habitat. But it can always be distinguished by the round culms, and if seen, the indehiscent, unilocular ovaries.>

<This species is very close to \i{}R. paludosus\i0{}, but the slender growthform, and the swollen red culm bases. It is distinct from \i{}R. paludosus\i0{} by the single-flowered male spikelets in which the flowers are obscured by the bracts, by the flexuose culms, and by the papillose or tuberculate seed coat.>
<The affinities of this species remain enigmatic, and Pillans was also at a loss to assign relations to the species when he first described it.>

<The affinities of this species are not clear, but I suspect that it fits near \i{}I. sieberi\i0{}, by the seed surface morphology, seed shape, and general spikelet construction. It may also be of hybrid origin.>
<A very distinctive species, with the membranous bracts strongly dominating the appearance of the inflorescences.>
<Collections from the Cedarberg may constitute a distinct subspecies, distinct from the rest of the species by the acuminate bracts.>
<The collection from the Garcias Pass marsh may not belong here, since the material is quite old, and not really comparable.>
<A rather strange species, the affinities of which are still unclear.>
<Taxonomically rather poorly known, its affinities are with the \i{}R. bolusii\i0{} group.>
<Distinctive among its relatives by the large male spikelets (more than 10 mm long). The plants often form mats, due to well developed stolons, but exceptions often occur.>

<This species is very similar to the allopatric \i{}R. clandestinus\i0{}, and the most obvious difference is that in \i{}R. clandestinus\i0{} the female flowers are glabrous, while the keels of the lateral sepals are very distinctly puberulous or hairy in \i{}R. pulcher\i0{}. The two species share a similar lax spikelet structure, with bracts in which the upper half is membranous. They are probably most closely related to \i{}R. parcispiculus \i0{} and \i{}R. asperus\i0{}.>
<The affinities of this species are obscure, since seed characters show different alliances from spikelets.>

<Closely related to\i{} R. zwartbergensis\i0{} by the roughly tuberculate culms, 1-2 flowered female spikelets, and flowers longer than the bracts. It is distinct largely by the caespitose growthform, while \i{}R. zwartbergensis \i0{} has a more stoloniferous growth-form. This distinction is in need of critical evaluation.>
<The rather bristly looking spikelets, with acuminate recurved bracts, the small size of the spikelets, and the small tufted plants are distinctive.>
<Distinctive within \i{}Restio\i0{} by the solitary female spikelets, and the fine growth.>
<A distinctive species, I am not sure what its closest relatives would be.>

<Very close to \i{}R. vimineus\i0{}, and the distinction between these two entities needs further research. Appears to be based on the erect sheaths, rather than patent sheaths. In addition, the female spikelets are much more slender, the flowers more villous, and the female bracts more acuminate. Possibly \i{}R. vimineus\i0{} is associated with well-drained habitats, along the pediments and lower plateaux of the mountains, while our species is typical of the coastal forelands on seasonally waterlogged sands.>

<This species is very closely related to \i{}R. tenuissimus\i0{}, but the habit is quite different. \i{}R. tenuissimus\i0{} is tufted, whilst \i{}I. rivulus\i0{} forms tangled mats. In addition, the male spikelets are larger and more prominent, and the seed is smoother.>
<Distinctive by the spikelets very tightly rolled around the culms, so that the inflorescence diameter is scarcely more than that of the culm.>

<It is difficult to delimit this species from \i{}Restio vimineus\i0{}. Here I have assumed that the flowers are bigger, the plants more robust, and the inflorescences much bigger, and often interrupted. However, there are awkard specimens which are intermediate between the two species. And in particular, the situation on the Kamiesberg is unclear. The flowers are smaller than typical for \i{}R. rudolfii\i0{}, but the habit seems to fit here, rather than with the stoloniferous \i{}R. vimineus\i0{}. I have no doubt that we are dealing with two quite distinct species, but have not quite determined on a simple morphological way of separating the two. There is also some similarity to \i{}R. muirii\i0{}, but the easiest separation is on the inflorescence, which is interrupted in \i{}R. rudolfii\i0{}, but not so in \i{}R. muirii.\i0{} There are, however, intermediate from the Karoo mountains, suggesting that possibly \i{}R. muirii\i0{} should be regarded as a part of \i{}R. rudolfii\i0{}.>

<This species is probably closest to \i{}R. brachiatus\i0{} by the single flowered female spikelets, and the foveolate cells in the bract apices. However, they differ in seed morphology, with \i{}R. brachiatus\i0{} with smooth seed.>
<A strange species with spreading rhizomes which grows in water, especially in the winter months.>
<The long bracts, strongly rhizomatous growth, oblique flowers and smooth shiny seed allies this species to \i{}R. vallis-simius, R. ejuncidus\i0{} and \i{}R. corneolus.\i0{}>
<\i{}R. saxatilis\i0{} is related to \i{}R. cincinnatus\i0{} by the tangled growth-form and small few-flowered female spikelets, but differs by the habitat and the very different seed type.>

<\i{}Restio scaber \i0{}is still a mystery, and an effort should be made to re-collect it. It may be related to \i{}R. involutus\i0{}, from which differs by the obtuse female bracts, wider female petals, and adjacent style bases.>

<This species is rather variable in the relative lengths of flowers and bracts, the number of spikelets per inflorescence, and the degree of roughness of the culms. There is a weak geographical pattern to this variation. It might be worthwhile to re-investigate this complex to determine whether it is not possible to recognise segregates within the species, but a superficial investigation suggests that \i{}R. fourcadei\i0{} and \i{}R. scaberulus \i0{}cannot be separated.>

<I have used the species here in its most restricted sense, which excludes all collections from the Cape Floristic Region. The closest affinities are to \i{}R. constipatus\i0{}, which previously had been included in this species. The major differences is in size . . . this might not be justified. However, there is also quite a difference in growth-form.>

<Very close to \i{}R. multiflorus\i0{} by the oblong spikelets in branched inflorescences, and more particularly, in the shared possession of ciliate bract margins, but differing (according to Pillans) in that the flowers are much taller than their subtending bracts. In addition, the following characters might work: (1) flowering in Feb-May, rather than July-August; (2) floral bracts obtuse to acute, not acuminate; (3) individual inflorescence branches with few, rather than numerous, spikelets (but there could be more inflorescence branches); (4) female spikelets generally smaller.>

<Distinctive by the slender many-flowered spikelets with very long slender awns. This species is superficially similar to \i{}R. ocreatus\i0{} (from which it differs by the longer and more slender bract awns) and \i{}R. affines\i0{} (geographically separated). It is also similar to \i{}R. virgeus\i0{}, but is a much taller plant, and the male spikelets are much smaller and very much more numerous.>

<This is a very variable species. The var. \i{}venustulus\i0{} is treated as a separate species, although the variation within \i{}R. sieberi\i0{} would appear to be wide enough to include this variaty. Further research may well show that geographical forms can be separated. It is still acting as a dumping bag for forms which cannot be comfortably be placed elsewhere.>

<This species is near the \i{}Restio bolusii\i0{} complex, with bracts with hollow cells along the apical margins. The three-locular ovaries are unusual for the \i{}R. bolusii \i0{} complex. However, within the species there is substantial variation, which partitions more or less into montane and lowland facies. It is not at all certain that these two facies belong in the same species.>
<The species has no close relatives.>

<Very similar to \i{}R. curviramis\i0{} by the female spikelets occurring solitary scattered along the inflorescence (almost as if each spikelet is has its own subtending branch). However, \i{}R. sporadicus\i0{} is a more slender plant, with smaller spikelets, more slender and much more curved culms.>

<There is a very wide range in the morphology of this species, and it might repay further investigation to establish whether the species boundaries have been set correctly. In one form the culms are very richly branched: this variant is associated with ledges and cliffs in upper South-facing slopes. The second variant is more sparsely branched, and is more associated with steep peaty slopes. The species is close to \i{}Restio sejunctus\i0{}, from which it differs by the smaller spikelets, with fewer flowers.>

<Related to \i{}R. bolusii\i0{} by the cone-like spikelets, but differs by the size of the spikelets, and the acute spikelet apex. A remarkably handsome species, with striking spikelets. Very close, too, to \i{}R. insignis\i0{}.>
<Very distinctive by the clustered branches at the nodes, and the striking growth-form>
<This species seems to be quite distinct, despite earlier doubts about its existence.>
<Distinctive by the tiny, solitary female spikelets, and the tapering leaf-sheaths.>
<Distinct by the slender somewhat curved acute spikelets, and the frequent presence of "sterile" branches around the base of the plants.>
<There is some hint of geographical patterns of variation in the species, with plants from De Hoop showing spikelets more reminiscent of \i{}R. multiflorus\i0{}.>
<Newly found species, quite distinct by the lax inflorescence, single-flowered spikelets.>
<Distinctive by the blue colour of the culms, the single female spikelet, and the stoloniferous growth-form.>

<Although the spikelet structure is very similar to the hyper-variable (and probably too large) species \i{}I. sieberi\i0{}, the plants can always be distinguished by growth-form, by the woolly prophylls, and by the stouter culms and somewhat larger spikelets.>

<Related to \i{}R. sarocladus \i0{}by the smooth triangular seed, cartilaginous bracts without membranous margins, and the spreading stolons. However, it differs by the small spathes, and the less acute bracts, the larger number of spikelets, but particularly by the symmetrical flowers.>
<A very distinctive species, without any obvious relatives. The structure of the female flower has not yet been elucidated, nor the fruit.>
<Distinctive by the hemispherical shapes of the plants.>
<A very poorly know species, highly distinct by the dense while wool on the base of the female flowers.>

<This species is taxonomically most unsatisfactory. It is difficult to delimit from \i{}R. rudolfii.\i0{} I have worked on the assumption that our species is basically stoloniferous, while \i{}R. rudolfii\i0{} and the related \i{}R. muirii\i0{} as basically non-stoloniferous. This still needs extensive testing in the field, but it remains difficult to assign specimens to either of these two species. Ecologically it appears as if \i{}R. rudolfii\i0{}s a higher altitude plant than \i{}R. vimineus\i0{}. Secondly, the Sandveld forms of the species differ somewhat from the rest. I am not sure if there is any significance to this. Thirdly, the limits to \i{}R. rigoratus\i0{} are unclear. Clearly, a detailed analysis of the complex is called for.>
<Similar to \i{}R. schoenoides\i0{}, it differs in the single female spikelet, and the caespitose habit.>
<Very similar to \i{}R. paludosus\i0{}, which als has a rhizome, and seems to grow in similar habitats. But it can be separated by the female spikelets with more than 1 flower.>

<Close to\i{} R schoenoides\i0{}, differs by the smaller and densely compacted male spikelets, and more strikingly by the small distinct tussocks, without stolons or rhizomes. In addition, the plants are killed by fire. The other close affinity is to \i{}R. virgeus\i0{} from which it differs by the larger denser cluster of males, and the more numerous female spikelets. It is also very similar to \i{}R. constipatus\i0{}, but differs by the simple culms and caespitose habit.>
<This appears to be an isolated species, without any obvious affinities.>
<The affinities of this strange species are obscure.>
<There could be specimens intermediate to \i{}R. foliosus\i0{} from the Klein Karoo mountains.>
<\i{}R. fruticosa\i0{} still contains much variation, from small to robust plants.>
<Very distinctive by the pockmarked bracts and the dark colour of the bracts. In addition, the female flowers with recurved sepals, and the stipitate ovary are quite unique.>

<Klein Swartberg populations differ from the rest by the more slender female spikelets. The species is morphologically very close to \i{}S. banksii\i0{}, and specimens can be difficult to determine with confidence. The interface between the two species needs investigation.>

<This species is morphologically close to \i{}S. aemula\i0{}. According to the keys, \i{}S. banksii \i0{}has keeled flowers, while \i{}S. aemula\i0{} has winged flowers. However, these two characters are continuous, and it is possible that the real distinction is that \i{}S. banksii\i0{} is a lowland species from the Cape Peninsula\i{}, \i0{}while \i{}S. aemula\i0{} is an alpine species from the inland mountains.>
<Female tepals with finely lacerated or lobed margins.>
<Distinct in the genus by the spreading rhizomes, and in addition, the female spikelets as they ripen widen and acquire a distinct appearance.>
<Usually characterised by the several slender female spikelets, but this seems to be variable in field collections, and this species remains somewhat dubious.>
<Distinct in the genus by its lobed lateral sepals.>
<Very different from the other species in the genus by the darker sheaths and compact spikelets.>
<A rather peculiar species, that fits uncomfortably into \i{}Staberoha\i0{}, due to its erect male spikelets and single style.>
<Distinct in the genus by the perianth shorter than the fruit, flat; female spikelets several, slender>
<A very striking plant particularly by its disproportionally large silvery spikelets, and its very neat habit.>
<Flower size in \i{}T. arenarius\i0{} is somewhat variable, though, and the Peninsula plants mostly have flowers 2.5-3 mm long, while the plants from Hermanus may have flowers up to 4 mm long.>
<Distinctive by the longitudinal grooves on dried culms, but these are not always visible.>
<There is substantial variation within \i{}T. gracilis\i0{} in the degree of robustness of the culms.>
<There is much variation within this species, on which Pillans erected several species. These all intergrade.>

<\i{}Thamnochortus lucens\i0{} is frequently collected, and shows a wide range of variation in the size of the female spikelets, and the colour of the bracts. These are mostly dark, but in many collections can tend to being hyaline.>

<Within this species is a massive degree of variation, recognised in the past as three distinct species. Although most specimens can be placed to one of these species, investigation of population variation in the Cederberg and the Bonteberg suggests that all three species are found mixed within each of these populations. The variation might therefore indicate traits rather than characters. The following variation patterns were observed. (1) growthform - plants range from tufted (young plants?) to ancient rings; (2) culm length - at lower altitudes the plants grow much taller than at higher altitudes, and also form denser tussocks; (3) number of female spikelets - there seems to be no pattern; (4) female flower size and width - this is immensely variable within populations, and is no indication of relationships. It remains possible that some segregates can be separated within this complex, but I have not done enough fieldwork to show anything except continuous variation.>
<Within \i{}T. sporadicus\i0{} there is extensive variation in flower size and to some extent in bract size and texture.>
<There is some geographical variation, with northern populations tend to have longer tepals, often as tall as the nuts, while the southern plants have tepals about half as long as the nut.>
<Contains two forms: one erect, caespitose, in drier country, the other with underground creeping stems, almost mat-forming, in wetter country. These could be different species.>
<At Bartholomeus Klip near the Voelvlei Dam a much larger than normal form is found, with plants to 0.3 m tall.>
<There seems to be substantial variation in this species, with some forms reseeding, and others resprouting. However, ecologically it is very uniform, and the peculiar nut hardly varies at all.>
<Very distinct in the genus by its very unusual, 4-lobed nut cap, almost as tall as the nut itself.>

<The perianth and female spikelet construction is still obscure, and as in \i{}W. humilis\i0{}, it is not clear how many tepals are actually formed and develop. It is possible that in these two species there is a reduction in the number of tepals formed.>

<The two very different habitats, coastal plains and Cederberg, suggest that there are two species in this complex. both though have distinctive tepals which widen to the base, so that the petal bases completely obscure the sepal bases. There is also a subtle difference in the spikelet appearance between the two habitats, with the spikelets from the coastal forms generally greyer and smaller than the montane forms. More detailed analysis might well indicate the existence of two distinct species.>

<This "species" might contain two quite distinct entities, and in addition the distinction from \i{}W. arescens\i0{} may not be correct. There appears to be extensive variation in this group. The species can often be identified by the grey spikelets, with the top of the nut visible among the tips of the female bracts, and by the base, which is a mixture of a long, spreading rhizome, and upcurved smaller, secondary rhizomes. The coastal forms usually have caducous spathes in the female inflorescences, grey bracts, and obovate nuts, while the inland forms are persistent spathes, reddish bracts and oblong nuts. This complex needs critical evaluation.>

characters.name: <Differences from related species>
data: <A typical member of \i{}Anthochortus\i0{} by its slender culm, long hairlike leaf mucros, and matted growth. However, it is unique in Restionaceae by the culm overtopping the lateral inflorescence.>

<Very similar to \i{}A. laxiflorus\i0{}, but differs in the earlier flowering time, the bracts with a darker centre and longer apices, and recurved apices, and the more tuberculate culms. These two species often co-occur in the same marshes. It is easily separated from the superficially identical \i{}A. ecklonii\i0{} by the absence of striations on the culms.>

<This and \i{}A. capensis\i0{} are the only \i{}Anthochortus \i0{} species with ridged culms, and both species have remarkably lax male spikelets, which look almost like several one-flowered spikelets. It differs from \i{}A. capensis\i0{} by the terminal spikelets.>
<A rarely seen species, distinct by the small flattened leaf blades. It is very poorly known, and more collections of female plants are needed to verify the description of the female parts.>
<A very distinctive species, by the dense heads of silver-coloured spikelets, and the long finely awned bracts.>

<Very similar to \i{}A. crinalis\i0{}, differs by the reseeding habit, smooth culms, bracts almost entirely membranous and erect, and later flowering time. The two species often co-occur. Seedling similar to \i{}A. graminifolius.\i0{}>

<A very distinctive species, especially by the white sheaths on the rhizome. The flowers are very obscure, and the generic affinities dubious. Most striking is the reduced inner tepal whorl, a unique feature in the African Restionaceae.>

<\i{}A. albo-aristatum\i0{} can be confused with \i{}A. nitidum.\i0{} Pillans separated \i{}A. albo-aristatum\i0{} from \i{}A. nitidum \i0{}by the smaller and more compressed female flowers, with a wing-like keel on the lateral sepals, and the single fertile chamber in the ovary. I used the shape of the inflorescences: \i{}A. albo-aristatum\i0{} has a more oblong spikelet, while \i{}A. nitidum\i0{} has a more globose spikelet.\par{}>
<This is distinct from \i{}A. chartaceum\i0{}, to which it is related by its deeply lacerated bracts.>

<\i{}A. andreaeanum\i0{} is very similar to \i{}A. paniculatum\i0{}: both have large female flowers, mostly 1 flower per spikelet with a few spikelets per node. Both form large tussocks in the south-western mountains. However, \i{}A. andreaeanum \i0{}has a dense panicle of large, well-formed male flowers, while the male inflorescences of \i{}A. paniculatum \i0{}are much more sparse. These species cannot be confidently separated on female or sterile material. The female flowers in \i{}A. andreaeanum \i0{}are smaller than in \i{}A. paniculatum\i0{}, generally being less than 6 mm long, and the tepals are acute, rather than acuminate.>
<Very distinctive by the capitate, black inflorescences.>
<The closests relative is \i{}A. capitata\i0{}, which occurs in the same area, but on dry stony slopes. It is different by the more papery bracts, which obscure the flowers.>
<Distinct by its very small female flowers. It also has a peculiar fruit structure, that would repay closer study.>
<A very distinctive species, readily separated by its great size. It is restricted to a very few populations on the highest peaks.>
<Very distinctive by the large flowers and short spathes.>

<In the Cederberg area \i{}A. nitidum\i0{} could be confused with \i{}A. albo-aristatum\i0{}. Pillans separated \i{}A. albo-aristatum\i0{} from \i{}A. nitidum \i0{}by the smaller and more compressed female flowers, with a wing-like keel on the lateral sepals, and the single fertile chamber in the ovary. I used the shape of the inflorescences: \i{}A. albo-aristatum\i0{} has a more oblong spikelet, while \i{}A. nitidum\i0{} has a more globose spikelet. A critical examination may reveal that these differences do not hold.>

<This species can be confused with \i{}A. andraeaenum\i0{}, but is distinct by the smaller and sparser males, and the different flowering time. Female material cannot be separated with confidence from \i{}A. andreaeanum\i0{}.>
<Distinct by the finely aristate bracts, the creeping rhizomes, the relatively long elaiosome, and the floral bracts which are papery rather than bony.>
<A very distinctive species by the hollow culms and perianth as tall as the nuts, as well as the compact base. This species is centered in the South-western mountains.>

<This species is similar to \i{}C. virgata\i0{} and \i{}C. robusta\i0{} by the branching culms and relatively robust growth. The caespitose growthform allies it to \i{}C. robusta, \i0{}from which it differs by the larger plants (usually more than 2 m tall), the inflorescences which are exserted above the branching "leaves", the fat nut (less than 7-9 mm in diameter), the perianth which is more than 9 mm long, and the swollen golden-brown spikelets. Note that male material, without a growthform indication, cannot be determined to species level.>
<From the other species of \i{}Cannomois\i0{} it is easily separated by the awned, acuminate bracts, and the globose, often quite large, male spikelets.>

<A rather distinctive species, allied to \i{}C. congesta\i0{} from the south-western mountains. Its distinctive features are the milky white tepals, somewhat shorter than half the length of the nut. Further it has large male spikelets with acuminate bracts, and a tussocked growth-form.>

<This species is similar to \i{}C. virgata\i0{} and \i{}C. grandis\i0{} by the branching culms and relatively robust growth. The caespitose growthform allies it to \i{}C. grandis, \i0{}from which it differs by the smaller plants (usually less than 2 m tall), the inflorescences which are not exserted above the branching "leaves", the slender nut (less than 6 mm in diameter), the perianth which is less than 6 mm long, and the long slender brown spikelets. Note that male material, without a growthform indication, cannot be determined to species level.\par{}>

<A very distinctive species, by its spreading habit and tall culms. It is part of the \i{}C. parviflora\i0{} complex, but differs by its generally taller habit. In the field it is readily indentified by the large clonal stands, often several meters in diameter.>
<This species is close to \i{}C. parviflora\i0{}, from which is is distinct by the dark brown spathes, the eastern distribution, and the generally more slender inflorescencest.>

<Previously included in\i{} C. parviflora s.l.\i0{}, but very distinct by the sparsely branching culms, the narrow, elongated nut, the single female flower, and the acuminate slender female spikelet.>

<Related to \i{}C. grandis\i0{} and \i{}C. robusta\i0{} by the branching culms and robust growthform, it is distinct from both species by the clumped growthform, with clones becoming several meters in diameter. The plants are generally less than 1.5 m tall. They rarely produce large, fully developed inflorescences. Because it is difficult to determine sterile or male specimens with confidence, many herbarium specimens currently placed under \i{}C. virgata\i0{} could be collected from one of the other two species.>

<A very distinctive species by the huge size of the plants. It is allied to \i{}C. caespitosum\i0{}, \i{}C. persistens\i0{}, \i{}C. pulchrum\i0{} and \i{}C. fistulosum\i0{} by the absence of an elaiosome from the nut. Within these species it is distinct by the nut ornamentation (evenly tuberculate), and the caespitose habit. However, male specimens, with no indication of the habit or size of the plant, cannot be identified to species level.>

<Separated from \i{}C. argenteum\i0{} by the smooth nut, and from \i{}C. persistens\i0{} by the tussocked growth-form, and from both \i{}C. persistens \i0{}and \i{}C. pulchrum \i0{}different nut size. This group is distinct within the genus by the absence of elaiosomes on the nuts. The nut, which is less than 5 mm in diameter, is also more slender than in the other species in the group. However, male specimens, with no indication of the habit or size of the plant, cannot be identified to species level.\par{}>

<Related to \i{}C. fimbriatum\i0{} and \i{}C. xerophilum\i0{} by the nuts with elaiosomes, but differing in the longer spathes, which are at least 5 cm long in this species, and less than 3 cm in the other two species.>

<Related to \i{}C. decipiens \i0{}and \i{}C. xerophilum\i0{} by the nuts with elaiosomes. It differs from \i{}C. decipiens\i0{} by the spathes which are shorter than 3.5 cm (more than 5 cm long in \i{}C. decipiens\i0{}), and from \i{}C. xerophilum\i0{} by the smooth nuts and deltoid or oblong tepals.>
<This is the only species of \i{}Ceratocaryum \i0{}with hollow culms, these are very evident when these are bent in the field.>

<Allied to \i{}C. argenteum, C. caespitosum, C. pulchrum \i0{}and \i{}C. fistulosum \i0{}by the sessile flowers, where the nut eventually lacks an elaiosome. It is readily separated from \i{}C. argenteum,\i0{} \i{}C. caespitosum\i0{} and \i{}C. pulchrum \i0{}by the spreading habit, and from \i{}C. fistulosum \i0{}by the solid culms. It is also by the nut ornamentation: the nuts have a distinctly rough cap. A similar cap is also found in \i{}C. caespitosum\i0{}, but the nuts in \i{}C. persistens\i0{} are fatter, being 7-9 mm in diameter. However, male specimens without an indication of plant size or habit cannot be determined to species.>

<Allied to \i{}C. argenteum, C. caespitosum, C. persistens \i0{}and \i{}C. fistulosum \i0{}by the sessile flowers, where the nut eventually lacks an elaiosome. It has the same round, evenly ornamented nuts as in \i{}C. argenteum\i0{}, but is separated by the plants being less than 1 m tall and a flowering time in spring (rather than autumn, as is the case in \i{}C. argenteum\i0{}. However, male specimens without an indication of plant size or habit cannot be determined to species.\par{}>

<Related to \i{}C. decipiens \i0{}and \i{}C. fimbriatum\i0{} by the nuts with elaiosomes. It differs from \i{}C. decipiens\i0{} by the spathes which are shorter than 3.5 cm (more than 5 cm long in \i{}C. decipiens\i0{}), and from \i{}C. fimbriatum\i0{} by the smooth nuts and orbicular tepals.>
<Previously included in\i{} E. racemosa\i0{}, which it resembles in the female inflorescence, but it differs by the caespitose habit, forming very large, conspicuous tussocks.>

<In appearance similar to \i{}E. caespitosa\i0{}, but readily separated from it by the long rhizomes (\i{}E. caespitosa\i0{} is neatly tufted), by the shorter bracts (\i{}E. caespitosa\i0{} bracts are more than twice as long as the flowers), and by the somewhat lacerated bract margins. It is also similar to \i{}E. glomerata\i0{}, but the latter has compact, globular inflorescences compared to the open inflorescences of \i{}E. asperiflora\i0{}.>

<Very close to \i{}E. ebracteata\i0{}, but differs by the compact, capitate inflorescences, the acuminate tepals and bracts, and the reduced number of nodes on the culms. Both species co-occur in the mountains above Hermanus, and the assignation of individuals to the species can be difficult. Ecologically separated by the coppicing response to fire, with a resultent difference in the habitats occupied, and in the density of the stands.>

<The species is close to \i{}E. hookeriana\i0{} and \i{}E. decipiens \i0{}(which has aggregated inflorescences). From \i{}E. hookeriana\i0{} it differs by the more robust culms, spikelets with 2-3 flowers, and flowers more than 3.3 mm long. Where both co-occur in the Kogelberg \i{}E. ebracteata\i0{} is common on the well-drained stony slopes, while \i{}E. hookeriana \i0{}is very common to locally dominant on plains and slopes with some impeded drainage or deeper sandy soils. They are never syntopic. Detailed comments under \i{}E. hookeriana\i0{}.>

<\i{}E. equisetacea \i0{} differs from \i{}E. juncea\i0{} by the absence of a rhizome and the presence of spathellae. It also approaches \i{}E. spathacea\i0{} (similar by the rich colour, the large spathes and the tufted habit), but \i{}E. spathacea\i0{} is mostly less than 1 m tall, the spathellae are not as prominently displayed.>

<\i{}E. filacea\i0{} can be confused with many species. From \i{}E. rigida\i0{} it is separated by the female spathes which do not completely obscure the flowers; from \i{}E. vaginulata\i0{} by the absence of a rhizome; from \i{}E. equisetacea\i0{} by the much smaller plants and the absence of spathellae.>

<Very close to \i{}E. ebracteata\i0{}, and the determination of collections as either \i{}E. ebracteata\i0{} or \i{}E. hookeriana\i0{} is at times difficult. Both species occur in Hermanus on the slopes above Fernkloof, and are clearly distinct, both flower in autumn, both appear to coppice after fire, but the size difference is clearcut. The type collection is from the summit of Sir Lowry's Pass, and this material matches the type precisely. Besides, both forms occur at Sir Lowry's pass, and on the flats at the Kogelberg side of Steenbras dam, where there is a clearcut flowering time difference, with \i{}E. hookeriana\i0{} flowering in March, while \i{}E. ebracteata\i0{} is well finished. . Both species also occur at Kogelberg, where \i{}E. ebracteata \i0{}clearly differs by the more robust culms, spikelets with 2-3 flowers, and flowers more than 3.3 mm long. \i{}E. ebracteata\i0{} is common on the well-drained stony slopes, while \i{}E. hookeriana \i0{}is very common to locally dominant on plains and slopes with some impeded drainage or deeper sandy soils. They are never syntopic. \i{}E. ebracteata\i0{} is in full flower in November, while \i{}E. hookeriana \i0{}is by then well finished flowering.\par{}\par{}>

<The species is separated from \i{}E. equisetacea\i0{} by the presence of a rhizome, and the absence of spathellae. From \i{}E. vaginulata\i0{} it can be separated by the culms which are wider than 0.8 mm at the apex (but note that there is some overlap in culm thickness).>

<\i{}Elegia vaginulata\i0{} is close to \i{}E. filacea\i0{} by the slender culms, but differs by the rhizome with widely separated culms and smaller inflorescences. The rhizomes and growth-form associate it with \i{}E. juncea\i0{}, which sometimes might appear as a more robust form of \i{}E. vaginulata\i0{}. Mostly \i{}E. juncea\i0{} has culms more than 1 mm in diameter, is generally more robust, and has shorter and more chaotically structured rhizomes (the culms not evenly spaced, the rhizomes more branching). Populations of both species sometimes are found in close proximity, indicating that they are most likely distinct. However, the possibility remains that they are ends of a cline within one species.\par{}>
<Superficially there is some similarity between \i{}H. albo-aristatus\i0{} and \i{}H. aristatus\i0{}, but our species can usually be distinguished by the culms with single nodes.>

<The fruit structure, and the flowers and spikelets, are rather similar to \i{}H. albo-aristatus\i0{}. The most obvious distinction is in the growth-form, with \i{}H. albo-aristatus\i0{} having a rhizome, and forming clumps, and with the culms with only one node. \i{}H. alternans\i0{} differs in the tufted growth-form, without a rhizome, and with several nodes on the culms. The bracts in \i{}H. alternans\i0{} are much more acuminate than in the other small-spikeletted species of \i{}Hypodiscus\i0{}, giving the spikelets are rather spiky appearance. The culms are also somewhat more slender than typical in the genus.>
<Very distinctive by the silvery bracts, and the reddish female spikelets and dark red styles. The perianth is absent. It cannot be confused with any other species.>

<This species is easily recognised by the robust growth, and the acuminate spikelet bracts, which gives the spikelets a very bristly appearance. In addition, the large, smooth nut with a smooth cap, and the long papery tepals, are unique. It is sometimes confused with \i{}H. albo-aristatus\i0{}, which has no or only one node plus sheath on the culm.>

<This tussocked species is distinct by the orbicular male spikelets, and the somewhat flattened culms. It may be difficult to distinguish from \i{}H. synchroolepis\i0{}: the differences are as follows: \i{}H. laevigatus\i0{} has acute to rounded male bracts without awns (\i{}H. synchroolepis\i0{} acuminate male bracts with awns up to as long as the bract), \i{}H. laevigatus\i0{} has an elaiosome, apparently consisting of swollen tepals, an elaiosome is absent in \i{}H. synchroolepis\i0{}. From \i{}H. rugosus\i0{} our species is also distinct by the presence of the elaiosome.>

<Very distinctive by the bright spathes, and the very simplified female spikelets. Superficially the species is intermediate between \i{}Hypodiscus\i0{} and \i{}Elegia\i0{}, and especially the male inflorescence is reminiscent of \i{}Elegia\i0{}. The species is very isolated in the genus, and its affinities remain obscure.\par{}>

<Within \i{}Hypodiscus\i0{} this species is distinctive by the long open spikelets of the male plants, and by the large conical superstructure of the lobes on the nuts. Some specimens lack culm striations, especially near Laingsburg. From a distance the species is distinctive by the acuminate bracts, which give it a lacerated look.>

<This species is clearly related to \i{}H. willdenowia\i0{} in its creeping rhizomes and striate culms, but it can be readily distinguished by the terete culms and fused styles. From the other species in the \i{}Hypodiscus\i0{} group with striate culms it can be separated by the creeping rhizomes. It may be confused with \i{}H. striatus\i0{}, but is distinct by the much smaller perianth (tepals 1-1.5 mm long, compared to 3-4.5 mm long), but the more slender (2-3 mm diam compared to ca. 5 mm diam.) and longer rhizomes, and the smaller plants (less than 30 cm tall). In the field the two species are immediately distinct: \i{}H. procurrens\i0{} has a creeping habit, while \i{}H. striatus\i0{} is clumped.>

<A segregate from \i{}H. striatus\i0{}, differs by the caespitose habit and the large bracts. It shares with \i{}H. striatus\i0{} the striate, slender culms, and the elongate nuts with concave bases.>

<Distinctive by the somewhat flattened culms, and small growth-form. The nut is remarkably rugose, and the habitat quite unusual - often it is the only restioid in the area. It can be confused with \i{}H. laevigatus\i0{}, from which it differs by the absence of an elaiosome on the nuts, the single row of lobes on the nuts, and the somewhat larger male spikelets.>
<This species possess a unique, small rounded nut, flattened culms, and peculiar aerial rhizomes. In addition, the flowers are much smaller than usual in the genus.>

<This is a very distinctive species. It can be recognised by its bluish, striate culms, the plants forming quite extensive clumps, and by the torpedo-shaped nuts with truncate bases. It is separated from the very similar \i{}H. rigida\i0{} by the clumped (rather than caespitose) habit.>

<Very distinctive with the stout, short, somewhat flexuose culms. Its closest affinities might well be with \i{}H. striatus\i0{} and \i{}H. rigidus\i0{}, with which it shares the striate culms and the peculiar torpedo-shaped tan-coloured nut, with a smooth surface, rounded apex and truncate base. It seems to be restricted to shaley soils in renosterveld.>

<This tussocked species is distinct by the orbicular male spikelets, and the somewhat flattened culms. It may be difficult to distinguish from \i{}H. laevigatus\i0{}: the differences are as follows: \i{}H. laevigatus\i0{} has acute to rounded male bracts without awns, while \i{}H. synchroolepis\i0{} has acuminate male bracts with awns up to as long as the bract; \i{}H. laevigatus\i0{} has an elaiosome, while \i{}H. synchroolepis\i0{} lacks an elaiosome. Furthermore, \i{}H. synchroolepis\i0{} is typically an eastern species (Swartberg, Outeniquas), while \i{}H. laevigatus\i0{} is typically a western species. The two species apparently do not co-occur.>
<Distinctive amongst its relatives by the flattened, striate culms and the distinctive nut. Superficially it could be confused with \i{}H. striatus\i0{}, but the rhizomes are more creeping.>

<Clearly distinct from the other two species of \i{}Nevillea\i0{} by the combination of the very tall female spathes, and the small male spikelets. From \i{}N. singularis\i0{} male specimens can be separated by the smaller male flowers (2-3 mm, vs 4-6 mm), and by the spathes overtopping the spikelets (although in most specimens the spathes have been dropped).>

<Very close to \i{}P. cascadensis\i0{}, both species have strongly compressed culms, usually faintly papillose, with a distinct ribs, as well as 1-3 flowered female spikelets more or less enclosed in the spathes. The plants form dense mats. However, our species can be separated from \i{}P. cascadensis\i0{} by the possession of a unilocular ovary (\i{}P. cascadensis\i0{} has a bilocular ovary) and by glabrous flowers (the lateral sepals of \i{}P. cascadensis\i0{}) are sparsely villous. The whole plant is also somewhat more gracile.>
<The differences between this species and \i{}P. major\i0{} are not clear (\i{}P. compressus \i0{}has smaller spikelets), and currently not very convincing, as the full range of intermediates exist.>

<The only species of \i{}Platycaulos\i0{} that is found in the Drakensberg. Distinct from the other Drakensberg species of Restionaceae by the much larger growthform and spikelets, rhizomes, and erect habit.>
<Related to \i{}P. compressus\i0{}, and differs from it primarily by the larger spikelets. This difference is not convincing.>
<Close to \i{}P. depauperatus\i0{}, technically separated by the two-locular ovary, although in some collections at least some of the flowers have unilocular ovaries.>
<This species is immediately distinct by the flattened culms and the striking two-toned floral bracts.>

<\i{}R. arcuatus\i0{} is similar to \i{}R. perplexus\i0{} by its tangled growthform. The spikelets are quite different, but more obvious is that the final ca. 5 cm of the culms in \i{}R. arcuatus \i0{} are curved thought 180 degrees: they are best described as arcuate!>

<This species belongs in the \b{}Restio bolusii Group\b0{}, defined by the foveolate black cells on the sheaths. It also has many of the other attributes of the group: the densely villous lateral sepals, reduced number of spikelets, two fertile locules. However, the affinities of the species within this group are still unknown. It is almost unique within the group by the single-flowered female spikelets.\par{}>

<Presumably closest to \i{}Restio strictus\i0{}. It differs from all other species of Restionoideae by the long straight hair from the leaf axils, and from \i{}R. strictus\i0{} in particular by the broadly membranous floral bracts. Furthermore, there are differences in seed ornamentation and colour and male flower size.>
<The female plants can be confused with female plants of \i{}Staberoha banksii\i0{}, but are generally more robust, and a deeper red.>

<The species is allied to the \i{}R. bolusii\i0{} complex, and species delimitations in this complex appear to be difficult. From \i{}R. bolusii \i0{}sometimes distinct by the tuft of hair on the odd sepal.>

<\i{}R. bolusii\i0{} is very close to \i{}R. bifurcus.\i0{} Several attributes may be used to separate the species. \i{}R. bolusii\i0{} flowers in autumn, \i{}R. bifurcus\i0{} in spring; In \i{}R. bolusii \i0{}the female bracts have distinctive nerves; in \i{}R. bifurcus\i0{} no nerves are visible; in \i{}R. bolusii\i0{} the bract apices are apiculate, in \i{}R. bifurcus\i0{} they are acute; and finally in \i{}R. bolusii \i0{}the foveolate cells are not sharply separated from the body, while they are in \i{}R. bifurcus\i0{} - where this gives the bracts a bicoloured appearance.\par{}>
<This species has some similarity to \i{}Restio occultus\i0{}, from which it differs by the smaller growth form, and the erect male inflorescences.>

<The geographical isolation of \i{}R. brunneus\i0{} in the Cederberg makes the distinction from \i{}R. pachystachyus \i0{}relatively easy. Technicall, \i{}R. pachystachyus\i0{} has 5-10 flowers, compared to the more than 15 flowers per female spikelet in \i{}R. brunneus\i0{}. Consequently \i{}R. pachystachyus \i0{}has fewer, but larger, bracts per spikelet, then in \i{}R. brunneus\i0{}.>

<From \i{}R. bifurcus\i0{} is should be distinguished by the glabrous odd sepal, from \i{}R. burchellii\i0{} by the obtuse bracts and the habitat in mountains, and the foveolate dark bract cells sharply delimited from the normal bract cells, and from \i{}R. bolusii\i0{} by the smaller female spikelets.>
<Very similar to \i{}Restio paludicola\i0{} from Hermanus, from which it differs by the bilocular ovaries and simple inflorescences.>

<Superficially very similar to \i{}R. miser \i0{}by the unbranched culms and the small globose spikelets, where the flowers are taller than the bracts. However, \i{}R. confusus\i0{} is caespitose, while \i{}R. miser\i0{} is matforming. Technically \i{}R. miser \i0{}is separated by having 1 to rarely 2 flowered female spikelets, while the female spikelets of \i{}R. confusus\i0{} are usually 2-4 flowered (the occasional poorly developed spikelet is single flowered). The two species also occupy the same habitat. \i{}R. miser\i0{} differs from \i{}R. confusus\i0{} by the more slender culms, the single-flowered female spikelets, the more acuminate bracts, and several minor size differences in the spikelets. Both differ from the very similar \i{}R. similis\i0{} by the glabrous lateral tepals.\par{}>

<This species is similar to \i{}R. wittebergensis\i0{}, both species have both male and female spikelets aggregated into button-like heads. However, it differs from \i{}R. wittebergensis\i0{} by its branching culms (\i{}R. wittebergensis\i0{} has simple culms), and the stoloniferous habit (\i{}R. wittebergensis\i0{} is caespitose). The stoloniferous habit and aggregated spikelets suggests a similarity to \i{}R. schoenoides\i0{}, but this species is more slender, carpet forming rather than tangled.>

<\i{}Restio corneolus\i0{} is closely related to \i{}R. sarocacladus\i0{}: both have oblique flowers, and similar looking bracts. However, \i{}R. corneolus\i0{} is caespitose, while the plants of \i{}R. saroclados\i0{} spread by stolons, and the floral bracts are awned, not muticous. Other related species are \i{}R. vallis-simius\i0{} and \i{}R. ejuncidus. \i0{}The habit of \i{}R. corneolus\i0{} of quite straight culms diverging from a narrow base is distinctive.>

<Distinct by the unbranched culms, the single female spikelets, and the recurved bracts. By these characters it is very similar to \i{}R. elsieae\i0{}, but it differs from the latter species by the sheaths which are closely wrapped around the culms. Superficially the species can also be confused with \i{}R. virgeus\i0{}.\par{}>

<Very close to \i{}Restio secundus\i0{}, and the two might be synonymous. However, in \i{}R. secundus\i0{} the spathes are more or less blunt, and closely applied to the culm, while in \i{}R. decipiens \i0{}they are extended and recurved from the culm. On the Langeberg at Swellendam the two species are readily distinguished, but if the whole variation pattern in the two species is considered, it becomes more difficult to separate them.>

<Very distinct by the long red female inflorescences, and the branching and paler male inflorescences. The species is often confused with \i{}R. purpurascens\i0{}, which, however, has bilocular ovaries, and a roughly papillate culm.>
<Superficially the species may be confused with \i{}R. triticeus\i0{}. Distinctive is the membranous apex of the floral bracts, and the way these spread to expose the male flowers at anthesis.>

<This species is readily confused with the closely related \i{}R. monostylis\i0{}. Technically, \i{}R. distylis\i0{} has two styles, compared to the single style of \i{}R. monostylis. \i0{}In addition, \i{}R. distylis \i0{}can be distinguished from \i{}R. monostylis \i0{}by the presence of spreading rhizomes, the somewhat different sheath margins. The floral bracts are also more acute to acuminate, as a consequence the spikelets are bristly rather than rounded.>

<This species is similar to \i{}R. laniger\i0{}, the two species often co-occur in the subalpine and alpine summit areas of the Cape mountains, and can easily be confused. The differences can be summarised as follows. (1) \i{}R. distractus\i0{} has a tuberculate culm; in \i{}R. laniger\i0{} it is smooth. (2) \i{}R. distractus\i0{} anthers are less than 2.2 mm long and brown; in \i{}R. laniger\i0{} they are more than 2.3 mm long and white. (3)\i{} R. distractus\i0{} culm colour is more blue; \i{}I. laniger \i0{}more green. There are also reported differences in fire survival strategy,\par{}>

<Very distinctive by its recurved bracts, with the flowers wider at the apex than the bracts and consequently exposed at the apex. Superficially the species has a similar look as \i{}R. curvibracteatus\i0{}.>

<This species is related to \i{}R. micans\i0{} by the pendulous male spikelets, somewhat reminiscent of \i{}Thamnochortus\i0{}. It is readily separated by the generally larger growth (up to 2 m tall), much female spikelets (25-50 mm, compared to 15-20 in \i{}R. micans\i0{}).>

<Close to \i{}R. saroclados, R. leptostachyus\i0{} and \i{}R. corneolus\i0{}, and the distinctions need critical investigation. From \i{}R. corneolus\i0{} it differs by the spreading stolons, \i{}R. leptostachyus \i0{}is a much finer plant with smaller spikelets (although on Table Mountain the two could be intergrading), and \i{}R. saroclados\i0{} has thicker culms.>

<This species is a high-altitude segregate from \i{}R. ocreatus\i0{}. It differs by the simple, stout culms, and smaller growth-form. The single female spikelet with recurved bracts and unbranched culms are similar to \i{}R. curvibracteatus\i0{}, but our species can be recognised by the flat, spreading sheaths. Note that sometimes only the lower sheaths spread, while the upper are only loosely convoluted. The species are also geographically separated.>
<Very distinct by the large, golden inflorescences.>

<\i{}Restio fraternus\i0{} is part of the \i{}R. ocreatus\i0{} complex, together with \i{}R. elsieae \i0{}(which as unbranched culms), and \i{}R. fuscidulus.\i0{} It is distinguished from \i{}R. ocreatus\i0{} by the female flowers less than 6.5 mm long, but the shorter female spikelets (less than 16 mm long), and by the darker coloured sheaths. Generally, \i{}R. fraternus\i0{} appears to have smaller flowers and inflorescences, while the plants remain the same size. Intermediate between the two species appears to be a single collection from Tarantula Pk in the Hex River Mountains (\i{}Esterhuysen 30613\i0{}).>

<Sharply distinct from the \i{}R.\i0{} \i{}luxurians\i0{}: they differ in growth-form, with var. \i{}luxurians\i0{} being an erect tussock, with straight terminal branches, and a more robust basal culm. In addition, the habitat differs.>

<Close to \i{}R. impolitus\i0{}, which is geographically isolated west of Houw Hoek pass. Both species have characteristically winged seed, and a remarkably distichous inflorescence. Morphologically \i{}R. hyalinus\i0{} is more gracile than \i{}R. impolitus\i0{}, with only 3 flowers per male spikelet (compared to 4-5 in \i{}R. impolitus\i0{}), the female spikelets are 6-10 mm long (compared to 11-15 mm in \i{}R. impolitus\i0{}), and the female flowers are 3-3.5 mm long (compared to 4.5-6 mm in \i{}R. impolitus\i0{}).>

<Close to \i{}R. hyalinus\i0{}, which is allopatric to this species and found east of Houw Hoek pass. Both species have characteristically winged seed, and a remarkably distichous inflorescence. It differs by the substantially larger female flowers, and the males with more than three flowers per spikelet.>

<\i{}Restio insignis\i0{} is possibly not distinct from \i{}R. strobilifer\i0{}. A multivariate cladistic and phenetic analysis based on the herbarium collections in the Bolus Herbarium (Morley, T., 1994. Defining the species boundaries within the \i{}R. bolusii\i0{} complex using morphological characters. Unpublished Honours thesis, Botany Dept., University of Cape Town) suggested that \i{}R. insignis\i0{} is nested within \i{}R. strobilifer\i0{}, differing primarily on the size of the male and female spikelets. According to \i{}Linder 5983\i0{} there is also a habit difference, and with \i{}R. insignis\i0{} found at higher altitudes. \i{}R. insignis\i0{} has mostly been recorded from among rocks, often on ridges and summits, while \i{}R. strobilifer\i0{} is found on sandplains and along streams, often where there is some ground water. Although the species is maintained here, it is in need of critical appraisal.\par{}>

<\i{}Restio inveteratus\i0{} is related by \i{}R. filiformis\i0{} by the spikelet structure. However, it is readily recognised by the robust growth-form, the larger flowers, the almost smooth, reddish seed, and the concolourous, yellow-brown bracts.>

<Close to \i{}R. saroclados, R. ejuncidus\i0{} and \i{}R. corneolus\i0{}, and the distinctions need critical investigation. Our species probably differs best by the very slender culms, the small bracts, adn the habit of hanging down from south-facing cliffs.\par{}>

<This species is related to \i{}R. egregius\i0{} by the pendulous male spikelets, somewhat reminiscent of \i{}Thamnochortus\i0{}. It is readily separated by the generally smaller growth (less than 1 m tall) and the much smaller female spikelets (15-20 mm, compared to 25-50 in \i{}R. egregius\i0{}). The bracts have also distinctive striate.>

<Very close to \i{}R. confusus\i0{} by the unbranched culms, the small compact spikelets with few flowers, and the dark bracts more or less as long as the spikelets. The two species also occupy the same habitat. \i{}R. miser\i0{} differs from \i{}R. confusus\i0{} by the more slender culms, the single-flowered female spikelets, the more acuminate bracts, and several minor size differences in the spikelets. However, these differences are not consistent, and it remains possible that the two should be regarded as a single species with a cline in the size and degree of development of the female spikelet.\par{}>

<Closely related to \i{}R. distylis\i0{} by the simple culms, cone-like spikelets, tuberculate culms, sheaths with decaying upper halves, winged persistent perianth, and reduced style number. Our species can be separated from \i{}R. distylis \i0{}by the lack of spreading rhizomes, the somewhat different sheath margins, and the styles reduced to one. The floral bracts are more rounded, as a consequence the spikelets are rounded and not bristly.>

<This species is very close to \i{}R. tuberculatus\i0{}, from which it can be distinguished by the tubercles being restricted to the basal portions of the culms, by the awn on the sheaths being less than 1/3 of the length of the sheath. It also has affinities to \i{}R. multiflorus\i0{}, both in the shape of the spikelet, and in the ciliate upper margins of the female bracts.>

<The species was originally described as a segregate from \i{}R. sieberi\i0{}, but it clearly differs from this dramatically by the dense cushions which it forms, and by the much thicker culms. In the field it looks rather like \i{}R. laniger\i0{}, and it might be difficult to separate the two species.>

<Related to the \i{}Restio bolusii\i0{} complex by the numerous overlapping bracts with black, foveolate apical cells. However, it can readily be distinguished from the other species in this complex by the globose spikelets, the short habit, and the habitat near the summits of the Hex River mountains.>

<This species has affinities to \i{}R. nuwebergensis\i0{} and \i{}R. nodosus\i0{}, shown by the sparsely branched culms, the densely villous flowers, the spikelets with numerous fertile bracts. However, it can be distinguished by the reflexed, almost black bracts, which are unique in the African Restionaceae. \par{}>

<The species complex includes \i{}R. ocreatus, R. elsieae, R. fuscidulus \i0{}and \i{}R. fraternus\i0{}: all have spreading sheaths and spikelets with acuminate, recurved bracts. \i{}Restio elsiae \i0{}is a high-altitude endemic to the Hexriver mountains: it is immediately recognised by the unbranched culms and shorter growth form. Esterhuysen regarded this as a high-altitude form of \i{}R. ocreatus\i0{}. \i{}R. fraternus \i0{}replaces \i{}R. ocreatus\i0{} in the coastal mountains, it is distinct the smaller, more globose female spikelets and female flowers less than 6.5 mm long. A specimen from Tarantula Peak in the Hex River mts, \i{}Esterhuysen 30613\i0{}, clusters with \i{}R. fraternus\i0{}, but flowers by size fits R\i{}. ocreatus\i0{}. It is from a much higher altitude than typical \i{}R. ocreatus\i0{}, and is best regarded as intermediate between the species.>

<Very close to \i{}R. communis\i0{} from the Cape Peninsula, it differs in the less robust spikelets, the more slender flowers, and the smaller female bracts. There is a single collection from the Caledon Swartberg, which might be intermediate, or which might constitute yet another segregate: the material was collected at the wrong time of the year.>
<Related to \i{}Restio perplexus\i0{} by the general habit and habitat, but with larger spikelets, and generally found at a higher altitude. The species is still poorly known.>

<It is allied to the \i{}R. triticeus\i0{} group by the colliculate seed, cartilaginous bracts and finely and densely tuberculate culms. However, it can immediately be recognised by the massive hyaline shoulders on the sheaths, and the long slender hair-like awn of the spathes and bracts.>

<This species is related to \i{}R. miser\i0{} and \i{}R. communis\i0{} by the simple culms, the small compact few-flowered spikelets, and the three-locular ovaries. However, it can be distinguished by the smaller, more compact plants, and by the bracts which exceed the flowers in length.>

<The distinction between this species and from \i{}R. patens\i0{} difficult, and needs critical evaluation. Curiously, the plants often have water droplets on them long after the rest of the vegetation has dried out. Also very near \i{}R. capillaris\i0{}, with the same isolated spikelets with bracts with broad membranous margins. Pillans (1928) distinguished it from \i{}R. capillaris\i0{} by "stems slender; branches usually filiform" compared to "stems filiform; branches usually capillary".\par{}>
<The species might be related to \i{}R. aureolus\i0{}, but currently the affinities are not clear. The spikelet, held at a slight angle, is reminiscent of that of \i{}R. alticola\i0{}.>

<Superficially often confused with \i{}R. dispar\i0{}, since both species form tall, similarly looking lanky tussocks. However, the two species differ in a number of ways. Firstly, \i{}R. purpurascens\i0{} has coarsely papillate culms and sheaths, secondly the ovaries are bilocular, and lastly the female flowers are 4-5.5 mm long (compared to 7-10 mm in \i{}R. dispar\i0{}).>

<Related to \i{}Restio paniculatus\i0{} and \i{}Restio tetragonus\i0{} by the branching inflorescences and the spikelet structure, and to the latter species particularly by the square culms. However, it can be distinguished by the side branches of the inflorescence as long as the main branch, thus making a more or less bushy inflorescence. In addition, the culms are ca. 5 mm in diameter, and the spikelets only 4-6 mm long, and the lateral sepals are more or less villous.\par{}>
<Very distinctive by the long awns on the sheaths, and the massive oblong spikelets. The latter are reminiscent of wheat-ears.>

<This species is related to the \i{}R. leptostachyus\i0{} group by the smooth seed, the bracts longer than the flowers and without a differentiated apical portion, and the obtriangular / oblong spikelets. However, it can be separated from all other species in this group by the bilocular ovaries.>
<us>

<Very close to \i{}Restio secundus\i0{}, and the two might be synonymous. However, in \i{}R. secundus \i0{}the spathes are more or less blunt, and closely applied to the culm, while in \i{}R. decipiens \i0{}they are extended and recurved from the culm. On the Langeberg at Swellendam the two species are readily distinguished.>
<The combination of a single-flowered spikelet, a three-locular ovary, and a branching culm makes this robust species easy to determine.>

<This species is very close to \i{}Restio subtilis\i0{}, with which it shares similar spikelet and flower morphology, compressed culms, and seed morphology. The flowers of our species are generally somewhat bigger than those of \i{}R. subtilis\i0{}, and the culms are branching. The two species also occupy the same habitat, but are allopatric. Both are probably related to \i{}R. confusus\i0{} and \i{}R. miser.\i0{}>
<The species is readily recognised by the lacerated, membranous spathes, which subtend a tight cluster of ca. 3 female spikelets.>

<Very close to \i{}Restio stereocaulis\i0{}, with which it shares similar spikelet and flower morphology, compressed culms, and seed morphology. The flowers of our species are generally somewhat smaller than those of \i{}R. stereocaulis\i0{}, and the culms are simple. The two species also occupy the same habitat, but are allopatric.>

<Related to \i{}Restio paniculatus\i0{} and \i{}Restio quadratus\i0{} by the branching inflorescences and the spikelet structure, and to the latter species particularly by the square culms. However, it can be distinguished by the side branches of the inflorescence much shorter than the main branch, thus making a more or less linear inflorescence. In addition, the culms are ca. 3 mm in diameter, and the spikelets 6-8 mm long, and the lateral sepals are more or less glabrous.\par{}>

<\i{}Restio triticeus\i0{} is a widespread species, typical of drier types of fynbos. It shares with \i{}R. multiflorus\i0{} an inflorescence of several many-flowered spikelets, and more or less tuberculate culms. It can be distinguished by the acute (rather than acuminate or apiculate) bracts. Most characteristic, though, is that the spikelets are somewhat curved. This is particularly visible in young spikelets, before the flowers have opened. The species is also easily confused with \i{}R. inconspicuus\i0{}, but can be distinguished by the spathes being much shorter than the spikelets, while in \i{}R. inconspicuus\i0{} the spathes almost obscure the spikelets. \i{}R. triticeus\i0{} is generally a much-branched plant, while \i{}R. inconspicuus \i0{}is sparsely branched.>

<This species is very distinctive by the very coarsely tubercled lower culms, and by the loosely convoluted sheaths with broad membranous shoulders. It may well be related to \i{}R. multiflorus\i0{} in the spikelet and branching patterns, as well as the ciliate bracts.>

<\i{}Restio uniflorus\i0{} has many similarities to \i{}R. confusus\i0{}: the more or less simple, slender culms, the few-flowered spikelets, the glabrous tepals, the bracts shorter than the flowers. However, it differs from these two species by the very lax female inflorescence, and by the consistently 1-flowered spikelets.>
<A rather distinctive species, which might be related to \i{}Restio zwartbergensis.\i0{}>

<This species is a segregate from \i{}R. fruticosa.\i0{} It can be distinguished primarily by the much larger and showier spathes, but also by the shorter and stouter culms. Ecologically it is found at a higher altitude than \i{}R. fruticosa\i0{}. Caespitose plants from the Langeberg were previously included in this species: they are here excluded. They are clearly different from our alpine species in growth-form and the size and shape of the male spikelets.\par{}>

<Very distinctive in the genus by the very tall, tufted growth-form. This species is difficult to separate from \i{}R. vleibergensis\i0{}, but in the field they are readily distinct by the growth-form, with \i{}R. vleibergensis\i0{} with less than 5 erect, widely spaced culms, while our species is densely tufted. Incomplete material can also be very difficult to separate from \i{}R. foliosus\i0{}, which which it differs only in the absence of a rhizome and of soft sterile branches at the nodes. There are a series of collections from the Little Karoo mountains from mid-altitudes, which have tough, rigid sterile branches at the nodes: it is not clear how these should be classified. \par{}>

<The growth-form of the plants is quite unique, with huge culms and tussocks, each with whorls of branches, all of which are fertile. The flower morphology places the species with the genus \i{}Rhodocoma\i0{}, although no other species in the genus have a similar growth-form. The homologies of what constitutes an inflorescence in this species are quite obscure. Superficially this species can be similar to \i{}Calopsis paniculata\i0{}, but it can immediately be separated by the whorled sterile branches, rather than the dichotomous branching system of \i{}C. paniculata.\i0{}>

<This species is very close to \i{}R. gigantea\i0{}, from which it differs in the female flowers being less than 5 mm long, the plants being smaller, more rhizomatous, and resprouting after fire. The two species are allopatric, with material west of the Gouritz gorge fitting \i{}R. foliosus\i0{}, and material from east of the river fitting \i{}R. gigantea\i0{}. There could also be intermediates to \i{}R. arida\i0{} from the upper altitudes of the mountains of the Klein Karoo, but our material is still inadequate (no rhizomes).>

<Close to \i{}R. arida\i0{} and \i{}R. alpina\i0{}, which were both relatively recently segregated from this species. \i{}R. arida\i0{} differs in being tussocked, and generally bigger, while \i{}R. alpina\i0{} differs in the more robust culms, and the much more striking and larger spathes. The three species differ in their ecologies, as well, with \i{}R. alpina\i0{} found at higher altitudes, and \i{}R. arida\i0{} found in drier habitats.>

<\i{}R. gigantea\i0{} is closely related to \i{}R. foliosa\i0{}, but can be distinguished by several features: the plants are taller, the flowers are bigger, the plants are killed by fire, and flower in autumn rather than spring. The two species are also allopatric separated by the Gouritz River gorge. Although there remain some collections which are difficult to key on morphological grounds, the two species seem distinct on sufficient grounds to keep them separate, contrary to the treatment in Linder (1985).>

<This species is close to \i{}R. fruticosa\i0{}, but differs by its caespitose habit, generally much more slender growthform, and different flowering time. It differs from \i{}R. arida\i0{}, which is also tussocked, by its much smaller and slender habit and size.>

<This species is very close to \i{}Rhodocoma arida\i0{}, but the "gestalt" of the plants is different, with smaller, tattier looking plants, which spread with a more developed rhizome. Further is there a geographical separation, essentially the N2, with \i{}R. vleibergensis\i0{} found north of this valley, and \i{}R. arida\i0{} east. However, I have not yet found a good character to separate the two species by.>
<\i{}Staberoha aemula\i0{} can be separated from \i{}S. cernua\i0{} by the flowers without hyaline or membranous, often lacerated, wings.>
<This species is similar to \i{}S. aemula\i0{}, but can be separated by the membranous or hyaline, often lacerated, wings.>
<Distinct in the genus by the robust female bracts and spikelets, the broad bases of the plants, and the widely winged flowers.>
<Differs in the genus by the angular male inflorescences. Like \i{}S. vaginata\i0{} there are several female spikelets, but the flowers are 2.5-4 mm long (rather than 1.5-2.5 mm).>

<Similar to \i{}S. multispicula\i0{} by the presence of several slender female spikelets, but the female flowers are only 1.5-2.5 mm long (compared to the the 2.5-4 mm long flowers of \i{}S. multispicula\i0{}).>

<It is related to \i{}T. fruticosus\i0{} and \i{}T. cinereus \i0{}and \i{}T. rigida\i0{} by the silvery large female spikelets and the pubescent culms, but is very distinct by the overlapping sheaths on the culms, and the tufted growth-form, without a rhizome. In particular, the out of proportion large and showy silvery-brown female spikelets set this species off from the others.>

<Closely related to \i{}T. papyraceous\i0{}, which is found along the summits of the adjacent Klein Swartberg. Although the flowers and spikelets are very similar, our species can be separated by the sterile growth around the base of the plant, and the very different growth-form, as well as the much larger spikelets.>

<\i{}T. arenarius\i0{} is related to \i{}T. lucens\i0{}. It is distinct by the smooth shiny nutlet, and by the smaller flowers. The species in this complex are separated by flower size and rhizome construction. This species is difficult to separate from \i{}T. sporadicus\i0{}: both have spreading rhizomes and similar spikelets. However, in \i{}T. sporadicus\i0{} the bracts are concolorous, while in \i{}T. arenarius\i0{} they have broad membranous margins. Maybe the easiest way to separate them, though, is by flowering time: \i{}T. arenarius\i0{} flowers in autumn, while \i{}T. sporadicus\i0{} flowers in spring.\par{}>

<The species is very close to \i{}T. lucens\i0{}. It often co-occurs on the West Coast sandplains with \i{}T. punctatus\i0{}, with which it is also morphologically very similar. The two species are most easily separated by the flowering times: \i{}T. bachmannii\i0{} flowers in spring, from June to September, while \i{}T. punctatus\i0{} flowers in autumn, from March to June.>

<Clearly related to \i{}T. fruticosus\i0{} and \i{}T. rigidus\i0{} by the velvety culms, and the largely hyaline bracts. It can be separated from the former by the caespitose growth-form (thus no rhizome), and from the latter by the much longer and finer sterile leaf culms and lacerated membranous leaf, and by the tepals obscured behind the bracts.>

<A most remarkable species, quite unlike anything else in the genus. Firstly, the acuminate awned bracts are shared only with \i{}T. pulchrum\i0{}. The most remarkable, though, is the fruit and female flowers. The sepals are almost redundant, and the petals form a strong box around the nut. It is not clear how dispersal happens, or what the dispersal unit looks like.>
<The distinction from \i{}T. guthrieae\i0{} is dubious, but may be a sandstone vicariant, based on different flower shape and texture of the bracts. The complex is in need of detailed study.>

<\i{}Thamnochortus erectus\i0{} is easily and frequently confused with \i{}T. insignis\i0{} and \i{}T. spicigerus\i0{}. These three species form tall tufts, more than 1 m tall, on the coastal forelands. Both have relatively large inflorescences, and long, straight culms. \i{}T. spicigerus\i0{} is easily distinguished by the oblong, almost black spikelets - the other two have pale brown spikelets. \i{}T. erectus\i0{} differs from \i{}T. insignis\i0{} by a number of characters: (1) the plants are clumped, rather than tufted; (2) they flower in spring, rather than autumn; (3) the female spikelets are shorter (less than 20 mm long); and (4) the flowers are frequently visible on one side of their subtending bracts, rather than being completely obscured by the bracts. The differences among them are discussed in detail by Linder (1990), A morphological study on the \i{}Thamnochortus erectus\i0{} complex (Restionaceae). \i{}S. African Journal of Botany \b\i0{}56: \b0{}443-449.\par{}>

<This species is allied to \i{}T. paniculatus\i0{}, with which it shares the typically decurrent sepal bases. However, it is very distinctive by the rich red colouring of the bracts, and the obovate shape of the female flowers. The female flowers are much smaller than in \i{}T. paniculatus \i0{}(3-4.5 mm compared to 5-7.5 mm in \i{}T. paniculatus\i0{}).>

<The species is clearly related to \i{}T. acuminatus\i0{}, \i{}T. cinereus \i0{} and \i{}T. rigidus\i0{} by the downy culms, hyaline floral bracts, and often long, overlapping hyaline sheaths. However, it differs from these species by the long, spreading rhizomes, and by the lateral sepals protruding extensively on both sides of the bracts. Due to the rhizome the plants form open mats (scattered culms) rather than tussocks.>
<Distinct by the large spikelets, and the eastern Cape distribution (it is the only species of \i{}Thamnochortus\i0{} found east of the Knysna forests).>

<\i{}Thamnochortus gracilis\i0{} can immediately be distinguished from all other species of \i{}Thamnochortus\i0{} by the sparingly branched culms (the only other species with branched fertile culms is \i{}T. levynsiae\i0{}), and the small, pale spikelets, bristly with the acuminate floral bracts.>

<Superficially the species bears some resemblance to \i{}T. lucens\i0{}, with which it can co-occur.
