It is distinct by the stout culms, the sterile branches at the nodes, and the reddish bracts with narrow hyaline margins. The most important attribute, however, is that the flower is oblong, clearly longer than wide. The species of the \i{}T. lucens\i0{} complex (e.g. \i{}T. lucens, T. sporadicus, T. arenarius\i0{}) all have orbicular flowers, which are as wide as long. May be similar to \i{}T. ellipticus\i0{}, and the distinctions between the two species need critical evaluation.>

<\i{}Thamnochortus insignis\i0{} is easily and frequently confused with \i{}T. erectus\i0{} and \i{}T. spicigerus\i0{}. These three species form tall tufts, more than 1 m tall, on the coastal forelands. Both have relatively large inflorescences, and long, straight culms. They may be closely related to each other. \i{}T. spicigerus\i0{} is easily distinguished by the oblong, almost black spikelets - the other two have pale brown spikelets. \i{}T. insignis\i0{} differs from \i{}T. erectus\i0{} by a number of characters: (1) the plants are tufted, rather than clumped; (2) they flower in autumn, rather than spring, (3) the female spikelets are longer (usually more than 20 mm long); and (4) the flowers are completely obscured by their subtending bracts, rather than being exserted on one side of the bract. The differences among them are discussed in detail by Linder (1990), A morphological study on the \i{}Thamnochortus erectus\i0{} complex (Restionaceae). \i{}S. African Journal of Botany \b\i0{}56: \b0{}443-449.\par{}>

<Similar to \i{}T. insignis\i0{}, but our species flowers later, the plants are smaller, and the female bracts more membranous. It is also allopatric with \i{}T. insignis.\i0{} At the northern entrance of Garcias Pass a small adventive population of \i{}T. insignis\i0{} exists, growing largely on the laterites used to make the road bed. This is within a few hundred meters of a natural population of \i{}T. karooica\i0{}. I have not observed intermediates, but the \i{}T. insignis\i0{} population might be still quite new. It would be interesting to investigate this in a few years' time.>

<\i{}Thamnochortus kammanassie \i0{}is probably most closely related to \i{}Thamnochortus guthrieae\i0{}, with which it shares the large flowers, the relatively few female spikelets, and the combination or large oblong - obovate female spikelets with chartaceous bracts. However, it differs by the larger, wider, more or less orbicular flowers, in which the tepals are exserted next to the floral bracts, and by the absence of sterile branches at the nodes of older, mature culms. This new species is also found far to the east of the nearest currently known populations of \i{}T. gurthrieae\i0{} from the Langeberg at Garcias Pass.>

<A very distinctive species. The only other species with branching culms is \i{}T. gracilis, \i0{}but it is immediately distinct from \i{}T. gracilis\i0{} by the oblong flowers, thicker culms, and habitat on cool south-facing slopes.>

<This species is closely related to \i{}T. arenarius\i0{} and \i{}T. sporadicus\i0{}: they have characteristically round small flowers, and very similar spikes. However, these other two species have looping rhizomes, while \i{}T. lucens\i0{} is always tufted. By its habit and inflorescences \i{}T. lucens\i0{} is also very similar to \i{}T. punctatus\i0{} and \i{}T. bachmannii\i0{}, but while these other two species have either punctate or sulcate culms, those of \i{}T. lucens\i0{} are always smooth and simple.>

<\i{}Thamnochortus obtusus \i0{}is readily recognised in the field by its remarkably diffuse growth, often forming a sparse understory under taller restios and other plants on the coastal sandplains. This is due to the long looping rhizomes. The plants also produce copious sterile growth.>

<The colour of the spikelets is very distinctive, as are the slightly reflexed, somewhat acuminate bract apices. The three groves in the flower pedicels suggests and relationship to \i{}T. fraternus\i0{}, which is also a limestone endemic, but the spikelet and bract morphology immediately distinguishes the two species. The flowers (5-7.5 mm long) are much larger than in \i{}T. fraternus\i0{} (3-4.5 mm long).>

<This species is very distinctive with its silvery inflorescences. Its closest affinity is with \i{}T. amoena\i0{}, from which it differs by the absence of sterile branches, and the smaller spikelets. It is also related to \i{}T. acuminatus\i0{} by the long papery sheaths, but differs in the glabrous culm.\par{}>

<The most distinctive feature of this species is the habit, with sterile branches forming a skirt some distance above the ground. The spikelets are more slender and silvery than in any species in the genus.\par{}>

<Very close to \i{}T. comptonii\i0{}, from which it can be separated by the flowers longer than 6.5 mm and by the consistent caespitose growth-form. However, the collections from Brandewijns Rivier, which are geographically intermediate, may also fit more comfortably with \i{}T. comptonii. \i0{}I remain unconvinced this this taxonomy is correct, and the possibility remains that it would be better to include \i{}T. comptonii\i0{}, \i{}T. scabridus\i0{}, \i{}T. schlechteri\i0{} and \i{}T. platypteris\i0{} in one variable species, and possibly to recognise geographical subspecies.>
<Distinctive among the other limestone species by the numerous spikelets in the inflorescences, and the minute flowers (only 2-3 mm long), which are almost orbicular.>

<Differs from \i{}T. fruticosus\i0{} by the absence of a rhizome. It is very similar to \i{}T. cinereus, \i0{} differs by the ecology, the more rigid sterile branches, the shorter stature. But it could be simply a local form of this species. It is very dubious whether should should be recognised as a distinct species.>

<\i{}Thamnochortus pulcher \i0{}is unusual in the genus by several characters: the male spikelets are large, and elliptical; the bracts are acuminate, and in the female flowers the petals are longer than the sepals. The grey colour of both male and female bracts is also distinctive.>

<Technically the species is diagnosed by the punctate culms, but these are very difficult to see. It often co-occurs on the West Coast sandplains with \i{}T. punctatus\i0{}, with which it is also morphologically very similar. The two species are most easily separated by the flowering times: \i{}T. bachmannii\i0{} flowers in spring, from June to September, while \i{}T. punctatus\i0{} flowers in autumn, from March to June. \par{}>

<\i{}Thamnochortus rigidus\i0{} was separated from \i{}T. cinereus\i0{}, and Linder (1985: Bothalia 15: 477) tabulated the differences between \i{}T. fruticosus\i0{}, \i{}T. cinereus\i0{} and \i{}T. rigidus\i0{}. Our species is separated from \i{}T. fruticosus\i0{} by the absence of a spreading rhizome, and consequently by the more tufted growth-form. From \i{}T. cinereus\i0{} it is distinct by the wings of the female flowers exserted from the sides of the floral bracts, and by the sterile sheaths without long, lacerated and consequently silky apical lobes, and by the shorter (less than 5 mm long) and more rigid leaf blades.>

<This species grades into \i{}T. platypteris\i0{} to the north, and is separated largely by the spreading, rather than tufted, growth-form. This is the result of a much stronger lateral rhizome growth, evident on herbarium material. It shares with \i{}T. platypteris \i0{}the widely winged flowers.>

<A very distinctive species. The almost barrel-shaped, dark-brown spikelets with the winged perianth protruding either side of the bracts is characteristic. In addition, the culms have a slight flexing to them which is not found in any other species of \i{}Thamnochortus\i0{}.>

<Similar to \i{}T. arenarius\i0{}, from which it differs by the bracts which are more or less concolorous. The two species are readily separated from \i{}T. lucens\i0{}, which also has a round flower (flower when seed is released as long as wide) by spreading rhizomes. These two species are difficult to tell apart. Maybe the easiest way to distinguish the two species is that \i{}T. arenarius\i0{} flowers in autumn, while \i{}T. sporadicus\i0{} flowers in spring. A further attribute is that in \i{}T. arenarius \i0{}the floral bracts are largely membranous / hyaline, with a narrow brown portion in the middle, while in \i{}T. sporadicus\i0{} the bracts are largely brown, with a narrow hyaline margin.>

<This little species is not readily confused with other species. Its distinctive combination of characters include the neat tussocks, less then 0.5 m tall, the silvery female brachts, and the female inflorescence with one to several obtriangular spikelets.>

<This species is distinguished from the other species with smooth (no striations) culms and with nuts with elaiosomes (\i{}W. glomerata \i0{}and\i{} W. teres\i0{}) by the obovate - spathulate tepals, which narrow towards to the base.>

<The species can immediately be recognised by the greenish spathes which obscure the flowers. Further it has a relatively large, and very distinctively fluted, elaiosome. A rather handsome species. It is similar to \i{}W. sulcata\i0{} in that the culm is striate and the nut has an elaiosome, but differs dramatically from \i{}W. sulcata\i0{} by its distinctly tussocked growthform.>

<This species is closely related to \i{}W. arescens\i0{} and \i{}W. teres \i0{}by the smooth (no striations) culms and nuts with elaiosomes, but is distinct by its small, oblong tepals that do not touch at the margins. In many specimens the tepals are lost altogether. The elaiosome is further distinct by its dark green colour.>

<A very distinctive species. In particular, the cylindrical, greenish nut with up-pointed lobes covering the surface is quite peculiar. The female perianth is also strange, and there may not be the full complement of tepal whorls present. At anthesis the female spikelets are completely obscured by the large spathes, only the stigmas are visible.>

<This is a very distinctive species typical of sandy habitats. Vegetatively the species is distinct by the caespitose habit, and branching and striate culms. The nut is unique, lacking an elaiosome and a very short, compact style.>
<It is probably closest to \i{}W. incurvata\i0{}, to which is allied by the seated nut, and the presence of a nut cap. It differs by the very well developd cap, the small plants.>
<Very distinctive by the nut shape, which is most unusual in this genus. Furthermore, the culms are more slender (diam. 0.5-0.8 mm) than typical in the genus.>

<This species is clearly related to \i{}W. humilis\i0{}, which which it shares the pecular cylindrical, rugose nut, and simple culms. It differs from \i{}W. humilis\i0{} by the almost complete absence of sheaths on the culms, and by the generally smaller male and female inflorescences.>

<Within \i{}Willdenowia\i0{} this species is immediately distinct by the thick, simple culms, and the dense heads of dark red-brown spathes which encase the male and female spikelets. The spindle-shaped nuts without elaiosomes are also quite characteristic.>
<\i{}Willdenowia sulcata\i0{} is readily recognised by the striate culms, the low growth (mostly scattered culms emerging from an extensive underground system), and the nut with an elaiosome.>

<This species is closely related to \i{}W. arescens\i0{} and \i{}W. glomerata \i0{}by the smooth (no striations) culms and nuts with elaiosomes, but is distinct by the tepals that widen towards the base.>

characters.name: <notes on threat status>
data: <Three or four populations on the Cape Peninsula (all protected) and one at Betty's Bay.>

<This species is restricted to the lower reaches of a few streams and in some marshes in the Ceres basin. The streams are subject to modification by damming, by diverting water upstream of the populations, or by the construction of weirs. While I do not know whether any populations have to date been adversely affected, it will surely happen in the near future. Fortunately a large marsh population is in a protected area near Ceres Dam.>
<Recorded as "insufficiently known" by Hilton-Taylor (1996), but several populations on the Cape Peninsula (especially Table Mountain), and from the Hottentots Holland mountains.>
<Two or three populations in the Cold Bokkeveld, widely separated and isolated. One of these populations is under threat from pine plantations.>
<A single population on Vleiberg>

<Recorded as "Vulnerable" by Hilton-Taylor (1996), but there are several populations from the mountains around Ceres. These are in quite well protected areas, vulnerable to unseasonable fires or invasive aliens.>

<Restricted to the Elgin basin, from the Arieskraal Dam to Houw Hoek. The populations at Houw Hoek are probably secure, but the population at Arieskraal is being invaded by alien pine trees. It is likely that there were more populations in areas now covered by orchards and farms. The species has therefore lost most of its populations.>

<Known from only three localities: Wolfberg and the adjacent slopes to Eselsbank in the Cederberg, Baviaansberg, and the Bonteberg. However, the Swartruggens have been poorly collected, and so it could be more common.>
<A single population known along the Langeberg, but there are probably more populations. These are in well-protected areas.>
<Known from one population, which is not in a protected area. The population size seems to vary enormously, it is possible that fire is needed to re-invigorate the population.>
<Known only from Riverlands, present in a protected area. The previous distribution range was much more extensive,>
<Known only from the type collection, from a poorly studied area.>

<There are probably only two extant populations. The Joostenberg population I have not been able to locate, and it may be extinct. The Rietfontein population I have not visited. The Wolseley population is extensive, with hundreds of plants, but restricted to an area of probably 1.5 x 1 km, mostly in the cleared area below power-pylons. This is heavily a forested area, and if the clearing is stopped, this area would soon be overgrown. There are a few subpopulations in the surrounding populations, but apparently next to the road.>
<Might be a taxonomic error - see the notes on taxonomy.>
<Mostly at lower altitudes, but this rating might be extreme.>
<In Riverlands reserve - but most of the other lowland populations have been lost. The two prime threats are urbanisation (greater Cape Town) and the spread of alien plants and agriculture.>

<This species was listed as "Vulnerable", but since then many more populations have been located. The species seems to be able to tolerate light disturbance. However, only one is in a protected area.>
<Possibly several populations: common on lower slopes of Olifantsberg. Although the other populations have not been visited, it seems unlikely that they have all been lost.>
<A lowland species, in which most populations have been lost. There is at least one population in a reserved area.>
<Possibly restricted to the Palmiet River valley>
<Endemic to Misty Point, this species could be vulnerable to inappropriate fire regimes.>

<Very few populations known. The type population is currently (2000) in an area being developed as a housing estate, and will probably be lost in the next few years. Another record is from Pinnacle Point at Mosselbay, an area which is also planned for development. I have not seen any other populations, although there are specimens of them.>

<Restricted to very few localities, all on richer soils, suitable for cultivation. Currently the species is known from only three localities, in close proximity to each other. The species appears to be absent from disturbed areas. It seems to be a long-lived species. This suggests that it might be highly susceptible to disturbance.>
<Known from only one population, in an area potentially threatened by invasive pine trees.>
<Misty Point endemic>
<Several populations in a the Kogelberg Reserve, but the species may not be distinct from \i{}P. anceps\i0{}.>

<Despite the very wide distribution, the following observations are relavent: on Mt Mulanje the species is common, but the Tanzanian population has not been recollected since 1913. The Mt Muhi populations are not well known. And it is not clear what the status of the species is in Madagascar.>
<Known only from one population, in an area under threat from invasive pine trees. In addition, this area seems to be subject to frequent fires.>

<Previously recorded from several localities between Cape Town and Paarl, these have all been destroyed by urbanisation. The species is now known only from Riverlands, where it grows in a local nature reserve. It may be susceptable to inappropriate fire regimes.>

<Although the species has a very restricted range, it is locally extremely common, often being the local dominant. However, it is killed by fire, and is also heavily grazed, suggesting that it could be susceptible to poor fire / grazing management.>
<Quite common high-altitude species from the Hex River mountains>
<Restricted to the Central and Northern Cederberg, but quite common in this area.>

<The species is highly restricted, but is quite common in this area. The whole area is within the Waterfall Reserve, consequently the major threats are alien plants (pines and hakea), and inappropriate fires. Currently the fire regeneration mode is not known.>
<Known from only two localities. The fire senstivity of the species is not known, so it remains possible that a series of inappropriate fires could result in the extinction of this species.>

<Restricted to the Cape Peninsula, to the low mountains between Constantiaberg and Fishhoek. The species has been recorded from 4-5 populations in this small area. Although most of the area is within the Cape Peninsula Park, its sensitivity to fire is not known, and it might be driven to extinction by a set of inappropriate fires.>

<Geographically restricted, but quite common in this area. The fire biology of this species is not known, and it could be sensitive to inappropriate fires. Regeneration after fire should be monitored. Most of the distribution range of the species falls in conserved areas.>
<Restricted to the southern end of the Cape Peninsula, all populations are within a National Park. The two major threats would be alterations to drainage systems, and inappropriate fires.>

<Restricted to the Bredasdorp Plains. There are at least five known populations, and it is possible that the species is quite common in the area. However, it is exposed to several threats, and currently none of the populations falls into a conserved area. The threats are aliens (as at the population at the base of Koueberg), drainage and cultivation of the rich loam soils in the seepages, and unseasonal fires.>

<Although the species is found in mountains, it is known from only three populations. One population is under severe threat from a very ill-advised \i{}Pinus\i0{} plantation (S-Cederberg Suurvlakte), and will be lost unless corrective measures are taken. The status of the other two populations has not been assessed.>

<A lowland species, of which several populations have been lost. The remainder seem to be, at least for the time being, in safer habitats. The species is mostly found in slight seepages, which are susceptible to drying out if the rainfall is inadequate.>
<The species has a restricted range. However, in the Bonteberg it is common on steep slopes, not under threat from cultivation or other forms of modification.>
<According to Hilton-Taylor (1996) this species is "Vulnerable", but this is not likely - it is quite common in disturbed areas from Viljoenshof to Houw Hoek.>
<Known from a single locality, in a protected area. However, the fire sensitivity of the species is not known.>
<Known only from the Audensberg, where it seems to be quite common - although I have not studied it in the field.>
<Known from a restricted area, almost all of it in reserve areas. The most likely threat is inappropriate fires.>

<Known from few localities, all from the lower slopes. At least the localities on the Cape Peninsula are now destroyed, the Somerset West localities are vulnerable; the Bot River locality is very vulnerable, and possibly only the Bredasdorp locality is secure.>
<Known only from the summit of Grootberg in the Langeberg. This area is within a conserved area, but the sensitivity of the species to fire is not known.>
<Restricted to the West Coast plain, most populations have already been lost in vegetation degradation due to farming or invasive aliens.>

<Restricted to the Bonteberg and the southern slopes below Baviaansberg. The species is very common where observed, and the habitat is not likely to be transformed. However, the species might be sensitive to modifications of the fire regime, and being a reseeder might be eliminated by too frequent fires.>
<It is known from three populations, and the general area has been poorly botanised, so it is possible that the species might be more common between Karoopoort and the Grootriver Poort.>

<Historically widespread and certainly locally common on the Cape Flats. Currently the only conserved population is in the Riverlands Nature Reserve. The major threat would be inappropriate fires, and alien invasions.>
<The spatial extent of this species has not yet been mapped, but the species is reported to be locally very common.>
<Hilton-Taylor (1996) listed this species as "Indeterminate", but there are several populations along the Langeberg, all in quite well-protected mountain fynbos.>
<Known from a single locality, where it is described to be "very rare". Since this locality is almost inaccessible, the only human activity that could affect it would be climate change.>
<A very localised species, known from two or four populations. However, there is some doubt about the distinction from \i{}C. marlothii\i0{}.>

<Known from a single population, in a generally well collected area. The major human impacts in this area are changed fire frequencies, climatic rainfall changes, and the possibility of alien invasions.>

<Restricted to one mountain range, and the habitats fall within both private and municipal nature reserve areas. The fire sensitivity of the species is not known, and consequently it may be vulnerable to an inappropriate sequence of fires.>
<Restricted to a narrow section of the Klein Swartberg, and very restricted in habitat terms.>
<Restricted to the summits above Swellendam, but quite common in the area.>
<Only known from two localities. It is possible that it is also found in the mountains between these two localities, but it is also possible that the two localities represent two distinct species.>

<Known from a single population. It is recorded to be locally frequent, and the area is quite well protected. The major threats would be climate change (the species is found in a very vulnerable habitat, in seepages), or inappropriate fire regimes.>

<Hilton-Taylor (1996) listed this species as "Vulnerable", but even though it is found in the lowlands, and has lost a number of its populations, there are still several populations over a wide distribution area, several in protected areas.>
<Known from a single locality, in a rather rugged and in accessible area. There appear to be no immediate threats to this species.>
<The species is found in seasonally waterlogged habitats on the coastal plain. Several of these have been drained, and the species has been lost from several of its previous populations.>
<Known only from a single population, where it is locally common.>

<Restricted to the basin of the Brandewyns Rivier near Clanwilliam. The species is found on sandstone outcrops, in areas not suitable for cultivation. Thus, although the species is not found in protected areas, it is currently not threatened.>

<Known from only four populations on three more or less adjacent peaks. Since these high peaks have been well explored, it can be assumed that it will not be found on other peaks. The major threat might well be fire - as the habitat sounds like a fire-refuge habitat.>

<There might be only two populations of this species, although the records from the Nuweberg are not really adequate to establish the exact number. Even if more, the species is still very restricted. Both populations are in conservation areas, but the sensitivity of the species to fire, and to a slight drying in the climate, is not known.>
<Known from several populations, all in areas too poor for cultivation. The only protected populations are those within the Cederberg Reserve. These seems to be no particular threat to this species.>
<Known from three collections from the Baviaanskloofberg. The area is botanically poorly known, and it remains possible that the species is more widespread.>
<Known from only one population, in an area under threat from alien invasion, and exposed to frequent fires. It falls in a conservation area, but will require active management to survive.>

<Endemic to the Kamiesberg, where it has been recorded from several peaks, suggesting that there are several sub-populations. There is no formal protection for any of these populations, but the species is found among granitic boulders on the upper slopes of the peaks. The major threat is probably unseasonal fire.>
<Known only from one population along the Klein Palmiet River, the species probably has more populations.>

<Common on the Witteberg above Laingsburg, but restricted to this one range. There is no formal protection for this area, but it is not suitable for cultivation. The major threats would be from unseasonal fires.>
<Known only from one area, the conservation status of which is not known.>
<Restricted to the hills around Viljoenshof. This area is increasingly being disturbed by spreading cultivation, and protea-farming.>

<Common along the upper summit ridge along the middle section of the Great Swartberg, particularly common on south-facing ledges and ridges in fire-protected habitats. There is no particular threat to the species, apart from climatic change.>

<It is currently recorded as "rare", but there are numerous populations over a wide distribution area. Although the species may occasionally be locally rare, I have also seen some pretty extensive populations. These arid mountains are still relatively poorly explored, and the species could be much more common than currently thought.>

<This species is known from two populations on the inland margin of the Langeberg. The area is poorly explored, and it remains possible that there may be more populations. But even so, the species will not be common. It is in need of better documentation.>

<The current classification of "Vulnerable" might be more extreme - the species is found in several reasonably protected areas, but not in any formal reserves. It is susceptible to invasive plants, and to changing managemetn patterns. It would need to be monitored.>

<There is some doubt that this is a distinct species. If it is, then it should be classed as rare. It is probably not vulnerable, as there seem to be no anthrogenic modifications of the envionment in this area.>

<Although the species has been listed as Rare by Hilton-Taylor, it is quite common with an extensive distribution range. Many populations are not in protected areas, but there seems to be no threat currently against its survival.>
<not really known, as only 1 or 2 populations of the species have been found.>

<This species is known from few localities on the coastal plain, in areas currently being transformed. Several populations (such as the Burchell habitats near Mosselbay) have probably already been lost. The current status of the species needs to be detailed.>
<Endemic to the summit plateau of Table Mountain and Constantia Peak. Although Constantiaberg is a more vulnerable population, the main population on Table Mountain should be secure.>

<The species has a limited distribution. None of the populations fall into conserved areas, and much of its distribution range is under threat from aliens, as well as from land transformation for protea farming, and has holiday resorts.>

<This species is known from only a few localities, and only one (in De Hoop) is in a protected area. However, the species is sufficiently widespread that it should not be at immediate risk of extinction.>
<Only known from one location, but common at this site, and well protected.>

<Collected only once, in 1918, from the north slopes of Table Mountain near Kloof corner. Since then these have been afforested, Table Mountain road and the Lower Cable Station were built, and the area had been invaded by alien plants. These factors could have led to the extinction of the species - it has not been recollected.>

<The species is known from only two localities. It is now extinct in one locality: partially due to a dam being constructed on them, partially due to a pine plantation. The second locality is in a reserve, but since it is the only known locality, it needs to be protected agains alien plants.>
<Only three populations of this species are known from the Kogelberg. Although the area is well protected, the species might be vulnerable to inappropriate fire regimes.>

characters.name: <notes on economic use>
data: <Comment on one herbarium sheet that the species was used for thatching in the past.>
<Used in dried flower trade.>
<Planted at Kirstenbosch, but apparently not commercially available.>
<One of the first Restionaceae to be introduced to cultivation, it is still one of the most popular restios, and has been on sale from Kirstenbosch since 1994.>
<Planted rather occasionally, but available from several nurseries.>
<This species was used to make the walls of a cottage in Hopefield. It is also one of the more popular species on sale from Kirstenbosch.>
<Commercially available, introduced by Kirstenbosch.>
<Occasionally sold from Kirstenbosch.>
<Occasionally sold from Kirstenbosch.>
<Occasionally sold from Kirstenbosch.>
<Sold in 1995 and 1996 from Kirstenbosch, it is not clear whether this handsome species is still in the trade.>
<Cultivated at Kirstenbosch, it is not clear yet whether the species is commercially available.>
<Occasionally on same from Kirstenbosch.>
<Available from Kirstenbosch since 1998.>
<It is not clear whether this species is in cultivation. It was sold from Kirstenbosch from 1996 to 1998, but is not as handsome as \i{}Elegia persistens\i0{}.>
<Available from Kirstenbosch since 1996.>

<Local as thatch in various places, especially in Bredasdorp area. This species probably originally provided the thatching for the settlement at Cape Town, as it might have been common along the flood plains of the Black and Salt Rivers. Currently, it is widely sold as a garden plant, and is used extensively for landscape gardening.>
<Several herbarium specimens note the heavy grazing on the plants, and personal observation corroborates heavy grazing by sheep.>
<It is not clear whether this species is still in the horticultural trade. It was briefly marketed by Kirstenbosch in 1996 and 1997.>
<This species was marketed by Kirstenbosch in 1997, but not since. So it might well no longer be in the trade.>

<Although the plants make a magnificent display when planted as beds, they are relatively shortlived, and probably need to be replanted every 2-4 years. This is one of the more popular species on sale from Kirstenbosch.>
<Heavily grazed by Hyrax.>
<Many of the populations seen in the field have been heavily grazed, presumably by cattle.>
<According to the West Coast farmers, this is heavily grazed by livestock as well as wild animals.>
<It has been on sale from Kirstenbosch since 1996.>
<A popular garden plant, on sale from Kirstenbosch since 1995.>
<This species has been available from Kirstenbosch since 1994.>
<Although this species is cultivated at Kirstenbosch, seed was available only in 1996. It is not clear whether the species is available elsewhere.>
<On sale at Kirstenbosch only in 1997.>

<This species has been in cultivation for at least a century (see Andrews, S. & McClintock, D. (1982). Notes on \i{}Restio subverticillatus\i0{}. The Plantsman\i{} \i0{}37\b{}: \b0{}230-233.), and is one of the more handsome restios. It is one of the more popular species sold from Kirstenbosch.>
<On sale at Kirstenbosch only in 1994.>
<Cultivated extensively at Kirstenbosch, this species has been on sale since 1996.>
<Cultivated extensively at Kirstenbosch, this species has been on sale since 1996.>
<This species has been occasionally available from Kirstenbosch.>
<Cultivated at Kirstenbosch, this species has been occasionally available from the Kirstenbosch gardens.>
<It is used locally use, with \i{}T. punctatus\i0{}. Said to make a superior roof, which lasts at least 50 years.>
<Cultivated at Kirstenbosch, and the plants have been for sale since 1994. The silvery foliage is particularly attractive.>
<Harvested extensively in the Albertinia area, often commercially. It is also used extensively over the rest of the range, but not commercially sold.>
<Cultivated at Kirstenbosch, and occasionally on sale, it is not clear how commonly it is used outside Kirstenbosch.>

<This is the main restioid used for thatching, and is the mainstay of the commercial thatching industry. Harvesting the plants is almost entirely restricted to its "natural" area, between Cape Agulhas and the Gouritz River, along the coastal plains. Many areas are being managed for this species, resulting in the species forming large almost mono-specific stands. There seems as yet no attempt to farm the species. It is also one of the more popular garden plants, on sale from Kirstenbosch since 1994, and seen in many suburban gardens.>
<The Muiskraal population has been harvested, but I do not know how extensive harvesting is, and whether the culms have been used only locally, or commercially.>
<Cultivated at Kirstenbosch, the seed as available from 1996 to 1998.>
<This handsome plant has been available from Kirstenbosch since 1994.>
<Used occasionally on West Coast for thatching. It is said to make a superior roof to \i{}T. insignis\i0{}, and I have seen a roof that is 50 years old, and still in very good condition.>

<This common species is rarely used for thatching, but rather commonly for brooms. It is very heavily grazed by cattle, which take the female nuts, and male inflorescences. The cattle do not seem to eat the lower culms, consequently grazed tussocks have a rounded-off look about them.>

taxa.name: Cannomois primosii <(Pillans) H.P. Linder comb. nov.>
